PROCTEXT.PARA: The PRESIDENT (Senator the Hon. Kerry Sibraa) took the chair at 10 a.m., and read prayers.

TALK.START.PARA: —Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows:

PETITION.TITLE: Community Services and Health Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the President and members of the Senate assembled:

We, the undersigned medical students and medical practitioners of Australia, oppose changes to general medical practice contained in the Community Services and Health Legislation Amendment Bill 1989. We believe:

All Australians should have equal access to our health care system and that there should not be two tiers of medical insurance rebates for general practice and we reject the concept of a vocational register for general practitioners.
Undergraduate training in general practice should be upgraded and that ongoing medical education should continue to be controlled independently by the profession.

The mechanism for establishing the vocational register proposed in the legislation violates the ethics of the medical profession as embodied in the Declaration of Geneva, and is totally unacceptable. (See Medical Ethics on the reverse side.)

We pray that the proposed changes to general medical practice contained in the Community Services and Health Legislation Amendment Bill 1989 should be rejected outright by the Senate and that it should be replaced with a broadly based consultative process to address the problems within general medical practice and general practice training.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senators Coulter (from 84 citizens) and Powell (from 605 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Community Services and Health Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the President and the members of the Senate. We the undersigned oppose changes to general medical practice contained in the Community Services and Health Legislation Amendment Act. We believe there should not be two levels of Medicare rebates for general practice. We also believe there should be upgraded undergraduate training and postgraduate training for general practitioners to obtain appropriate skills. Current and proposed Medicare rebates for general practitioner services are inadequate, and there should be appropriate Medicare rebates for doctors who provide out of hours consultations.
Therefore we humbly pray that the Senate in Parliament assembled will support general practitioners to achieve the above.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senators MacGibbon (from 35 citizens) and Sheil (from 200 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Pharmaceutical Drugs
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and senators in Parliament assembled; the humble petition of the undersigned citizens showeth:

that your petitioners deplore the Federal Government's decision to remove 53 Pharmaceutical drugs-including the best available for the treatment of high blood pressure, cancer, epilepsy, high cholesterol and uneven heartbeat-and place them, for cost saving reasons only, on a special list requiring Authority from a Canberra Bureaucrat, and;

that we believe a patient's doctor is clearly the best judge for medication needed for their particular illness and that it is therefore wrong and unfair to force that doctor to waste valuable time referring a case to a person in Canberra who has no personal knowledge of that case.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Senators in parliament assembled will call on the Government to immediately abandon the proposal and keep its election promise of high quality and universal health care for all Australians.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and member of the Senate in Parliament assembled: This humble petition of certain citizens of Australia respectfully draws the attention of the Senate to the Governments attack on the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme, which has severely affected the viability of our community pharmacies and their ability to provide the quality and quantity of services to which we as Australians have a right.

Your petitioners respectfully request the Senate to urge the Government to guarantee an adequately funded Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme, so as to ensure the continued viability of neighbourhood pharmaceutical services through our local community pharmacies.

PETITION.TITLE: Vietnam: End of War List
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned showeth that:
The members of the Australian Armed Forces who served in the Vietnam from 1962 to 1973 did so with distinction, valour and professionalism, upholding the traditions of the Armed Forces.
After World War 2 and the Korean War the Australian Government approved an End of War List of Gallantry Medals for individual acts of bravery that were not rewarded during wartime.
The Whitlam Government refused to approve such an End of War List at the end of the Vietnam War.
Your humble petitioners pray that
The Federal Government reverse the decision of the Whitlam Government and thus approve an End of War List for the Australian Armed Forces personnel that served in Vietnam.
Upon the approval of the End of War List, the case of the 2nd Lieutenant John Fraser, 3RAR be considered for the award of a posthumous military honour.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Medicare: Abortions
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President of the Senate and the senators in Parliament assembled: The Humble Petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That every abortion kills an unborn human baby.
That the right to life of all humans is the most fundamental and essential of all human rights.
That the Government's first duty is to protect this right to life.
That the most defenceless and threatened lives are those of unborn babies for whom the Government is duty bound to take extra steps to protect.
That in 1987/88 taxpayers funds through Medicare provided Medical Benefits for 61,879 abortions totalling $6.4 million.
That in the same year Commonwealth grants to the States indirectly financed the deliberate killing of thousands of other unborn babies in State Public Hospitals.

Your Petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Australian Parliament will carry out its duty to protect the right to life of Australian babies by ceasing to fund abortions through Medicare, restricting grants to the States and by all other means at its disposal.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senators Boswell (from 1,008 citizens), MacGibbon (from 1,226 citizens), Panizza (from 451 citizens) and Sheil (from 1,206 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Medicare: Abortions
PETITION.PARA: The Honourable President and members of the Senator assembled in Parliament. This petition of the below citizens of Australia draws to the attention of the Senate that we support the continued cover for all abortions on the Medicare schedule. We oppose any attempt to restrict access to the rebate under Medicare.

Medicare cannot pretend to be a Universal health care system without providing a rebate for a termination of pregnancy. These who will be hardest hit by proposals to restrict access to items 6469, 274 and 275 on the Medicare schedule are poorer and disadvantaged women who will not be able to meet the cost of a non-subsidised abortion.
Your petitioners humbly pray and request that the Senate will vote against any attempt to restrict access to abortion or any abortion-related items on the Medicare schedule.

PETITION.TITLE: Housing: Interest Rates
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled: The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
1. That we consider the current level of interest rates on home mortgages to be intolerable;

2. That we believe that Senator Haines' Income Tax Assessment (Housing Loan Interest) Amendment Bill 1989, which provides for tax relief for mortgage payers and is currently before the Senate, provides reasonable relief to the current unacceptable situation;
3. That the Senate assembled should, therefore, urgently debate and pass Senator Haines' Bill;
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: World Heritage List
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of certain citizens of Australia shows:-That Fraser Island and the other parts of the Great Sandy Region qualify for World Heritage Listing because of outstanding Values:
Geological-The World's greatest sand mass and the oldest age sequence of Giant Coastal dunes; perched dune lakes; barrage dune lakes unknown elsewhere.

Biological-Coastal heathlands, freshwater swamps, mangroves, the World's only rainforest growing on high coastal dunes, ancient paperbarks; 750 species of flowering plants and ferns; wallum; wide diversity of marine, terrestrial and avian fauna, some of which is rare or endemic.

Aesthetic-40 Kilometres of coloured sand cliff faces, volcanic outcrops, over 40 perched dune lakes, the majestic Noosa river, wildflower-strewn heathlands, vast surfaces of loose mobile sand, rainforests, crystal-clear fresh-water streams.

Cultural-Evidence of large populations of Aborigines in the region-middens, bora rings, canoe trees, implements and other artifacts; historical artifacts from the last 150 years-2 operating lighthouses, shipwrecks.

Your petitioners therefore pray that the Commonwealth Government take action to place Fraser Island and the other parts of the Great Sandy Region on the World Heritage List to ensure proper recognition of the region's international importance and to ensure appropriate management to preserve its unique qualities.

PETITION.TITLE: Violent Television Programs
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President of the Senate and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled: The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth, that:
We are concerned about the increase in violent television programmes for children and particularly those programmes promoting violent toys that are available for sale in Australia.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray;

That you support the Broadcasting (Prohibition of Violent Programmes for Children) Act 1988 which has been presented by WA Independent Senator for Nuclear Disarmament, Jo Vallentine. This act aims to prohibit the broadcasting of children's TV programmes that are violent and that promote toys modelled on characters, weapons or other war accessories which are also available for sale in Australia.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senators Jones (from 91 citizens) and Vallentine (from 23 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Kakadu National Park
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable President and members of the Senate in Parliament. The petition of the undersigned shows:
That we oppose any mineral exploration or mining in any part of Kakadu National Park, the Kakadu Conservation Zone, or the Alligator Rivers Region.
Your petitioners ask that the Senate, in Parliament assembled, should:
Halt all mineral exploration and mining in the Kakadu conservation zone by revoking current leases and licences and by incorporating the zone in Kakadu National Park and;

Prevent proposed mining in Kakadu stages one and two by incorporating the Jabiluka and Koongarra project areas in the National Park and by proclaiming the whole park under the World Heritage Properties Conservation Act, 1983.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Kangaroo 89 Joint Military Exercise
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable President and members of the Senate in Parliament. The petition of the undersigned shows:
From June to September 1989 Australia will host the Kangaroo `89 joint military exercises involving 28,000 Australian and United States troops from the air, navy, and land forces;
The exercise coincides with a massive increase in Australian military expenditure on frigates, submarines, helicopters, and joint military exercises;
Your Government's own defence paper states that Australia is without direct threat of invasion;
The Australian and New Zealand Governments are prepared to intervene militarily in the Asia Pacific region;
And believing that the Kangaroo '89 exercises are designed to:
Stimulate fear of invasion in the public;
Encourage acceptance of increasing Australian militarisation and continued dependence on the US alliance;
Your petitioners request that the Senate, in Parliament assembled, should:
Cancel the Kangaroo '89 joint military exercise;
Allocate the $230 million due to be spent on the exercise to the public health, housing, education, and other urgently needed social and welfare projects.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Timber Harvesting Operations in New South Wales
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament. The Petition of the undersigned shows the strong opposition of Australians to woodchipping in SE forests of NSW.

Your Petitioners request that the Senate, in Parliament assembled, should ensure that the licence to export woodchips exclude the key proposed national estate areas of Tantawangalo, Coolangubra and Egan Peaks.
Further, we humbly request the Parliament to ensure that these areas are fully protected from all timber harvesting operations.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray:

PETITION.TITLE: Environment
PETITION.PARA: To The Honourable The President and members of the Senate assembled in Parliament. The humble petition of certain citizens of Australia draws to the attention of the Senate our deep concern for the future of our environment.
Your petitioners therefore ask that stricter laws and penalties be drawn up and enforced to:
Protect and conserve forests
Control mining our resources
Minimise industrial pollution, and
Cleanse waterways and oceans.
We humbly request that programs be introduced to educate the public to:
Recycle waste products
Conserve energy
Use alternative energy resources, and
Conserve and replant forests.
We, the students of Marymount Primary School, agree to take responsibility for our school and home environments, and we charge you, as our elected representatives to protect our natural heritage.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: COULTER

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I present to the Senate the following petition from 40 petitioners requesting that that provisions of the Community Services and Health Legislation Amendment Act 1989, relating to vocational registration of general practitioners, as considered by the Select Committee on Health Legislation and Health Insurance, be rejected:

SPEECH.PARA: We the undersigned patients of general practitioners humbly pray that the following be brought to your attention:

We feel that the health care system at present is unfair and discriminatory and this legislation will only serve to worsen the situation.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —Pursuant to the procedures provided by the resolutions of the Senate of 25 February 1988, Senators Hamer, Teague and Newman have written to me raising a matter of privilege. The matter raised is an alleged unauthorised disclosure of a report of the Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade before the presentation of the report to the Senate.

INTERJECT.PARA: Under the Senate's resolutions, I am required to determine whether a motion to refer the matter to the Committee of Privileges should have precedence over other business. In making this determination I am required to have regard to the following criteria:

(a) the principle that the Senate's power to adjudge and deal with contempts should be used only where it is necessary to provide reasonable protection for the Senate and its committees and for senators against improper acts tending substantially to obstruct them in the performance of their functions, and should not be used in respect of matters which appear to be of a trivial nature or unworthy of the attention of the Senate; and
(b) the existence of any remedy other than that power for any act which may be held to be a contempt.

In making determinations in the past, I have indicated to the Senate the way in which I have interpreted and applied these criteria. I have given precedence to motions relating to matters which are capable of being regarded by the Senate as meeting the criteria in paragraph (a), provided that there is no readily available other remedy.

The matter raised is clearly capable of being regarded by the Senate as meeting those criteria, if the facts are as alleged. The unauthorised disclosure of a document confidential to a committee, which includes a report not yet presented to the Senate, is declared by the Senate's resolutions to be a matter which may be treated as a contempt. The Senate has in the past treated such unauthorised disclosure of committee documents as a contempt. There is no readily available other remedy.

I have therefore determined that a motion to refer the matter to the Committee of Privileges should have precedence over other business. Any of the honourable senators who wrote to me may now give a notice of motion.

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the following matter be referred to the Committee of Privileges: Whether there was an unauthorised disclosure of the report of the Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade on visiting nuclear-powered or armed vessels, and whether a contempt was committed by a person who made such an unauthorised disclosure.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave of the Senate to move notice of motion No. 333 standing in my name, notice of which was given on Tuesday. Yesterday, with a brief explanation, I sought to move it as a formal item. I had had discussions with the Opposition and it had agreed to support it, as had the Australian Democrats, with a couple of technical amendments, in particular the spelling of `Myanmar', the new name for Burma, and the deletion of one word. Unfortunately, I had not had the time to show that to Senator Harradine by the time it was called on and he objected to it being declared formal. I understand he now has no objection, and I seek leave of the Senate to move the notice of motion formally, with the amendments.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
Motion (by Senator Schacht) agreed to:
That the Senate-

(a) condemns the Myanmar (Burmese) Government for the arrest and detention without trial of Aung San Suu Kyi, Secretary-General of the National League for Democracy (NLD), U Tin U, Chairman of the NLD and many other NLD members throughout the country;
(b) calls on the Myanmar Government to release immediately Aung San Suu Kyi and all other political prisoners;
(c) notes that, unless all political prisoners are released, the announcement of the Myanmar Government that there will be free and fair elections by May 1990 will have no credibility;

(d) further calls on the Myanmar Government to lift all restrictions on political activity, such as freedom of speech, freedom of assembly, freedom to organise and freedom to establish independent trade unions, noting that free and fair elections cannot be held unless these fundamental human rights have been established and guaranteed for all the people of Myanmar;
(e) calls on the Australian Government to make the strongest possible representations to the Myanmar Government to achieve the release of Aung San Suu Kyi, U Tin U and all other political prisoners;
(f) requests the Australian Government to seek the assistance of other democratic countries who have representation in Myanmar to make a joint approach on these matters to the Myanmar Government; and

(g) requests the Australian Government not to restart any of the presently suspended aid programs for Myanmar until substantial progress is made towards the restoration of human rights and democracy in Myanmar.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lewis Sen A.W.R

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Leader of the Opposition, Senator Chaney, I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That in relation to the decision of the Government to increase the postage entitlement of the members of the House of Representatives as announced in the letter dated 16 August 1989 by the Minister for Administrative Services (Stewart West, MP) there be laid on the table of the Senate, not later than 2 p.m. on 29 August 1989, a written statement by the Manager of Government Business in the Senate (Senator Ray)
(a) explaining in detail the reasoning behind the Government's decision to increase postage entitlement;

(b) indicating why the Government chose to ignore the recommendation of the Remuneration Tribunal in its 1988 Review that members of Parliament generally be provided with access to the full range of postal services provided by Australia Post subject to an annual limit of $9,000; and

(c) explaining why it is considered that while a significant increase in the existing postage entitlements of members of the House of Representatives is necessary with immediate effect, senators should continue to receive their existing entitlement indexed to changes in the mailing rate.

This matter was debated in the chamber last evening. It has been the subject of a number of press releases and statements to the media and has received a run in the press. The motion which I have moved today gives the Government, in effect, until the first day of the next sitting week to come forward with some proper explanation to the Senate as to what this is all about.

The Remuneration Tribunal in its determination in 1988 determined that senators and members of the House of Representatives receive a postal allowance of $9,000 a year. I do not recall the Government jumping up and down about that or indicating that it was not adequate for members of the House of Representatives, but now when we are in a position where it is clear that the Government has become quite desperate about its chances of winning the next election, it has taken this decision out of the hands of the Remuneration Tribunal-at some stage during the debate I will be seeking to ask the Government whether it is entitled to take these matters out of the hands of the Remuneration Tribunal; I hope that we will get some assurance that it is entitled to do so-and made a decision which massively increases the allowance for members of the House of Representatives with regard to their postal allowance from $9,000 a year to approximately $30,500 a year, or thereabouts. An increase of about $21,000 in postal allowance at this particular time is a very strange decision and I think the Senate is entitled to a proper and adequate explanation.

At a time when the Government is talking about cutting back, here it is prepared to spend an additional $3m, or thereabouts. Further, previously the $9,000 was to be expended over the full term of the year; in other words, by quarterly allowances. The Government has said, `Look, we have backdated this to 1 July. You can go ahead and spend it as soon as you wish'. In other words, as soon as the Government decides on an election date they will be able to go out and absolutely flood their electorates with material in relation to the forthcoming campaign.

The Government has its direct mailing arrangements in order. No doubt it has distributed the discs around to the various members of the House of Representatives and they will be ready to fire as soon as the Government presses the button. This is a blatant political gimmick. There is not the slightest doubt that this Government has become absolutely desperate to hold its seats. What gives the game away is that the Government has not said, `We will give this to all senators and members of the House of Representatives', it has given it only to members of the House of Representatives. The reason it has done that is that it has a vast majority in the House of Representatives. There is an enormous advantage to the Australian Labor Party in granting these funds to the members of the House of Representatives. Not only is this a significant political disadvantage for the non-Government parties, but also the whole timing of the arrangement, the fact that the money can be spent at once, in effect puts the Australian Labor Party in a position where it can conduct a massive direct mailing campaign. It is clearly politically driven, as is the Budget itself, as we have pointed out.

Earlier today I gave a notice of motion providing the Senate with an opportunity to debate the matter of whether any expenditure of this amount should be made before the Budget is passed. That is another matter which is of grave concern to us. We will be very unhappy if we discover that the Government has used funds out of the Advance to the Minister for Finance to enable some members of the House of Representatives to go on and undertake expenditure in excess of the $9,000 allowance divided quarterly at any stage since 1 July.

We are saying that this is an Australian Labor Party rort. There is no doubt that it is rorting the system for pure political purposes in an attempt to spend taxpayers' money to get itself re-elected. It has spent a massive amount in the Department of Social Security, promoting itself on television advertising all over Australia-a massive amount of taxpayers' funds, not Australian Labor Party funds-and is talking about having free time on television. The Labor Party has got itself to a stage where I am sure, if it could pass some sort of motion whereby we do not ever bother to have another election, it just remains in office forever, it would take that step. The Labor Party is rorting the system for pure electoral purposes and we want an explanation the day we come back as to what this is all about.

TALKER.NAME: Senator ROBERT RAY
TALKER.ROLE: Manager of Government Business in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —It is always my wont, as Manager of Government Business in the Senate, when I sit in my office, hopefully working hard, to leave the television set switched on with the sound turned down so I can have a rough idea of what is happening in the chamber. At about six o'clock last night I glanced at the television set several times, and I admit to this chamber that I was worried because there was a verve, an elan, a sort of magic look in the eyes of the Opposition senators as they ripped into us on some issue. I saw Senator Michael Baume, Senator Crichton-Brown, Senator Walters, and at least one other Opposition senator, and I thought, `What are we getting a hiding on?'. I have never seen such enthusiasm. At first, I assumed that they were attacking the Australian Democrats again. I thought that was the reason for their enthusiasm. I turned up the sound at about 6.30 to find out that it was about postage. It was not about interest rates, as I had assumed, it was not about nuclear disarmament, and it was not about taxes. The issue that really excited them, that has given them the greatest thrill, and made them express such enthusiasm, was the issue of postage.

SPEECH.PARA: I have remarked before that the one issue that will get a good debate going in here is Opposition senators' own incestuous rights. If they really want to excite people, they talk about their own rights and privileges. If they throw in a bit of chauvinism, they have a recipe for a marvellous debate conducted with enormous enthusiasm. Fancy giving that lot a postage entitlement; they are sitting in here listening to me-and what a waste of time that is!-instead of sending out business letters. Instead, they choose to sit in this chamber.

I put on the record my view that, in general, I support equal entitlements for the House of Representatives and the Senate. It has always been my view that we should not vary them too much; that we should keep a degree of equality. But it is not true that the entitlements are not varied. They are varied in two ways: in actual entitlement and in timing of delivery. On the question of the timing of delivery, it is quite clear that senators in their electorate offices generally got computers later than did House of Representative members. That is one example of a differential in the timing of delivery. The same thing happened with fax machines. It may well be the case with postage entitlements. There might be a difference in the timing of delivery.

Entitlements are not equal; there are differences. Let me outline some of the differences that exist. For example, senators get an electoral allowance of $21,005. House of Representatives members get $21,005, $24,977, or $30,458, depending on the circumstances. The logic is the need to provide a greater degree of service in particular electorates. Another example of where the entitlement is different is in charter entitlement. Some House of Representatives members get no charter entitlement. All senators at least qualify for that entitlement.

TALK.START.PARA: —Some senators get no charter entitlement.

—All senators, bar territorial senators. As Senator Reid indicates, there are even differentials amongst senators. Some in Victoria, New South Wales and Tasmania, get a $5,000 charter allowance. Some in Queensland and Western Australia get $10,000, and those in the Northern Territory get $25,000. There are five different entitlements in the House of Representatives according to different criteria. A further example is that some House of Representatives members get a second electorate office. Those members are those who represent the electorates of the Northern Territory, Kalgoorlie, Maranoa, Grey, and Kennedy.
—Why don't I?

—That entitlement is to be extended after the election to O'Connor and Riverina-Darling. Senator Crichton-Browne plaintively asks, `Why don't I?'. He has never raised this matter before that I know of.
—I have so.

—I have never heard him raise it before. Differential allowances apply elsewhere. One could also say the same with Commonwealth-owned vehicles. The point I am making is that I am not necessarily saying that in every case differentials are justified. I am just replying to those who said last night that there is never a differential. There is a differential and there is also a differential in timing of implementation.

SPEECH.PARA: If this motion is carried the rationale will be put on the table of the Parliament. Would people here seriously argue that the constituent work and turnover in Senate offices is greater than that in House of Representatives offices?

TALK.START.PARA: —Mine is overwhelmingly bigger.
—Frankly, I doubt that that is the case.
—Speak for yourself.

—But I know that, out of a sense of pride, no-one could ever admit it. It is the same as saying that we do a lot more serious work in committees than do members of the House of Representatives. But I very much doubt that the demand on honourable senators from constituents is as high as it is in the House of Representatives. Senator Walters said, `Speak for yourself'. Quite possibly, with the slack lower House representation in four seats in Tasmania, all the work comes to her rather than to Max Burr, Bruce Goodluck or any of the rest of them.

SPEECH.PARA: Before I conclude I want to make two other points. I was asked by Senator Lewis, `Has the Government the right to resume jurisdiction from the Remuneration Tribunal?'. Absolutely. The Remuneration Tribunal was set up to consider salaries and allowances. All those other matters that it has ruled on over the years have been referred to it by government for recommendation.

TALK.START.PARA: —What do you think stamps are if they are not an allowance?

—I know that the subtlety of this misses the honourable senator. I was asked by Senator Lewis whether a government is legally entitled to resume those areas. Currently, it would not be entitled to resume the area of salary or allowance. All those other entitlements were referred to the Remuneration Tribunal by government for arbitration and acceptance by government. As the honourable senator would know, those other matters were not even binding on government. For instance, when the decision was made to have a third staff member it was not made by the Remuneration Tribunal; again a classic example where the power was resumed by the Executive and granted by the Executive.
—You applied your mind to this before you did it. That is good.

—I am applying my mind to what has happened in the past. I did not hear anyone on the other side object to the Executive resuming that section of what was the Remuneration Tribunal's recommendation to the Executive. Not one Opposition senator objected. Of course, the final point, and I think it should be put on the record, is this: what has the Liberal Party of Australia ever done for members of parliament and their entitlements? It has done nothing. When in government it treats members of parliament like stray dogs; it gives them nothing. The first ever staff member for MPs was allocated by the Chifley Government. When did MPs get their second staff member? Under the Whitlam Government. When did MPs get their third staff member? Under the Hawke Government. Every time honourable senators opposite are in government they give MPs absolutely nothing.

SPEECH.PARA: Let me go through the record to show what we have done in the last six years to improve the lot of MPs. We have taken the size of the electorate office from 60 square metres to 120 square metres. We have provided one and in most cases two-or we are getting there-computers in the electorate offices. We have provided facsimile machines. We have provided more flexible staff travel arrangements. Time and time again the Labor Government has looked after MPs. Under Menzies, Holt, Gorton, McMahon and Fraser, MPs were given absolutely nothing. Not one honourable senator opposite would object; they are all toadies, crawling to a Prime Minister because they want to get in the Ministry and they do not have an elected Ministry. They have all got to crawl and grovel to the great leader and not criticise him over entitlements or anything else. Under the Liberal Government, members of Parliament got absolutely nothing. They never got anything. The only time they showed a bit of spunk and a bit of guts was in June 1981 when Doug Anthony was in charge and said, `Yes, we will take the pay rise. Trust me. We'll deliver. Bill Hayden, come out and support it'. When the great leader, who is now a candidate for the secretaryship of the Commonwealth, got back he ratted on the deal. It is typical of the Liberal Party. In my view, this postage allowance is a harbinger for the future. It is another entitlement for members that inevitably, in my view, although not necessarily in any one else's, will flow through to senators over time.

TALK.START.PARA: —Two dollars a week for pensioners!

—Senator Reid can knock back some of her entitlements that she has got over the years if she does not like them. She can knock them back and give us the money back and we will reallocate it somewhere else. When I was Minister for Home Affairs she never rang me up and said, `My entitlements are too great, I feel really guilty about it'.
—I can prove you wrong.

—Senator Reid will restore my faith in human nature if she does, because she has no colleagues over there who can join her in that regard. It does not say much for her persuasive powers that she cannot persuade them all to give some of their entitlements back. I reiterate that, in my view, entitlements to senators and members of the House of Representatives should generally be the same. That is not necessarily the case at the moment; there are variations. I repeat that there are variations in time. When fax machines were introduced to electorate offices we wrote to each party leader and asked that leader to nominate who should get them. Guess who was missing off the list-senators. John Howard did not put one senator on the list. Barry Cunningham, who has the devolved responsibility for the Australian Labor Party, did not put a senator on the list. When we said, `Because workloads are increasing a second computer is necessary', how many senators were put on the list? Absolutely none. So the Opposition's own leadership has said that the workload in the House of Representatives must be much greater than in the Senate. But I do argue that over a period of time any increase in entitlements to one House should flow through to the other. I am sure everyone here today is going to urge Mr President to cut out the third newspaper. Honourable senators get three newspapers while the members across the road get two newspapers. So let us cancel the third newspaper today as a result of the passion honourable senators have shown.
—Right, done!

—Senator Harradine is willing to give up his newspaper to get an extra $20,000 postage. Altruism rides again! Thank you, Senator Harradine, for your gracious sacrificial offer. I will pass that on to the relevant authority.
—No. You are wrong. I think that the Representatives should not get the extra amount. They haven't justified the extra amount. You have not justified the extra amount for them.
—I have argued, whether I have satisfied Senator Harradine in his own mind, that the workload in the House of Representatives' offices is on average much higher.
—I bet you it isn't as high as mine.

—That is the reason why Senator Harradine gets an extra staff member, for a start. People must recognise that independent senators in many cases have a higher workload. I recognise that they have to cover all issues. They are quite often the key votes in this chamber and have to see many delegations. I also recognise how hard it is for independent senators to be right across all the issues. It must be a drastic difficulty at times. I have no doubt in Senator Harradine's case of the workload that would come into his office. I also have no doubt, Senator Harradine being a Tasmanian and having regard to the pathetic Liberal representation at the parliamentary level down there, that he would have to bear a lot of the load of the constituents who come to him for sympathetic advice. I know that Senator Harradine is that sort of person. I have to concede that argument.
—You still haven't got him.
—If the honourable senator can hum the theme tune to Mission: Impossible, I will sum up and finish in a moment.
—Did you ask the Tribunal for its view on postage increases?
—The Tribunal would have received representations on postage increases.
—Did you seek their advice on this proposal?
—Why should I seek anyone's advice? I am not the responsible Minister. I do not have to know what every other Minister does on every aspect of expenditure, and no one should expect me to.

SPEECH.PARA: If this motion is carried I will endeavour to carry it out. I am not sure why my name is included as the person who is to deliver the explanation. If it is carried that explanation will be delivered. I am delighted to see a resurgent Opposition. I am delighted to see an excited Opposition with a gleam of combat in its eye. After six years of only an occasional outbreak, it is united about postage. It is not worrying about nuclear disarmament, taxes or anything else. Postage has brought it to the barricades. Postage has brought it to life. If I had anticipated this result and if I had known that it would have this effect, I would have doubled the extra amount allocated to House of Representatives members just to see the excitement opposite.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-Madam Acting Deputy President, I claim to have been misrepresented. During the opening remarks of Senator Robert Ray he claimed that he turned on his television set to see me speaking with feeling and passion about the question of stamp allocation for the House of Representatives vis-a-vis the Senate. That is quite untrue. It is obvious that Senator Ray had the sound turned down because I was not speaking about that matter. I was speaking about the annual report of the Senate. I was bemoaning the fact that the Minister for Finance, Senator Walsh, had again, with capricious disregard for the necessities of the Senate, cut expenditure to the point where we were no longer able to function.

—I rise on a point of order, Madam Acting Deputy President. Senator Crichton-Browne is no longer involved in a personal explanation. He is obviously repeating his eminent speech from yesterday. As I was able to dodge it yesterday, I claim the privilege of dodging it again.
—I rise on a point of order, Madam Acting Deputy President.
—What exactly is your point of order?

—My point of order is that it was claimed that I was speaking with passion and feeling on the issue which is before the Chair at present. I was speaking on a totally different subject. The only way in which I can demonstrate that is to refer to what I was speaking about.
—Thank you, Senator Crichton-Browne. You have made your personal explanation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Puplick Sen C.J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —The issue which has prompted Senator Lewis's motion today is not simply the question of postage entitlement. Postage entitlement is part of what is now becoming an extraordinarily serious question for the Parliament to address-that is, the consistent pattern of attempting to shift the burden of financial responsibility for the election campaign of the Australian Labor Party away from the Labor Party and onto the shoulders of the Australian taxpayer. That has been achieved in part by a number of devices. I do not propose at this stage to go into all of them but simply to indicate what they are and to say something very briefly about this overall pattern.

SPEECH.PARA: The first and most obvious has been the misuse of the National Media Liaison Service-the deliberate attempt to use public funds to pay for the monitoring of statements made by the Opposition and their circulation to the Government's alleged political advantage. The second arises from the report of the Joint Committee on Electoral Matters-the attempt to transfer the cost of political advertising from the political parties to the commercial television stations. The third was an attempt by this Government, prevented only by combined activity by the Opposition parties, to use public funds to promote one side of a particular referendum case. The fourth has been the production of a whole series of glossy publications which were referred to yesterday by Senator Newman and others in terms of departmental publications allegedly put out for the purposes of public information which, nevertheless, are simply propaganda documents for the Government and its policies of the day. The fifth is this question of postal allowances. I will come back to that in a moment. Essentially it relates to the transfer from Labor Party members in marginal seats of the cost of their direct mail activities for re-election purposes to the public purse. The sixth deals with the cuts which Senator Crichton-Browne was talking about yesterday: the deliberate attempt to ensure that the Senate, where the Government does not possess the force of numbers, is systematically wound back in its capacity to play its proper role in the parliamentary process and to scrutinise the passage of legislation. The Minister for Finance (Senator Walsh) is deliberately seeking to hobble the Senate by the restrictions that he places upon it.

The next part of this shabby deal, I predict, will come when the Government starts fiddling with the media reach legislation in order to ensure that the quid pro quo with its friends in the media is carried on to a situation in which the Government makes offers to the media barons about the extent to which it proposes to increase their power and influence. But the whole overall pattern is a quite clear, quite deliberate, quite planned pattern of activity. It goes to the question of shifting the cost of the re-election campaign of the Australian Labor Party off the shoulders of the political party and on to the shoulders of the Australian taxpayer.

This tactic is part and parcel of the whole Government strategy. Let us remember that it was the Labor Party which introduced the system of public funding of election campaigns which the coalition parties have said that we will repeal upon our election to government. I put it to you, Madam Acting Deputy President, that that public funding, the `Animals' operation, the changes in the cost of election advertising, the attempts to advertise only one side of the referendum questions, the production of the departmental glossies, the increase in postage, and the restrictions on the power and capacity of the Senate to manage its matters are all part and parcel of the current systematic attempt by this Government to shift on to the shoulders of the Australian taxpayer the costs which would otherwise have to be borne by the Australian Labor Party itself.

We now have an increase in the postage allowance that puts into the pockets of members of the House of Representatives the additional sum of $413 per week, which I suggest ought to be offset against and compared with the sum of $2 per week to be put into the pockets of Australian pensioners. The $413 is to be backdated whereas, with the $2, it is a question of waiting for another six months before payment actually flows through. This is perhaps an indication of the relative importance which the Government gives to its own re-election strategy compared with the importance it gives to the benefits it will give to the Australian pensioner community.

As Senator Lewis rightly pointed out, we believe that the Remuneration Tribunal is the appropriate body where these matters should be determined. Section 7(1) of the Remuneration Tribunals Act 1973 provides:

The Tribunal shall, from time to time as provided by this Part, inquire into, and determine, the allowances (including allowances in accordance with section 48 of the Constitution) to be paid out of the public moneys of the Commonwealth to members of the Parliament by reason of their membership of the Parliament or by reason of their holding particular offices, or performing particular functions, in, or in relation to, the Parliament or either House of the Parliament.

We accepted that it was correct and proper to view the postal allocation as part of the allowances which the Tribunal should determine on the basis of representations made to it and on the basis of evidence put before it.
Yesterday the Minister for Administrative Services (Mr West), in his circular to honourable members and senators in relation to postal services, said:

This facility is seen as an essential cost of operating Senators' and Members' offices rather than a remuneration issue and, accordingly, the Government has decided the entitlement is more appropriately one for consideration by Government.

Honourable senators will note that the statement says that the matter is one that is to be considered by the Government. Therefore, the Government has made a determination about the expenditure of money out of public revenues, but it has sought to backdate it and therefore, presumably, to make it available to members of the House of Representatives to expend, prior to the passage through this Parliament of an appropriate appropriation for the department concerned to pay for that. That itself raises a very serious question which goes to the notice of motion that Senator Lewis gave for debate on another occasion-namely, the allocation to members of parliament of money to spend on political purposes prior to the Parliament passing the appropriation to authorise that money to be expended. That is equally a serious matter for consideration.

In the statement of the Minister for Administrative Services, the facility is described as an essential cost of operating `Senators' and Members' offices'. The determination is, then, made by the Government-not by the Tribunal-that on this occasion senators and members are to be dealt with separately. Members are to be provided with an increase from $9,000 to $30,525 and senators are to have their allowance increased only by an indexation to the mailing rate. That is not a determination made by the Tribunal.

Senator Ray previously dealt with the question of differential allowances made by the Tribunal in relation to charter or in relation to electorate allowances. I have made representations to the Tribunal saying, for example, that senators' electorate allowances should be fixed at the same rate as the maximum allowance made to members of the House of Representatives. The Tribunal has examined that matter and decided not to proceed along those lines. But that was done by the Tribunal exercising its independent judgment about what it thought was the correct and appropriate way for that to be handled. This decision, however, has not been made by an independent body like the Tribunal. It has been made by the Government to discriminate positively against senators. The Government was not unaware, for example, of the disparity between the representation on our side of the chamber compared with the representation on the Labor Party side of the chamber in both the Australian Capital Territory and the Northern Territory. The Government has therefore quite clearly indicated that in terms of the Australian Capital Territory and the Northern Territory it knows full well that this advantage is one which can be exercised at the moment only by members of the Australian Labor Party. The Government has made that decision quite consciously.

In his remarks yesterday, Senator Macklin pointed to the question of the number of constituents he has. He described the number of people who voted for him in terms of a first preference vote being something like the equivalent of three divisions in Queensland. Senator Harradine has made the same point. Many honourable senators are established and well known for the amount of electorate and constituency work that they do. It is simply not possible to argue that senators do not have constituency responsibilities and that they are not entitled, therefore, to the same degree of communication with their constituents as members of the House of Representatives.

It is interesting to note that, when the Australian Constitution was being framed, one of the things that were looked at was the parallel with the American Constitution. At the time of the adoption of the Australian Constitution, American senators were still elected by their State legislatures. They did not become elected by the people of the States of the United States until 1913 or 1914. The constitutional fathers of this country decided that the principle that they wished to enshrine was not that senators should be elected by State legislatures but that senators should be directly elected by the people of the States and that they should have direct constituency contact through the process of direct election. So it has been fundamental to the nature of the Senate to establish the principle that senators were elected directly by the people of the States acting as their constituents. The argument, therefore, that they are not entitled to the same consideration in relation to the communications which they have with their constituents in the same way as members of the House of Representatives has never been a valid one. This is therefore not an attempt to resolve this on the matter of principle that the House of Representatives people have constituency responsibilities and senators do not; it is an attempt by the Government to resolve it on a deliberate ploy of discriminating against senators in terms of their capacity to communicate with their constituents, the people to whom they are responsible and from whom they derive their legitimacy by election to this place.

I do not propose to take any more of the time of the Senate this morning because this matter will come back for debate in August, if the resolution is passed. But I do make these points. First, the argument that senators do not have direct constituency responsibility is false and always has been false. Secondly, the argument put forward by the Minister, Mr West, in his letter was that this increase in allowance was necessary in order to allow members of parliament to operate in the most effective fashion. It is the Government-not the Tribunal-which has made the determination to allow members of the House of Representatives a privilege, an advantage, an allowance, which it is not prepared to allow to members of the Senate. Thirdly, I repeat the point which I made previously about the overall strategy which this Government is putting in place of transferring the costs of the Labor Party's election campaign from the shoulders of the Labor Party to the shoulders of the taxpayers through those devices of public funding, the `Animals' operation, the changes to electoral provisions about free advertising time, the attempts to advertise only one side of a referendum campaign, the departmental glossies which are being put out in support not of public information but of government policy, the changes to the postal allowance which we are currently debating, and the cuts to the Senate in order to prevent it from exercising its proper political role in this bicameral system.

Finally, I refer to the steps which the Government will undoubtedly take to do some sweetheart deals with its mates in the media about ownership and control issues. I put it to the Senate that it is important to carry this resolution so that this matter can come back for debate on 29 August, when we will be in a position to scrutinise precisely what the Government seeks to argue and to expose the fact that it is arguing nothing other than that this is to the political advantage of the Australian Labor Party and the taxpayers will have to cop the burden of it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —When I suggested last evening in a discussion with Senator Chaney and Senator Lewis that it might be better to move a motion so that rather than debate the matter today we could debate it later when the Government has an explanation, I thought today's motion would be carried with only a short debate. However, it has not turned out that way. I suppose, therefore, that I should put our view on the record. It differs from that of the Opposition. The numbers in the House of Representatives differ by only 16. Therefore, we believe the support provided is not support of Government members, as such; rather, it is support of the House of Representatives vis-a-vis the Senate.

SPEECH.PARA: Our problem with the statement put out by the Minister for Administrative Services (Mr West) is that it did not justify the increase. No justification was provided in the statement for the increase. We have a mechanism for providing that type of justification-the Remuneration Tribunal. It would have seemed to us sensible and reasonable to go to the Tribunal to argue a case. If the Tribunal had then said on the weight of the evidence that the increase should be granted, I am sure there would not have been a debate in this place. There has been no inquiry into the weight of work done by members of the House of Representatives vis-a-vis the work done by senators. Everybody knows-it is not a secret-that some people in this place do what is called in the trade `sweet stuff all'. It is the same in the other place. Other people work their tails off. It is the same in any of the political parties: some people do nothing; some do a lot. But if we do an averaging exercise we have to do it between the average work senators do and the average work that is done by members of the House of Representatives. I think that that exercise is better not done by somebody in the House of Representatives or somebody in the Senate. We all tend to gild the lily in our own favour. An independent tribunal would be the sensible way to do it.

I have just made some notes here in terms of my own position in Queensland. There are 125 paid politicians in Queensland at State and Federal levels. There is one Australian Democrat. I welcome anybody to come into my office to look at the pension and immigration inquiries I get, at the inquiries about roads and about everything else. I have to travel over an entire State. Many senators do that. It is grist to the mill. Senator Collins represents the Northern Territory and we have made a differential allocation to Senator Collins. The differentiations that were mentioned by the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs (Senator Robert Ray) are there but they are based on certain principles. They are based on geographical distances, for example, or the fact that Senator Collins has an island attached to his electorate.

TALK.START.PARA: —Two.

—Two islands separated by enormous distance. The Remuneration Tribunal has given Senator Collins the ability to fly to those islands. He cannot represent the people on them if he cannot get there. But, as a senator for Queensland, I cannot go to those islands, despite the fact that they are part of Australia. I am not complaining about that; I am saying that the differentiations that have been made to date have all been based on the principle that individual members or senators have to represent a particular type of electorate. No one worries about that at all.

SPEECH.PARA: When we look at the principle that has been put by the Minister for Administrative Services with regard to this proposition, however, it is one of having constituents. Nothing else was mentioned in the letter-not that people had to fly to distant islands or that they had a large geographical area to cover but simply that they had constituents. When Senator Puplick raised this issue I think I heard Senator Ray say by way of interjection that nobody was arguing that. I hope not. As Senator Puplick pointed out in the history, from the very beginning this has been a fully elected House. At that stage the upper House in Britain was hereditary. The upper House in Canada-that is, the Senate-is still nominated by the government of the day and the American Senate is elected by the State legislatures. This Senate, however, has always been elected by constituents.

So we have constituents. Those constituents, in terms of the differentiation of power between the two Houses, since it has shifted towards the Senate, make astute political judgments about who they see. They do not bother going to see people in the House of Representatives any longer; they come and see senators. Why do they do that? Members of the electorate in Australia can add up. They know it is useless to go and see members of the House of Representatives, because nothing can be done. People will go along and see a senator, however; the numbers are different in the Senate and something might happen.

If any independent tribunal sat down and started to look at who came knocking on whose door, I would be quite happy. We would come out a long way ahead. It is useless to go knocking on the door of most of the people at the other place-except Ministers' doors. Nobody else can do anything. Members have been hived off into Caucus committees to keep them happy and working hard so that they do not interfere with the Government. Opposition members pound at the door. They do not get anywhere so they come and talk to their senators to try to get something done. It happens not only with members of one's own party; I get representations from members of the House of Representatives from all parties. That is an absurd situation. There are representations not only from those in the electorate but from people in the other place. Let us have a bit of sanity. I am sure that any independent inquiry would disclose that.

We would accept whatever decision the Tribunal made because the inquiry would be done in an open, fair and reasonable manner. Our concern is not that they have got $30,000 and we have got $9,000 but that no justification whatsoever has been offered. Therefore, we need Senator Lewis's motion to be carried to find out what the justification is. Secondly, there has been no inquiry. On a matter such as this, quite frankly, I think there should be an inquiry. The people of Australia are entitled to an inquiry when there are significant increases in costs. When I looked at the Budget Papers on Tuesday night it struck me that the $4.2m there for postage would surely excite somebody's breast. Why was it there? Where did it come from? I had not heard that we were getting an increase in postage allowances. When this matter came out in a letter the following day I had to read it two or three times before I believed it.

By the way, the figures in the letter are wrong. The figures actually show that there can be one postage per person in an average electorate. Members of the other place have been given $30,000, which actually covers three mailings to each person in an electorate, not one. Those doing the calculations did not bother to take into account the discount postage one gets for bulk mailing and the fact that within an electorate 70,000 people do not live in 70,000 houses. It is basically three mail-outs. The reason for retrospectivity is so that members can get the entire amount for this year rather than part of the amount.

TALK.START.PARA: —How will they audit it?

—Senator MacGibbon asks how they can audit it. It could not possibly be audited. I have been a strong proponent of the idea that the obligation in all these matters should be taken away from the departments and given to members of parliament. I like the American system where the member of parliament has to account for the dollars that he or she spends. We all now have computers. It is a very simple process for us to have an accounting system in those computers. I think we should be keeping the figures, the bureaucrats should not be keeping them. However, that is a different debate. I think we and not the bureaucrats should be accountable for what we spend. The bureaucrats do not represent the people; we do. I would be quite happy to do that and to account for every dollar I spend. I think then the people would know what was going on and it would be a much more open and accountable system, with the people of Australia being able to scrutinise what we spend. I think that is only fair and reasonable in any democracy.

SPEECH.PARA: I do not think these things should be hidden in bureaucratic budgets; I think we should stand up and be accountable for what we spend. We should say, `We spent that in this way and people have got good value for dollar'. People could look at what we do. It might be part of the reason that people vote for us or do not vote for us-that they see the way we actually spend the money with which we are provided to represent the electorate.

It seems to me that this is another silly exercise that has gone on without much thought. I am not sure that I agree with an interjection by Senator Michael Baume that this was a massive conspiracy. I must admit that I still go along with my previous leader on this matter: if one has to choose between a stuff-up and a conspiracy one always goes for a stuff-up around this place. I think that is what it is. I do not think this is a conspiracy. I do not think the Government even thought about it. I think it should now go away and think about it. That is what this motion provides. When those responsible come back they may have an explanation for what they are doing. I am sure that if we had asked them today we would not have got an explanation. Senator Robert Ray, as usual when he is really on the back foot, made a very entertaining speech. He shines very well in that situation. He talked about the Opposition shining last night. Senator Robert Ray always comes in here and does his best when he is defending the indefensible. He did that again today in a splendid speech but, if one looks at it, he did not try to defend the proposal. He referred to only one principle throughout the entire speech, and that is that the allocations made to senators and members should be equal. That is the only principle that he said he upheld. During all the rest of his speech he was trying to pull the wool over our eyes. We need an explanation for this. I hope the explanation will include a justification for the taxpayer being hit again for this amount of money and upon what basis only members of the House of Representatives should be considered to have constituents while senators are not.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lewis Sen A.W.R

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply-I rise to close the debate. It has been demonstrated today that the Government, so far, has not given any explanation at all-let alone any satisfactory explanation-and no justification for this massive increase in the postal entitlement of members of the House of Representatives. It appears that this allowance has been granted by the Government for blatant political purposes to help its members in marginal seats to hold their seats by enabling them to conduct a substantial mailing campaign in their electorates.

SPEECH.PARA: I agree with practically everything that Senator Macklin had to say, except that I disagree with him when he said that this exercise had not been given much thought. If one examines the way in which the Australian Labor Party has been conducting its political campaigns over the last decade, one will see the degree of expertise applied to a vast range of tactics. One can observe the way in which the National Media Liaison Service operates now, and the fact that yesterday an alleged statement by one shadow Minister was purported to contradict something that another shadow Minister had said-but that is doubtful. Such incidents are blown up in the newspapers so that there appears to be a major crisis within the coalition parties. It is, of course, absolute nonsense that there is a crisis. It indicates the political strategies and capabilities of this Government. Believe me, nothing is done accidentally or without much thought in relation to the Labor Party and its campaigns.

TALK.START.PARA: —They have probably already got their draft mail out.

—As Senator Bishop says, they have probably already got their draft mail out. I said earlier that I have not the slightest doubt that the discs have been prepared, the money will be in the bin and, at some appropriate stage just prior to the election, the buttons will be pressed and the mail will go out. The Government does not have to tell members the date of the election, we will know the date because constituents will come to us saying that they have received strange letters, apparently signed by Mr Hawke and their local member.

SPEECH.PARA: There is no doubt that the Labor Party's strategies are very clever. As I said, the Labor Party has examined all of the things that have been done in the past by coalition governments. It has examined things that have happened overseas-campaigning techniques in the United States and Great Britain-and has adopted and adapted those systems and techniques so as to become a past master and an expert at campaigning. In particular, at this stage in its campaign for the next election, the Government is trying to mislead the public by pointing to problems that do not exist. We really cannot tell just what will be the far-reaching consequences of this postage entitlement proposal. As I say, there is not the slightest doubt, having regard to the debate which has taken place here today-including the remarks of Senator Ray-that there is clearly no explanation of or justification for it, yet there is a desperate need for an explanation to be made to the Senate. I say to the Senate and to the Government that if the explanation and the justification are not satisfactory when we return here on 29 August, there will be a very substantial debate about the matter.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Consideration resumed from 16 August, on motion by Senator Tate:
(1) That the Senate take note of the recommendations of the Select Committee on Legislation Procedures, and the 3rd and 4th Reports of the Procedure Committee for the 63rd Session.
(2) That further consideration of the recommendations and the reports be an order of the day for the first sitting day in December 1989.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.TITLE: ABORIGINAL AND TORRES STRAIT ISLANDER COMMISSION BILL 1989

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 26 May, on motion by Senator Robert Ray:
That this Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —This is a second reading debate on one of the three Bills-the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission Bill 1989-which make up the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission (ATSIC) package of the Government. They are the most important pieces of Aboriginal legislation we will see in this decade. The Bill before us seeks to establish ATSIC. It seeks to make necessary arrangements; it seeks to abolish other pieces of legislation; it seeks to abolish all the arrangements that exist with the States on Aboriginal matters; and it seeks to abolish, in clause 202, the Aboriginal Development Commission (ADC). The Aboriginal Development Commission Bill will be the subject of another second reading debate, and I will speak on that at that time. However, I say at this stage that we shall oppose the emasculation of Aboriginal self-management and the nobbling of the Aboriginal Development Commission, and we vigorously oppose any attempt that might be made actually to dismember the Aboriginal Development Commission ahead of ATSIC arrangements being put in place.

SPEECH.PARA: We enter this debate after a year and a half of unprecedented turmoil and disturbance in the portfolio of Aboriginal Affairs. During this time the ATSIC legislation has been floated and promoted. Eight acting commissioners of the Aboriginal Development Commission have been sacked. The reputations of those eight acting commissioners have been traduced. During this past year and a half scandals were revealed about the administration of the Department of Aboriginal Affairs and the portfolio agencies, which culminated in the dismissal of the Secretary of the Department; we learned of activities on which the Auditor-General has reported so adversely; and there was the appointment and report of a select committee of the Senate into the administration of Aboriginal Affairs. During all of this time, with all these things happening, the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Mr Hand), rather than concentrating on the reform and improvement of the Department for which he was responsible, concentrated on the development of the ATSIC concept. He did so, initially at least, with little or no input from officers of the Department. Also during the past year and a half misleading answers were given to the Parliament by the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs on several significant and distinct matters.

Those of us who have spent part of our lives working with and on behalf of Aboriginals have become deeply and permanently affected by that experience. I suppose one could say we have become marked by what we have learned of the evidence of deprivation and disadvantage. We have become committed to overcoming that deprivation and to the lessening of that disadvantage. Certainly the various people who have been Ministers for Aboriginal Affairs or who have been involved in Aboriginal affairs might have different ways of giving expression to that concern. Certainly we on this side differ from Mr Hand on questions of political theory and practice, but because it is neither necessary nor helpful, we do not question the commitment of Labor Ministers for Aboriginal Affairs to the task before them. I observe, however, that it is regrettable and unfair that the present Labor Minister has not made the same acknowledgment of the motives of his predecessors. The road to hell is paved with good intentions, and the good intentions of the Minister are not enough. Wanting to improve outcomes does not, of itself, improve outcomes. Neither does it justify the ATSIC proposal.

I return to this Bill for an Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission. I can do no better at the beginning of my remarks than to quote the words I wrote with Senator Boswell for the dissenting report of the Senate Select Committee on the Administration of Aboriginal Affairs which investigated and reported on this proposal. Those words were:

The proposal for an Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission (ATSIC) is unjustified, unnecessary, and culturally inappropriate. The detailed proposal that has emerged in the Bill is faulty and unsafe.

If pursued it will operate to the detriment of the very people it is designed allegedly to serve. It is likely to lead to worse outcomes than those produced by the bodies it is to replace, to worse services for Aboriginal and Islander people, to less accountability of the Commission and its servants to the Aboriginal and Islander people, and to less accountability to all Australians.

If those assertions are even partly true-Senator Boswell and I believe they are correct-then it is incumbent upon us not to allow this legislation to proceed, and if we are determined to have it proceed, not to let it proceed in the form now before us.

The difficulty is that views differ. What I see as likely outcomes, some see as imagination; what I see as facts about what is happening in Aboriginal Australia, some see as error. On this side of the chamber we have a crystal clear view that these undesirable outcomes will be the legacy of this legislation. Labor Party senators who served on the Senate Select Committee did not at any stage challenge the proposition underlying ATSIC: they were bound by the Government and Caucus decisions on the threshold issue that there would be a new Commission; they were bound by decisions that it would incorporate other bodies, that it would combine administrative and elective functions and so on.

The Australian Democrats too seem to have accepted the threshold proposition and thereafter have concentrated their attention on questions of detail and process-and they are important questions. But if outcomes for Aboriginal people will not be improved demonstrably by this new Commission, then ATSIC fails. If it does not produce better outcomes, it fails. I am talking about better process outcomes as well as better outcomes in health, education, employment, enterprise formation, housing, land acquisition, lower rates of imprisonment and better police statistics. Those are the outcomes that must flow and which we must be able to expect. They are the outcomes that Aboriginal people need so desperately. I hope it is a multi-partisan concern that those outcomes be achieved; that is, we should all want to see the most disadvantaged, depressed and hopeless Australians strengthened and allowed to succeed.

The Estimates document from the Department of Aboriginal Affairs last year, 1988-89, contains a portfolio overview, which sets out in stark point form some of the more awful statistics of Aboriginal disadvantages. About the aims of this program it goes on to state:

Government and other services should be adapted and expanded as necessary and certain special benefits-not generally available to other citizens-should recognise Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islanders' unique circumstances, their history and identity.

But the problem is that not all approaches, even by well meaning people, will achieve worthwhile outcomes, certainly not the worthwhile outcomes I outlined a moment ago. We think ATSIC will not work. We fear that it will fail to deliver. We believe that outcomes will actually be worse. Further, when one reads the Bill one sees how the Commission will be structured. We fear that the structure will lead to Aboriginals inevitably being blamed when ATSIC fails. We see this as a setting up exercise. The Commission will not work and Aboriginal people will be blamed when it does not work. It is, in short, a set-up of Aboriginal people by the Labor Government. I am charitable enough to believe that it may be a set-up motivated more by ignorance and foolishness than by malice. But this ATSIC legisla- tion is flawed. It is an awful Bill. It is unnecessary; it is incomplete; it is ideological in its purposes and approach.

It is a very major change to Aboriginal administration and it is notable that there has never been a justification for ATSIC made by the Labor Government that introduces it. There has never been a coherent justification-certainly no justification has ever been made known in any credible way. This is not just point scoring; it is vital to the future of Aboriginal people. Just to talk about self-determination is not enough. I remind honourable senators that at the same time we are introducing ATSIC in the name of self-determination, the Government has prepared another Bill to destroy the Aboriginal Development Commission (ADC), which exists in reality as an instrument of self-determination by Aboriginal people. The Government has never explained why it is necessary to destroy the ADC.

If no convincing justification has been offered for change, then why make the change? I have been told by colleagues that there is an old saying from New England which states, `If it ain't broke, don't try to fix it'. Why, for instance, should we not prefer an alternative approach? Why should we not try to reform the existing portfolio agencies? There is no a priori justification for this quite radical suggestion for an Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission and there is no justification which flows from any of the events of the last few years. On the contrary, those of us who have worked in the portfolio and who know many of the people remain convinced that the outcomes, which we are willing to accept are the goal of every Minister for Aboriginal affairs, could better be achieved in other less radical, less threatening and less destructive ways.

As an Opposition, it is not our job to justify or defend any alternative proposition. Nor is it our first responsibility to propose improvements to meet the basic purposes of the Minister; it is the obligation of the Minister, of the Labor Government and of those who want to introduce ATSIC. It is the obligation of those who are proposing radical change to offer some credible justification for what they propose. So far they have not ever done so.

The Minister has justified his approach on the basis of his claims of consultation with the various Aboriginal communities. For a start, this is not an adequate justification for this structure. Even if it were, the Senate Select Committee unanimously voted that the claims of the Minister to have consulted widely were unjustified. We all-Labor, Democrat, Liberal and National party members-found that the consultation process had been inadequate and incomplete, and that it had been less than had been promised.

TALK.START.PARA: —What has he done since?
—That is a very good question. That Senate Select Committee report came down some time ago and the Minister should have moved to redeem these promises.
—Twenty-eighth February.

—Thank you, Senator Boswell. The Minister, during the earlier consultation period promised, at 46 community meetings, that he would seek their agreement in principle and that he would return with details of the proposed legislation before it was introduced.
