He promised that he would allow people to have some say in the details. He told them that all he was seeking was approval in principal for his general thoughts. That is not the way it panned out. Honourable senators may have seen the Sydney Morning Herald of yesterday in which Mr Charles Perkins is reported in the following terms:

SPEECH.PARA: Mr Perkins said that ATSIC was a good concept but that the-
then it quotes Mr Perkins-
`mechanics are flawed dramatically' and more consultations were needed with Aboriginal people.

I suggest to the Government and to my colleagues in the Senate that we should pay particular attention to the claims of Mr Charles Perkins that the mechanics of ATSIC are flawed dramatically. He would not have said that without some reason. He said it because it is correct-the mechanics are flawed dramatically.

The Opposition is grieved as much as it is upset by what is going on. One would have expected a Labor Government committed to the highest principles of public administration to have responded to the report of the Senate Select Committee by redeeming its promises and by completing the processes of consultation. One would have thought that the Minister would have responded by correcting what he had failed to do even though he had promised to do it, but of course the Government and the Minister did not redeem their promises. The Minister did not answer the specific criticisms of the Senate Select Committee. Honourable senators may recall that we invited him to show a little charity and courtesy for the eight dismissed commissioners. Did he do that? He did not. He did not redeem his promises as he should have done and he did not redeem his promises as some other Ministers would have done; he simply repeated his determination to proceed with the ATSIC legislation. He repeated the very same mistakes that the members, including the Labor members of the Select Committee, had complained of-failure to consult adequately. That is a major objection. He has never, ever redeemed that mistake.

The Labor members of the Committee, who are in the majority, identified clearly-as, in fact, did the entire Committee-failures of process and failures to deliver promised consultation. The Government, while it did pick up some of the recommendations of the Select Committee, decided to ignore others. There is no reason priori why government must automatically accept every recommendation of every committee-I do not expect that-but neither is there any reason for those associated with unanimous recommendations not to persist with them if we think that they have merit. One thing we can say about that Select Committee is that it took a lot of trouble over the recommendations it put forward. We may have a chance to try to persist with some of our recommendations later.

Let us come back to what this Bill is all about. The Minister asserts that a new structure is necessary to enable better outcomes to be achieved for Aboriginal people. There is nothing in the new arrangements that logically or necessarily gives promise of any better outcomes. The Minister then asserts that self-determination by Aboriginals is essential for the outcomes of Aboriginal people to improve. It is his version of self-determination, it is his concept of what it means, that makes the ATSIC proposal so mean. The Minister has promised the Aboriginal people power over decisions affecting them, to use his language. He has promised them money to put the decisions into effect, and he has promised them support for the decisions that they take. In fact, and in law, they are not going to receive those things. It is a cruel and cynical deception. Aboriginal power over decisions will remain in important respects subject to ministerial veto.

TALK.START.PARA: —He has total power.

—As Senator Boswell says, he has total power. Funding will remain, I must say properly and inevitably, as it was always going to be, subject to the normal processes and constraints of government and of the Budget cycle. But that was not made clear to people. In any event, the arrangement is conceptually flawed. It is like putting out to the Australian public a proposition and saying to veterans' organisations that all decisions on veterans' affairs and all public funds for veterans' affairs are to be placed under veterans' control independent of the general community or of the normal mechanisms of accountability to the Parliament and to the public which provides the cash. Such a proposal would be laughed out of court. It would be seen as a fraud; it would be seen as being inconsistent with constitutional proprieties; it would be seen as being inconsistent with the administrative or financial realities and imperatives. But the ATSIC proposal proceeds on the same or equivalent basis. It is a proposal which is crazy in every way.

SPEECH.PARA: The public administration of Aboriginal affairs is to be taken outside the structure and processes of government and placed in a new structure supposedly based on what the Minister has called `community', and what the Minister has also called `grassroots'. It seeks to replace a department that has been magnificent in the past and which could be magnificent again were it not for the fact that the Minister it now has is administratively incompetent. The failures of the Department of Aboriginal Affairs are, more than anything else, failures of the Minister, Mr Hand, of his administration, and of the amateurs and zealots with whom he surrounds himself. He has worked to destroy the effectiveness of the major Aboriginal controlled organisation in Australia; that is, the ADC. He sacked a competent and professional board and replaced it with sycophants and cronies. They were able to force out the chairperson, Shirley McPherson. But even in that supposed victory the Minister was ungracious, and Shirley McPherson, the chairperson for five years and a Commissioner for seven, went with scarcely a word of thanks from the Government. The Minister insists on incorporating the functions of another Aboriginalised body-that is Aboriginal Hostels Ltd-into the new structure. There has been no justification for that ideological decision either.

My objective, and the objective of the Opposition, remains the achievement of better outcomes. Our objective remains the achievement of outcomes such as less illness, fewer Aboriginals in prison, more effective Aboriginal participation in education and the education system, greater Aboriginal longevity, more people housed, better housing, more people in employment, more Aboriginal people in senior administrative positions, fewer alcohol and drug problems, and so on. The question before the Senate now is whether or not ATSIC is the vehicle to achieve the outcomes. Sadly, it is not. This proposal is more likely to remove Aboriginal Australians from the mainstream of Australian life, to emphasise Aboriginal separateness, to require Aboriginal people to operate in a system different from other Australians and to make them into welfare recipients forever. If ATSIC proceeds, they will be the victims of a new paternalism. The damage which ATSIC will do to Aboriginal Australia may be irremediable; at the very least it will take a generation to fix.

At the very least the ATSIC Bill will require amendment to the extent recommended by the Senate Select Committee. It will require an attempt at the very least by the Senate to make the Bill workable. The Opposition will oppose this legislation at the second reading stage and at the third reading stage. In another debate we will do what we can to defend the Aboriginal Development Commission from the attack made on it. At the committee stage we will discover whether the many amendments, which we think are necessary to bring about some of the improvements, can be achieved. I conclude by saying again to the Senate that if this legislation passes it may be a parliamentary victory for the Government but it will be a very sad day in the longer term for Aboriginal Australia.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McKiernan Sen J.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —After some considerable time the Senate is debating the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission Bill 1989. It has been a long time getting here and, certainly, it is not before time. The Bill concerns particularly and specifically 1.4 per cent of the Australian population-200,000 Aboriginals and Torres Strait Islanders. I explain at the beginning of my contribution to this debate that I do not consider myself to be an expert on Aboriginal affairs. I do not seek to match my experience and understanding of the Aboriginal Affairs portfolio with that of the previous speaker, Senator Peter Baume, nor with that of many other honourable senators in this place. That is not to say that I have not had some involvement with Aboriginal communities both in the State of Western Australia, which I represent, and in other parts of Australia. Despite the stories and the television reports, I was shocked to see the conditions under which some Aboriginal people live in some parts of Australia-not all of them but certainly far too many-in this latter part of the twentieth century.

SPEECH.PARA: I shall not seek to reply point by point to the contribution made by Senator Peter Baume. However, he made the point that the Opposition is looking for better outcomes in this legislation. It is a point that the Government and I think every resident of Australia should be considering when looking at the question of Aboriginal affairs. It is unfortunate that this Bill is not going through this chamber with bipartisan support. Certainly we will argue about individual points of policy but, overall, we should look for, as Senator Baume said, better outcomes. I believe-and this is where we differ from the other side of the chamber-that this Bill will provide for those better outcomes. What better outcomes do we need? What yardstick are we after? What is the situation at the moment? For explanation, let me run through some points of measurement that can be used both now and in future years. As I said, Aboriginal people account for only 1.4 per cent of the Australian population. Their average life expectancy is 15 to 20 years less than what it is for other Australians. That is a deplorable state of affairs and it is a yardstick that we will be using in future years when this legislation comes into effect. Aboriginal infant mortality is three times that of non-Aboriginal Australians. Aboriginal people suffer from a higher incidence of both communicable diseases such as hepatitis B, and lifestyle diseases such as diabetes and heart attacks. Aboriginal unemployment is six times the national average. Nobody should be unemployed at all, but that a section of the population experiences six times what the rest of Australians experience is pretty deplorable. On average, Aboriginal people earn only half the income of other Australians. Many Aboriginal families live in substandard housing or in temporary shelter. Some live in appalling conditions. I am sure that honourable senators have witnesses this for themselves and have been as shocked as I have been. It is not something one gets used to; it is something one works to change for the future. Aboriginal imprisonment rates, which Senator Baume referred to, are 14 times higher than those of other Australians. I make the point in passing that we have currently an inquiry being undertaken in Australia on black deaths in custody. It is one of the ramifications of this horrible statistic. Again, it is an issue which is not directly measures by the legislation or its contents but one that can hopefully be addressed with goodwill once it is in place.

Aboriginals in remote communities are often without basic essential services which the rest of Australia takes for granted, services for which the rest of Australia continually demands improvement and rightly so. Some communities do not even have running water. We know how important water is to human life in this country. Some of the people live in areas with a very harsh climate. Recently I was in the Rudall River region of my home State and experienced for a few brief hours just what it is like to need water. The Aboriginal culture is being threatened continually, and in some cases already has been destroyed.

TALK.START.PARA: —This will destroy it worse.

—I am talking about destruction. Let me move on. I think this will be a fairly fiery debate because there has been much point scoring in the lead-up to the debate in this chamber today and there will be over the next few sitting days and perhaps weeks. There have been a number of inquiries and investigations into the Bill. Some have been referred to already by the previous speaker. One such inquiry was by the Senate Select Committee on the Administration of Aboriginal Affairs. I will quote selectively from page 20 of the dissenting report and we all understand what dissenting report means. Under the heading `Aboriginal Affairs in disarray' the report states:

SPEECH.PARA: Over the past few months, a picture of utter disorder in the administration of the Aboriginal Affairs portfolio has emerged. This is thanks largely to the persistence of Opposition senators . . .

I make no apology for using selective quotes because it is a fair political tactic. The persistent attacks by Opposition senators have resulted in a number of inquiries. A report by the Department of Finance on the financial management of the Aboriginal Development Commission (ADC) was presented in March 1989. There was another report from the Department of Finance entitled Report on certain staff classification matters in the Department of Aboriginal Affairs; reports from the Public Service Commission entitled Reports on allegations about personnel management in the Department of Aboriginal Affairs; and a special audit report from the Auditor-General on the Aboriginal Development Commission and the Department of Aboriginal Affairs. An inquiry was also instituted entitled Inquiry by Mr A. C. C. Menzies into Allegations as to the Administration of Aboriginal Affairs. An interim report was presented in April 1989 and a final report was presented in June 1989.

What are the catalysts for all these reports? Banner headlines appeared in newspapers right around Australia which alleged that a black mafia was in existence within Aboriginal affairs portfolios in Australia-within the Department of Aboriginal Affairs and within the whole aegis of Aboriginal matters. Further allegations of patronage, favouritism, nepotism and implied corruption were also made.

As I have said, we have had-and I went through them individually-a series of reports. The last report of Mr Menzies was presented in this chamber two days ago. In my reading of those reports nowhere has any of those allegations been proven. In the final stages of getting this legislation onto the books I challenge the Opposition to present evidence of those allegations. I have challenged the Opposition and we will await the evidence, as it is not contained in these reports that have been presented to us. The allegations have not been substantiated in any way. If the time were available, we could go through each and every one of the reports to see just where they are.

It is a sad affair that the political parties have split so dramatically on this portfolio. I will go back to the outcomes that we are looking for. There is an obvious need for governments and for politicians to do some work to improve the lot of the original inhabitants of this wonderful country. But what do we do? We turn it into a political bunfight. We point-score between ourselves in the hope of winning votes and, on the way through, we forget about the main objectives. It is obvious that political parties will point-score. But I think that the Government, in addressing these allegations and smears over the past year and a half or so, has kept in mind the firm objective; that we have to improve the lot of the original inhabitants of Australia.

We have listed very carefully what those objectives are. The Hawke Labor Government works for social justice for all Australians. The Australian Government is committed to this objective. It seeks to establish a fairer Australia and to eliminate the disadvantages due to language, religion and culture. But in a multicultural society the Australian Government seeks to ensure that all Australians have full and equitable access to available programs and services. One of the highest priorities that we have set ourselves in the social justice arena is a strategy to advance the economic, social and cultural position of Aborigines and Torres Strait Islanders. Aboriginal Australians hold a unique place in our multicultural society. The promotion and maintenance of this uniqueness is integral to government policies and programs.

What is the Opposition's alternative to the sentiments I have just expressed? We get accusations of patronage, favouritism, nepotism, cronyism and corruption. It has been said that individuals who do not have the right to come into this chamber under parliamentary privilege to defend themselves against accusations are accused of being sycophants and cronies. I was particularly disappointed that Senator Peter Baume used terms like that. I expect that from some other Opposition senators; I certainly did not expect that from Senator Baume. But I still hold that honourable senator in high regard.

We are trying to achieve with this legislation a fair and equitable social justice system in our multicultural society. I know that sections of our community reject the fact that we are a multicultural society, but there is living proof, before the eyes of Australia, in the fact that I, as a migrant to this country, am evidence that such a society exists. The legislation which is before us today provides the means by which Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people can be directly involved in the processes of government, particularly as those processes affect the rights of Aboriginals and Torres Strait Islanders. That is a commendable objective but one which, in turn, finds disfavour with some Opposition senators. There have been accusations that what we are putting forward in the Bill is culturally inappropriate to Aboriginal people. The argument used by Opposition senators and many others is based on the reality that traditional Aboriginal society did not develop representative structures and placed a high value on individual autonomy. Perhaps that was so in the long distant past, but recent experiences, under coalition governments as well as under this Labor Administration, disprove the allegation that this Bill is culturally inappropriate. The major flaw in the argument is that it ignores present day realities of a pluralist society which places great store on the representative structure at all levels.

As I have said, Aboriginals have about 20 years experience with community-based bodies and organisations. They have shown in that 20-year period that they have the ability to adapt in order to take advantage of the social, political and economic structure of modern day Australia. Some examples of Aboriginal bodies which were established by the previous Fraser Government are: the National Aboriginal Conference, the National Aboriginal Consultative Committee, the Council for Aboriginal Affairs and the ADC. Senator Baume, in his contribution, also alluded to these examples.

Many of the allegations which I have referred to went into the area of finance-how it is spent and how accountable are those organisations receiving taxpayers' funds. Certainly the reports show that there have been difficulties in certain areas. Those difficulties that are referred to did not just emerge when the Hawke Labor Government took office or when Gerry Hand was appointed Minister for Aboriginal Affairs. They emerged under a previous administration. There have been previous examinations-auditors' reports, the Department of Aboriginal Affairs and the ADC-which pointed out that there were a number of flaws in the way in which funds were accounted for. Those flaws have been addressed over a period. Certainly the Department of Aboriginal Affairs has had its problems, as has probably every other department of any government since this nation was established.

The ATSIC Bill incorporates a range of strengthened accountability measures which will ensure that the Commission's expenditures and programs are fully accountable to the Parliament. These measures do not detract from the rights and responsibilities of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people. It has been argued that by putting in this clause we are enhancing and furthering the control of bureaucrats over the affairs of Aboriginal people. Perhaps that is so, because the politicians are the elected representatives of the people. We have got control over how taxpayers' money is expended. In turn, we have got to be accountable for those funds and the expenditure of those funds. If we are not, then the taxpayers will take it out on us at the ballot box when the elections are held. We have to have accountability. The buck has to stop somewhere-that was not meant to be a pun-and it must stop in the Parliament with the Executive Government and with the Minister responsible.

In relation to this Bill, we were aware of some of the deficiencies that existed in the Department of Aboriginal Affairs and the ADC. We have learnt from those experiences and we have built into the ATSIC Bill strengthened accountability measures which will protect taxpayers' funds. Despite the statistics I went into at the beginning of my speech, there are some Aboriginal people in Australia who are taxpayers. I hope it is not put on a banner and carried around the streets that we want more and more Aboriginal people to become taxpayers, but really that is what we are talking about if we want to get them into the labour market. If they start earning salaries and wages, they will, in turn, if they are paid enough, become taxpayers.

The ATSIC Bill, once it has been passed, will ensure that decisions designed to advance the welfare of the indigenous people will be made with the full participation of those people. They will be involved in the decision making process. It will not be some bureaucrat sitting in Canberra, Perth, Melbourne or wherever making the decisions. There will be an enormous involvement in that decision making process by Aboriginal people from the remotest parts of Australia. While there have been moves in the past to provide administrative measures to ensure such participation, this is the first time that such participation has been given legal force and embodied in legislation. I mention in passing the National Aboriginal Conference which did some good work for a period of time. It probably outlived its usefulness, but it did provide for a degree of participation that was not there before.

Not only are we taking that a step further but we are also actually legislating for such participation to be allowed to happen and, furthermore, to be encouraged to happen. It is unfortunate that in Australia there are some who look upon the Aboriginal people as second class or even lesser class citizens. I regret that I was not in the Parliament during a Western Australian election campaign some years ago, when Aboriginal affairs became the No. 1 issue. It was a particularly nasty campaign which will be long remembered with shame, I would suggest, not only by Western Australians but by all Australians for the degree to which it went in playing down the role of Aboriginal people in that State and their legitimate claims and demands.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Chaney suffered great political damage.

—I acknowledge that interjection from Senator Peter Baume that Senator Chaney suffered great political damage. I regret that. I acknowledge that, despite the fact that we are on different sides of the political fence. I must say that I had absolutely no involvement in the damage that Senator Chaney suffered. I accept the interjection with pleasure. It is a harsh reality of political life that if a person stands up to put forward an ideal he can be damaged to the extent that Senator Chaney was damaged at that time. That is something that we in this chamber should all condemn. Senator Chaney has been a better human being since that event. I am glad he has not lost the ideals he was pursuing at that time. That is not to say that I accept each and every word that Senator Chaney has uttered in debate on the legislation that is before the chamber today. Unfortunately, the agenda for the debate and the position of the Opposition parties have been set in other areas: for example, those dreadful headlines, which I hope will be put to rest after this debate has finished, about the black mafia, cronyism, nepotism and so forth. Hopefully, Senator Chaney will not jump on the bandwagon as well but will stick to debating the philosophy and the merits of this legislation rather than get into the slanging match on this legislation that occurred in Estimates committees and other places.

SPEECH.PARA: This is the first occasion on which I have had an opportunity in this chamber to put my point of view on Aboriginal affairs. I regret that I will not now have time to say so many of the things that I had to say on this legislation and in the area of Aboriginal affairs. I hope that once the legislation is passed there can be an acceptance by all sections of the Australian community-and that includes Opposition parties-that the situation for Aboriginal people must be improved. If people do not think that it needs improvement, I refer back to the statistics I used in my introductory remarks this morning. If that is not good enough, people should come out to some of the remote communities in Western Australia, which I obviously know better than those in other States. They should go to such places as Wingelinna, Kiwikurra, Warburton-which is actually on the map-and Frog Hollow in the Kimberleys and see the conditions that human beings are living in today. I am sure that once they have seen them and witnessed the conditions for themselves-I am not necessarily addressing these remarks to the individuals in the chamber because I know that honourable senators opposite do travel and have visited some of these communities-they will see why passion is generated when we talk about this portfolio. They will know what a disgrace it is for Australians to travel abroad and have to admit that their fellow citizens are living in conditions such as these people are living in in some of these areas. I do not just pick on the names of the communities I have mentioned as bad examples. They were the names that came into my head. I do not hold them up as being the worst or the best; I note them because they are examples of the appalling living conditions that some Aboriginal people are faced with in Australia today.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —In a very real sense it is quite inappropriate for the Senate to be debating this legislation. I draw attention to the fact that last year we celebrated the so-called Bicentenary of Australia. We celebrated 200 years of predominantly white European settlement in this country. Only a little attention was given to the fact that when we came into this country we progressively displaced and brutally treated a people who had been here for 200 times as long as that. It is estimated that those people had occupied this country for something in excess of 40,000 years. If the Aboriginal people have been in this country for 24 hours we, the representatives of the white people, have been here for seven minutes. Yet here we are in this chamber debating the future of those original inhabitants. It is in that sense that it is perhaps inappropriate that we should be debating this matter at all. Nonetheless-and I am picking up on what Senator McKiernan has just said-the appalling conditions of Aboriginal people are clearly related to what has gone on and their displacement from traditional lands and traditional cultures. Because of that we are in a position where we must address this very serious problem.

SPEECH.PARA: The Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission Bill 1989 is an attempt to give back to Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people, as far as is now possible under the existing conditions, the ability to determine their own future and the future of their peoples into some indeterminate future. It is important because the Aboriginal culture is still markedly different from the mainstream culture of Australia. I will return to that shortly.

I believe that the Australian Democrats are coming to this legislation and to this issue-the issue is really what second reading debate speeches are about-from a somewhat different perspective to that of the Opposition and the Government. Despite what the Opposition and the Government say about the recognition of cultural difference and cultural pluralism in Australia, the mainstream culture in Australia does not accept Aboriginal culture as a legitimate and separate culture. The mainstream culture in Australia is exploitative and is oriented towards economic and material values, and the difference is well exemplified by our attitude to land. Very often one finds that if one talks about Aboriginal land rights many people in the mainstream culture say, `But if you give Aboriginal people land they don't do anything with it'. This represents a total failure to understand the relationship between Aboriginal people and the land. This is also the case in relation to a number of other cultural elements. It is therefore important in the Democrats' view to recognise and preserve that cultural difference.

As I said during the Bicentenary, I believe that different culture has a very significant message to give to the mainstream culture. We are now aware of the damage which 200 years of white settlement has done to Australia and to the environment in this country. That difference, expressed through Aboriginal culture, of caring for their environment, is something that we desperately need to bring back into our mainstream culture. It is important that it be preserved and enhanced and that its importance be recognised in the mainstream culture. For that reason the Democrats are supporting this legislation. We believe that even though there are faults in the legislation-emphasis has been placed on the differences between ourselves and the Government-it is a step in the right direction.

Earlier Senator Peter Baume said-I think I am quoting him directly-that the Department of Aboriginal Affairs has had a magnificent past. He spoke about outcomes. When we look at the outcomes-Senator McKiernan dealt with some of them-we find that they are dismal. The Aboriginal people in this country are still among some of the most deprived in the world. They are deprived in a material sense. It is interesting that Senator McKiernan placed emphasis on that material sense. In other words, he was using white-type criteria to estimate that deprivation. That is significant in terms of the cultural context I was referring to a moment ago. In terms of those outcomes the result has been abysmal. Senator Baume also stressed that it is not just outcomes but process that is important. He seemed to forget that later in his speech. Surely the process should involve more Aboriginal participation, determination and self-management. That is what this legislation is about.

TALK.START.PARA: —The ADC wasn't a bad start.

—The Aboriginal Development Commission was a step in the right direction, but it was an appointed body and was still subject to very strong government intervention. This Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission proposal goes somewhat beyond that. I will deal with some of the defects later, so I can pick that point up then.

SPEECH.PARA: This legislation is about process. The process should be, as far as possible, to allow Aboriginal people to determine the way they want their culture, their lifestyle and those material criteria to be addressed. Those who are opposing this legislation are saying that the Aboriginal people will do worse than they have already. The only point I am making here is that over the last 200 years white administration has not done very well. It has done very poorly. I think it is about time that the Aboriginal people were given a go and given an opportunity to see whether they cannot do better. At least coming from their cultural position they should be able to understand the situation of their own people within the terms of their own culture.

The principle to which this legislation is giving effect is to allow Aboriginal people to self-determine and self-manage as far as that is possible, given that we have had 200 years of white occupation and white domination. Inevitably, whatever is put in place must dovetail and fit in with that administrative process. Nonetheless, the principles are to elevate as far as possible self-determination and self-management.

Several days ago a number of newspapers around Australia ran an article about the Treasurer, Paul Keating. It was a very long article. I think it appeared in most papers on Saturday. All the copies of this article which I saw had a quotation from the Treasurer which said:
The Democrats are a party without structure, without disciplines. It's a party without policies.
In the Adelaide Advertiser the next four or five paragraphs were quite deceitfully and deliberately deleted because the article in other newspapers then went on to say:
This, of course, is not true. The Democrats have had a comprehensive-and uncompromising-set of environment policies for a decade.

In relation to self-determination and self-management I would like to read into the record precisely what the Democrats' policy is because a number of journalists have claimed that the Democrats do not have policies. Our policies are ones which are adopted by the total membership in a thoroughly democratic way. They represent the views of our members at large and not those of any elite group within the party. We have in our policy document a heading `Self Determination' and it follows an extensive preamble which outlines a number of broad principles. The document states:
1 In pursuit of the principles set out above, the Australian Democrats hold that the government of the Commonwealth should:
- guarantee and facilitate the return of the Aboriginal land base and sacred areas;
- guarantee land to Aboriginal peoples as compensation where this is unobtainable (eg. land excisions and land purchases);

- guarantee the establishment, in the manner proposed by the Aboriginal people, of a autonomous national Aboriginal Commission fully representative of their people to receive all compensatory funds for disbursement.

2 Further, until such time as full Aboriginal control of Aboriginal affairs is achieved, it is recognised that in any field where responsible Aboriginal controlled agencies exist, such agencies should receive preference in allocation of funds. The Australian Democrats will support the national Aboriginal Commission if it decides to negotiate a treaty or charter having constitutional authority.

I will come back to that point in relation to the preamble to this legislation. That is the declared policy position from which the Democrats approach this legislation. It is certainly true that the ATSIC legislation is not supported by all Aboriginal people. Indeed, when the Senate Select Committee on the Administration of Aboriginal Affairs travelled around Australia, I think it is fair to say, the majority of Aboriginal witnesses were opposed to the ATSIC legislation. That is not surprising when we have any committee of inquiry into something which is controversial. It tends to drag out those who are opposed to the proposition rather than those who are in favour of it. However, as a consequence of that Senate Committee report the Government has adopted a significant number of recommendations for change to the legislation. The legislation was withdrawn, redrafted and re-presented.

However, a number of significant changes recommended by the Committee have not been accepted by the Government. In recent weeks we have been in close negotiation with the Government to see whether further advancement could be made on the acceptance of those further recommendations. Some advance has been made in that respect. I stress again that this negotiation has not been done from a position of opposing the legislation, as distinct from the Opposition's position. It has been done from the position of supporting the principle of the legislation, but being concerned that the legislation work as well as possible once it is in place.

It is certainly not true, as many Aboriginal people vehemently in favour of the legislation have asserted, that any attempt to modify the legislation represents opposition to the legislation. That has not been our position. Our position has been to attempt to modify and to improve the legislation as far as that is possible. Clearly, this is a major attempt to give back to Aboriginal people these principles of self-determination and self-management and to put in place the mechanisms which will allow that to occur. It is vital therefore that this legislation work and that it not fall flat on its face. Should it do so, it is doubtful whether any government would want to approach legislation of this sort in the near future. The abysmal state that Aboriginal affairs is now in would probably sink to an even lower level.

I return to the question of mainstream culture. It has been obvious to me that there are in Australia a number of people with a quite frank racist outlook who are opposed to anything that would advantage Aboriginal people. Indeed, just yesterday my office had a phone call from a lady opposed to the ATSIC legislation. When we were setting out our reasons for supporting the legislation the lady's comments became extremely heated and the conversation concluded with this communicant saying that it would be better had all Aboriginal people been poisoned in those early days and that that would have solved the problem. That is the attitude of some people in the Australian community.

I recall particular interviews I have seen with former United States citizens who had come into this country and taken up land. When asked why they had come to Australia to take up land they said things like, `Well, you know how to deal with your niggers in this country'. So there are extreme racist views among some people. As a consequence there is probably very little mileage in this particular debate on either side. One hopes therefore that the debate will not descend into a party political slanging match.

As I indicated earlier, the legislation is imposing on Aboriginal people something which is not basically Aboriginal. It is inevitable that that is the case because it is a piece of legislation that does not sit with traditional culture in any way. However, one of the significant amendments which the Government did accept from the Senate Select Committee's report is that one of the first and important features of the 60 regional councils, when they are established, will be their right to review the boundaries of those regional areas and also to look at their own electoral processes and to advise the Minister if they wish to make an appropriate change, having received advice from the Australian Electoral Commission to ensure that any recommendations along that line are properly democratic. It is possible that over time the ATSIC structure will evolve throughout Australia and be different in different parts of the country but still meet the desires of people in different areas.

There are marked divisions between the cultural integration of Aboriginal people into mainstream European society. One finds marked differences in the educational level in the adoption of mainstream values, for instance, between the urban Aboriginal people in Sydney and the more traditional people in Arnhem Land. Clearly it is desirable therefore that the processes of election and the way in which the management is conducted at the regional council level be determined by Aboriginal people. That, after all, is the principle to which this legislation is to give effect.

Senator Peter Baume also used an expression which I have heard him use before. He quoted the aphorism, `If it ain't broke, don't try to fix it'. My simple response to Senator Baume is that it is broke. Aboriginal Affairs is not working and nothing is a better indication of that fact than the sorts of claims which have been made by the Opposition over the last 12 months. It is time to try something better and something different. It is certainly true that Senator Baume can point to defects in the legislation. He and I would probably share some of the concerns over those defects. But it is not necessary that the legislation be perfect. What is necessary is that we put in place something substantially better than what we have now. The legislation can at least do that and, given its ability to evolve over time and that the mechanism for the evolution is given to the Aboriginal people, eventually we will see better and better operation of this proposal.

The goals of self-determination must not be merely material. They must not be merely better health, better housing, the sorts of things that Senator McKiernan referred to. Those goals could be achieved in an autocratic way. One could say to Aboriginal people: `You will be healthy whether you like it or not. We will control your water supply. We will control the nutrition that you get. We will control the houses that you live in'. This legislation is not just about outcomes in that sense. It is about processes and about those outcomes coming about through Aboriginal people taking control of their own destiny and determining such things as water supply, the sorts of health services, educational processes, housing, and so on, that they want.

I totally reject the view that the legislation is similar to putting into the hands of veterans the administration of veterans' affairs. That analogy would hold if we were comparing veterans' affairs in the hands of veterans with, for example, pensions in the hands of pensioners. Here we are talking about a people within this country who are substantially culturally different. Therefore, it is appropriate that they be given this sort of control over their own destiny. Their culture is clearly not understood by mainstream Australians and that is where a lot of problems have come from.

I will briefly pick up on a few of the problems that I still have with the legislation. These will be dealt with in more detail in the committee stage. Attached to the front of the legislation is a preamble. The Australian Democrats would certainly not disagree with one word in the preamble. However, it has been made quite clear to us that the preamble has no force in law whatsoever. It has no force in law because, firstly, there is no clause in the legislation the amplification of which in a court hearing could be clarified by reference to the preamble. Secondly, it has no force in law because--

TALK.START.PARA: —Are you absolutely sure on that point?

—The Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Mr Hand) has said so and legal advice has been obtained on that. Secondly, any court seeking clarification of an Act can look to the second reading speech of the Minister. The second reading speeches on both the first and second presentations of the Bill contained the Minister's declaration that the preamble had no force in law. So the concerns which have been expressed in some quarters that the preamble should be removed because it has some force in law are totally without foundation.

SPEECH.PARA: However, for quite contrary reasons, the Australian Democrats believe that the preamble should be removed from the Bill. The reason is very simply that it has no force in law; it has no weight whatsoever. When the Act that we hope the Bill will become in the not too distant future is printed, that preamble will be attached to it. People looking at the Act in six months' time, a year's time or two years' time will read those very important words and think, `Gee, this is good; this has some force in law'. They would be misled. Therefore, it is dishonest to attach something like this, something which has no force, to legislation. I gave notice yesterday that at the appropriate time the Australian Democrats will move to separate the preamble from the legislation and to put the words in the preamble in a separate motion which we will seek to put through the Senate in a cognate debate. We believe that will advance the intention of the Government more than attaching the preamble to the Bill.

The reason is that the preamble currently is seen by the Government as the second step in a three-step process. The first step was the passage through both Houses of Parliament on the first day of sitting in the new Parliament House of a motion recognising prior Aboriginal occupation and dispossession. The Government sees that the second step is this preamble and that that will lead to the third step, which will be a negotiated treaty-I would prefer to call it a memorandum of understanding and reconciliation-between the Government, representing mainstream Australians, and Aboriginal people.

In taking the words in the preamble and putting them as a separate motion to follow the Bill, I would seek to add at the end of the preamble words which say that that is indeed the intention of the Government. In other words, it is tying the Government to what it says is its intention and it is putting that before the Senate so that everybody can be quite clear that that is the third stage in this process. We believe that is more honest. It advances what the Government wants to do. I mention it here because the technicalities of removing that preamble and having it as a separate motion may not be understood. But that precisely is the effect of the motion of which I gave notice yesterday.

I could pick up briefly one other matter at this second reading stage-that is, the payment of dividends and taxes on the capital fund of what is now the Aboriginal Development Commission (ADC) but which will become a capital fund within the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Development Corporation. Again, the reason for this is a matter of principle and I hope the Government will see fit to assent to it. That capital fund was established when the Opposition established the ADC as a compensatory fund. It was established in recognition of Aboriginal dispossession and all that flowed from that. For that reason, it is quite wrong that the Government should seek to levy dividends and tax on earnings from that capital fund.

The Senate Select Committee accepted that view and recommended to the Government that that fund should not be expected to pay dividends or tax. It is a matter of principle. The Government may say that in terms of Government revenue the same effect could be achieved simply by allocating less money from revenue to the capital fund. That is perfectly true. However, the other proposal is a more honest way of proceeding. If the Government puts less money in, at least one knows that that is what is being done; there is not a backdoor leakage of earnings from that capital fund by way of dividends and tax. That is an important amendment which I will move at a later stage which I believe will recognise that principle which is incorporated in the preamble.

In conclusion, the Democrats are and always have been committed to the principle of this legislation, that of self-determination and self-management. It is an important step forward for Aboriginal people. There are still defects in the legislation. We will seek to improve the legislation as far as that is possible, but nothing could be worse than the situation which has obtained for the last 200 years in which Aboriginal people have become among the most disadvantaged in the world.
Debate (on motion by Senator Cook) adjourned.

TALK.START.PARA: —It being almost 12.45 p.m., under sessional order the Senate will proceed to matters of public interest.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McMullan Sen R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to raise a matter that is definitely of public interest which is particularly of concern to a large body of my constituents because it has the potential to affect the welfare of 17,000 employees here in Canberra, the employees of the Australian Capital Territory Administration. It is a matter which arises somewhat unfortunately from some irresponsible and ill-considered remarks of a member of the ACT Legislative Assembly, Mr Bernard Collaery. Unfortunately, in the pursuit of publicity at any price, this gentleman seems to have ignored the serious responsibility to consider the consequences of his actions, a responsibility imposed on him by his new office. I refer in particular to the proposal which he made which I heard reported on the Australian Broadcasting Corporation radio news this morning that a separate ACT superannuation fund should be established for employees of the ACT Administration-that is, removing them from the Superannuation Fund Investment Trust which governs the superannuation of Commonwealth public servants, and the corollary which implied a requirement that that body would invest disproportionately, or more than commercial requirements would indicate, in the Australian Capital Territory.

SPEECH.PARA: The proposal causes me concern not because I am opposed to investment in Canberra-which of course I support-but because it raises three particular problems. Firstly, it is a barrier to transferability of employees between the ACT Administration and the Commonwealth and therefore erodes the terms and conditions of employment of those people. Secondly, it undermines the Superannuation Fund Investment Trust. Thirdly, it endangers the earnings of any potential ACT super fund and therefore the potential return to its members-those employees to whom I referred.

With regard to the problem of the barrier to transferability, a very important part of the discussions which led to self-government in the ACT was that people who went to work for the ACT Administration would not find themselves in a second-class environment with second-class conditions, that they did not become second-class public servants, that the ACT did not become a ghetto. I think that the governing of the ACT is a very important matter and it is therefore very important that we ensure that we have the highest quality public servants available. At the moment we are very well served in that regard. It is important that those people do not have their career opportunities diminished, their transferability into and out of the other arms of Commonwealth government limited, or the terms and conditions which were negotiated on the transfer undermined. This proposal would significantly undermine those conditions and I am opposed to it, firstly, on that ground.

Secondly, I am opposed because it may well undermine the Superannuation Fund Investment Trust. The ACT employees, as far as I have been able to establish during this morning's research, constitute some 4 per cent of the contributors to the Superannuation Fund Investment Trust, and that is a significant erosion of its potential. Mr Collaery seems to fail to understand that the Superannuation Fund Investment Trust is a big player in the Australian financial and property market. It is the major ACT based financial institution. It is the player that brings us into the major investment game in a large number of those areas and provides, here in Canberra, employment opportunities for people wishing to participate in those sorts of financial management areas, in funds management, et cetera. It is not the only player-there are other substantial ones-but it is the biggest and a very important institution and should not be lightly and cavalierly undermined.

Thirdly, and of particular concern, the implementation of the proposal as outlined endangers the earnings of any proposed ACT superannuation fund. If such a superannuation fund is required to invest on criteria other than maximising return to the members and contributors, it will lead to only one of two outcomes. Firstly, there could be reduced returns to retiring employees. They would not receive the same benefits as Commonwealth employees when they retired. If the same benefits were to be legislated, then it would require a major input of taxpayers' funds to top up the shortfall in the returns on the investment because they were failing to maximise the commercial return on the investment. In my view, that also offends the normal trustee principles. It would put the trustees of the fund in an intolerable position. They would find that investment `A' delivered the maximum return to their contributors, their members, the people who had given them money in their trust, but that the requirement to invest other than commercially required them to deliver a lesser return. For those reasons I think the proposal ought to be reconsidered by its author and thrown away.

It may be that at some stage a fund will be established for the employer's contribution from the ACT Administration-that contribution which it is required to make, on behalf particularly of the employees in its statutory authorities, to the Commonwealth to fund its share of the responsibilities of an employer. That would be a much smaller fund; it is certainly not the fund that was being referred to by Mr Collaery this morning. In my view, that would not be the most financially sound and sensible way to proceed, but at least that would have some logic. However, it would be a very small fund relatively and would not make the contribution we are talking about to undermining the Superannuation Fund.

I say to Mr Collaery and anybody who supports a similar proposal: do not endanger the interests of 17,000 employees of the ACT Administration carelessly or by ill considered remarks. I emphasise in conclusion, Madam Acting Deputy President, that membership of a body with legislative powers is a serious responsibility. It should be taken seriously. Actions by people in such bodies should not be the same as the legitimate activities of one-issue groups which do not aspire to government, do not have legislative responsibility, and therefore do not have to consider the implications and the implementation of their proposals. I urge Mr Collaery to reconsider his proposal and to remove this threat from the employment conditions of 17,000 employees here in Canberra.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Teague Sen B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Acting Deputy President, for three weeks in June and July I was able to visit India, Pakistan and Nepal, and in a speech yesterday I made some observations about my visit to Nepal. I shall continue now with some observations and conclusions with regard to my visit to Pakistan, and if there is time to complete all that I wish to say, with regard to India as well. I am given to understand that I may have been the first Australian senator ever to visit Pakistan. If I was, then you, Madam Acting Deputy President, would have been the second, because a few days later your own itinerary took you to Pakistan, and perhaps the Senate will hear of that visit more widely. Certainly I am interested to learn of your meeting with the Prime Minister of that country. I was able to visit several Ministers in the relatively new Government of Pakistan, and I will come to that in a moment.

SPEECH.PARA: However, four members of the House of Representatives have visited Pakistan in the last 10 years: Foreign Minister Peacock in 1980, Foreign Minister Hayden in 1984, Trade Minister Duffy in 1988, and the Prime Minister, Mr Hawke, in February this year. But it is surprising to note the limited contact that there has been by parliamentarians and Ministers, representatives of the Australian Government, over a long period. There have been long-established, excellent diplomatic relations between Australia and Pakistan at the official level, and indeed, with some small beginnings in business contacts in recent years we are not entirely absent from the field. But there needs now to be much greater attention given by Australians and by this Parliament to understanding what is happening in Pakistan.

There are three principal reasons for my call for a greater interest in Pakistan. The first is the return to parliamentary democracy and an elected government. There is no longer a military regime governing the 105 million people of Pakistan. As we all observed very closely at the end of last year, the then Opposition and the most vigorously progressive party gained sufficient numbers in a wide and well-conducted election to become the Government of Pakistan, led by Prime Minister Benazir Bhutto. This was eight months ago, and in my visit I was able to meet several Ministers of the Government. I observed, as many others have, a newly exciting atmosphere of responding to the people that the Government represents, a new openness, and a commitment to being accountable to the electorate and for developing the country in a refreshing participatory way by seeking to serve the people.

Reform is in the air. Pakistan also wishes to become a member of the Commonwealth of Nations again. The Parliament in Pakistan is interested to ensure that parliamentary democracy is effective and that new procedures are adopted, including any that may be deemed appropriate after listening to the experience of other parliaments, including Australia. There has been a strong commitment to human and political rights in Pakistan over the last eight months. This refreshing return to democracy is welcomed in Australia and, I am sure, is welcomed by senators in this chamber. We need to take account of this and to make sure that we have increased contact and discussion and that we pay attention to these events.

Secondly, there ought to be increased contact because the prospects for trade between Australia and Pakistan are considerably increased and increasing. In 1988 the level of Australian exports to Pakistan stood at $A127m, and Australian imports from Pakistan in 1988 were somewhat less, $A73m. So there is a modest trade of some $200m, which, in the next few years, could well double. The opportunities for increase are real and there is a new outwardly looking, much more export oriented approach in Pakistan. The Pakistan Government, business, and indeed-and in a quite bipartisan way, it is not a controversy between various areas of political opinion within the country-everybody in Pakistan is looking for the economy there to be a part of the international economy. There are infrastructure needs for capital programs and the wide range of economic development needs in a developing country.

There is not sufficient awareness in this country to the opportunities for Australians to become a part of that growing economy and, indeed, there are opportunities for Pakistan exports to meet some of our needs. So, I believe increased attention should be given to Australia-Pakistan trade. This is in a general pattern of Australia looking much more carefully towards the whole of South Asia. Our trade with India is very considerable at the moment. It stands at a half a billion dollars of exports and a quarter of a billion dollars of imports. Trade with Pakistan is considerably less but it is, relative to the populations in the two countries, very comparable and when we in this chamber and in Australia look to our links with South Asia we need to make sure that all the opportunities in India and in Pakistan are taken up.

The third principal reason why we should take an increased interest in Pakistan is that after 10 years of civil war in the neighbouring country of Afghanistan there have been some recent achievements which will lead to a greater expectation of some resolution of the conflict there. After enormous international pressure, including that from members of this chamber on all sides, the Soviet Union has withdrawn its substantial number of troops from Afghanistan following 10 years of occupying that country. Whilst the Soviet military assistance to the present government in Kabul is enormous-plane loads and truck loads on a daily basis that are fearsome in their huge quantities of armaments and that are fuelling a continuing civil war-there is, nevertheless, a recent call by Prime Minister Bhutto for a negotiated settlement between the various elements in the civil war in Afghanistan. This call by the Prime Minister of Pakistan has been supported in the United States and more widely and therefore there are considerable prospects that the mujahideen and the various elements resisting the present Kabul government will take very seriously the option ahead of negotiating to achieve free elections and a stable government in Afghanistan.

The impasse in the battle of Jalalabad has been a fact for the last four or five months. This strategic battle on the main road between the Khyber Pass and Kabul has led to there not being a victory by either side. A great deal of the ground has been won by the mujahideen forces and yet the actual citadel of this provincial town, Jalalabad, has not fallen. Again, a fearsome amount of armaments from both sides is being thrown at each other in that battle. All the more this means that the prospect of a negotiated settlement that leads to a stable outcome for Afghanistan is the prospect that we in this Senate chamber should all look to.

Afghanistan is so closely the neighbour of Pakistan that some four million Afghans who have fled their homes have become refugees in Pakistan. This is the greatest refugee concentration anywhere in the world. The repercussions of this prospect for more stability in Afghanistan affects the whole region, and not least Pakistan.

For these several reasons these new developments over the last nine months have led us all in this chamber to give much more attention to Pakistan and we should pursue these interests, I believe, very carefully. Pakistan has 105 million people-only about one-eighth the population of India-and it has a gross national product (GNP) of some $US38 billion. Compare this with India, with $233 billion, and Australia, with even more-$246 billion. We see a small economy and a very low GNP per capita statistic, but it is an economy of comparable size with the Philippines, and a little smaller than Thailand, and one that is in our region and which has development needs which we need to take account of.

The defence needs of Pakistan ought to be very apparent to us. It sees itself as being in a precarious situation, bordering four much larger neighbours-India, China, Iran and the Soviet Union-and having a long common border with the buffer country, that very troubled country, Afghanistan, to which I have referred. Throughout the entire existence of Pakistan these last 42 years it has been in this precarious situation. It therefore has a very active defence policy and a very careful foreign affairs assessment of its own security within that region. Very rightly Pakistan is making sure that it is ready to meet any threat to its security. We in this chamber need to take account of those tensions and do all that we can to ensure that those tensions do not get out of hand.

Very briefly I should refer to Australia's involvement at the diplomatic level. I wish to commend the representation that we have in our Embassy there and the leadership of Ambassador Geoffrey Price and his staff. They are doing an excellent job. We have a new location for a new Embassy building and I would implore the Government to get on with it and actually commit the funds to seeing it established. Also I believe that Austrade should be represented full time by a resident person with access to Islamabad and Karachi.

Finally, I look forward to the visit of the Chairman of the Senate of Pakistan, Mr Wasim Sajjad, and other senators I met while I was there who were very welcoming to me and whom we in this Senate should be very welcoming to when they come in October. I thank all of those who assisted me in my preparation for the visit to Pakistan, including Australian academics, the Department of Foreign Affairs, the Parliamentary Library, my colleagues, those who met me in Lahore and Islamabad and everyone who assisted me so admirably in this most valuable visit on my part to Islamabad. I will need to continue my remarks about India on a subsequent occasion.
Sitting suspended from 1.05 to 2 p.m.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. Has the Minister noted today's report that Australia's biggest employer, Coles Myer Ltd, estimates it will have to borrow another $67m a year because of the changes in the collection of company tax announced in the Budget, and that this will cost the company a net $7m in added interest payments? In view of the very significant amounts involved in this one example-and there are obviously thousands of others-I ask the Minister: has the Government any estimate of the likely cost to companies of its Budget proposals? If so, what is it? If no estimate is available, is this just another example of a bright idea of Treasury to increase Government revenue without any detailed consideration of the practical impact of the decision?

—I have not seen the specific report relating to Coles Myer Ltd. I suppose it is one of the biggest companies in Australia and, no doubt, the figures relating to that company would probably be higher than for any other company. I was asked a question yesterday about the cash flow effects of this tax. If Coles Myer claims it will cost it that sum each year, as has been put in this question, that is incorrect. It will cost the company that much this year-the next tax year. It will not cost the company that on a permanent basis.
—Of course it will.
—It will not. I answered this point yesterday. That company's business is as a retailer; it is not in the business of lending what is otherwise taxpayers' money and gaining interest on that.
—Are you going to tell them how to invest their money now?

—Why should that company be any different from any other taxpayer? That is the question, and that includes privately owned small businesses. Why should Coles Myer be different in terms of equity? As I say, I do not know the position in relation to Coles Myer. If the honourable senator wants an estimate of the cost of this proposal to companies across Australia I suggest he looks at the revenue implications which are contained in the Budget Papers.

—I direct a question to the Minister representing the Treasurer. Has the Minister's attention been drawn to a recent statement by the Police Federation of Australia which calls for the elimination of tax deductability for the purchase of radar detection devices? In view of the positive correlation between speed and road deaths and injuries, will the Minister give consideration to withdrawing any tax deductability for such devices?

—I have seen the report to which Senator Colston refers. I think it is under section 51 of the Income Tax Assessment Act that radar equipment, if it is fitted to a car and assuming the car itself is tax deductable-let us say it is a business vehicle and not a private vehicle-just like a wireless, air-conditioning or, for that matter I suppose, the brakes and radiator, is part of the vehicle and is, therefore, tax deductable. I understand that the Treasurer has suggested to the Premier of New South Wales that the appropriate way to deal with this problem is for the States to legislate against the fitting of radar devices to private vehicles rather than adopting the more clumsy way of trying to amend the Income Tax Assessment Act for the same purpose. I presume the Treasurer has made the same suggestion to other State Premiers who have approached him on the matter, but I am not sure of that.

—I address my question to the Minister representing the Treasurer. Following Mr Keating's remarks yesterday, as reported in the Sydney Morning Herald today, that it is really the Treasurer who determines social welfare matters such as `family allowance supplements . . . superannuation . . . pension changes, assets tests' and so on, I ask: will the Minister explain why the Budget did not include extending the pensioner health benefit (PHB) card to all aged persons at a cost estimated by the Life Insurance Federation of Australia of $165m, given that this would still have produced a Budget surplus of $9 billion? Given that the PHB card benefits are subject to a sudden death income and assets test and have a profound influence on the investment behaviour of many retirees, would not the general availability of the PHB card increase incentives for retired persons to maximise their retirement income without fear of losing the card and, hence, the benefits that go with it?
—I cannot remember what the estimated cost was of making the pensioner health benefit card available to all persons. Was it to all persons in receipt of a pension or all people of pensionable age?
—The Life Insurance Federation of Australia estimate of $165m was the additional cost of extending eligibility to all pensioners, that is, to people in receipt of part pensions.

—The existing cutoff point, I think, is pension plus $40 for a single person. I cannot remember what the estimated cost was but Senator Haines says it was $165m. There are 165 million reasons why it was not done. To say that because there was a large surplus therefore the Government should blow $165m here and $100m or $1 billion somewhere else is not, in my view, a very impressive argument. It is true that the cutoff is a sudden death cutoff but, if the PHB card were to be made available to all persons in receipt of full or part pensions, there would still be a sudden death cutoff at some other point, that is, the point at which a person loses entirely entitlement to a pension.

—I have a supplementary question. I remind the Minister that last year the Government was quite prepared to cut company tax by 20 per cent from 49c to 39c in the dollar at a cost of $2 billion, at a time when many companies were paying no tax at all. Perhaps he would like to explain why it is considered appropriate to spend that sort of money on companies but not to spend $165m on Australian pensioners?

—There have been a lot of changes made to taxation, over the last four years in particular. It is true that so far as cash payments are concerned, the company tax rate applicable to this financial year and to last financial year's income has been reduced. It is also true that company tax collection-I will not guarantee these figures because I am going from memory-is in double figures this year, in spite of the reduction in the company tax rate, following an even higher increase in company tax collection for the previous year. That does not include the fringe benefits tax which is largely paid by companies, the estimated revenue for this year from which, I think, is in the order of $1.3 billion. The estimated revenue for this year from capital gains tax is $500m. In other words, the net effect of the changes that have been made to the tax law in the last four years is generally to reduce rates by broadening the base. That is a major reason why we have produced a Budget this year with a surplus in excess of $9 billion.
—By bringing taxation forward.

—The revenue is the same proportion of gross domestic product (GDP) as it was in 1981 and 1982. In response to the interjection by Senator Panizza, I say that, if he wants to proceed with that line, he cannot have it both ways. Revenue, as a proportion of GDP, is not lower than it was in 1981-82, he is suggesting that the timing of payments should have been changed. As a result of the broadening of the tax base and, of course, the growth that has taken place in the previous year, we have been able to produce a Budget with a very large surplus, with taxation levels being maintained-or slightly more than maintained in real terms-as a proportion of GDP at what they were in the previous year, in spite of a very big reduction in personal income tax collection, a reduction in rates, some adjustment of thresholds and the cut in the company tax rate.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Employment and Education Services. What assistance will be provided to disadvantaged young people as a result of the recently completed social justice review?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —As a result of the Government's review of its youth strategy, the Government announced in the Budget that it will spend $100m over the next four years to ensure that disadvantaged young people benefit from the reforms in the youth area achieved by the Government since entering office. While the Government's present youth strategy has been successful in increasing school retention rates to year 12 to 58 per cent and halving youth unemployment since 1983, that is not sufficient. The Government recognises that some young people such as the homeless, those from low income families and those who have been unemployed for long periods have not been able to share fully in these advances.

ANSWER.PARA: Key elements of the package to which I have referred include, first, responding to the needs of homeless youth through more than doubling the availability of secure accommodation and, importantly, funding a mediation service designed to prevent the circumstances in which youth homelessness develops; secondly, providing from January 1990 an extra $14 per week to homeless youth and others who have clearly established independence from their parents; thirdly, providing money for the development of an innovative health service for young people targeted especially at those in high need locations; and, fourthly, providing improved access to information and advice for disadvantaged young people, including the opening of 20 new youth access centres.

I know that Senator Childs, who asked this question, has a particular interest in the education and training of youth. I am sure he will be pleased to learn that additional assistance will be given in these areas. I refer to two particularly important measures: first, improved participation in education for a new initiative targeted at government schools with low secondary retention rates; and, secondly, significant upgrading of labour market measures to encourage and assist unemployed and other disadvantaged young people to make the transition back into employment, education and training. This will mean that all 16- and 17-year-olds who have been unemployed for 12 months or more will be assisted through a comprehensive package of assistance including joint interviews by the Commonwealth Employment Service and the Department of Social Security, access to labour market program assistance and new incentives to get back to work, such as a $50 employment entry payment.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is also directed to Senator Button, in his capacity as Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce. I refer to the Minister's attempt yesterday to defend the Budget decision on company tax collections by arguing that companies enjoyed a deferral not available to individuals. Does the Minister acknowledge that the proposal to collect 85 per cent of company tax within 15 days of the end of the financial year could lead to great cash flow difficulties because of extended credit terms inherent in business operations-sometimes between 90 and 120 days-offered by certain types of businesses? In other words, does he agree that the circumstances of companies and individuals are different because wage and salary earners get paid evenly over the year whereas many commercial enterprises have an uneven cash flow and that cash flow generally lags reported profit? Does he further agree that there will simply not be enough accountants to finalise the accounts for small corporations in time for them to pay the first instalments of tax within 15 days of the end of the financial year? This will be particularly critical in circumstances of declining profitability compared with the previous year. Will the Government reconsider its Budget decision to penalise small businesses which will either have to estimate income for the year just ended or pay tax on the basis of the previous year's income, which may bear little relevance to their current situation?
—Of course, circumstances vary from business to business. Some companies are in the category which Senator Watson describes; others are not. He asked whether--
—You would not know, anyway. Why don't you twist his question around so you can make up what you want to say.

—I really have nothing much to add to what I said yesterday, except to comment on some of the points that Senator Watson advanced in his question. He referred to declining profitability. I do not know whether that is his projection; it is not a projection I see coming from anywhere else at present. Opposition senators must get used to the fact that company profits in this country have been at their highest level ever in the last four years. Senator Watson said that there would not be enough accountants to work out all these problems. I can assure him that he is wrong about that. Sadly, Australia has the highest ratio of accountants to other professions compared to any country in the world. We ought not be too worried about that. I have nothing to add to the answer I gave yesterday. The measure will be introduced and adjustments will have to be made by some companies.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Finance. What change in the Commonwealth Government's fiscal position has taken place since Labor took office in 1983? How has that change in the fiscal position been achieved?

—The change that has taken place in the fiscal outcome, the Budget bottom line, or whatever one wants to call it, since Labor took office in 1983 is that a $9 billion deficit has been turned into a $9 billion surplus. That has been done whilst revenue remains at the same proportion of gross domestic product (GDP)-that is, 26.2 per cent-as it was in 1981 and 1982. The bottom line is that a deficit of $9 billion has been changed to a surplus of $9 billion while revenue has remained the same. The reason is that during the last four years an aggregate of 8.1 per cent has been taken off outlays in real terms. During the same period, and indeed a couple of years prior to those four years, the economy was also growing. So outlays as a proportion of GDP-that is, of the whole economy-have fallen by almost six percentage points.
—Tell us about the rises in taxes. There are huge tax rises.

—Senator Michael Baume is babbling away about how taxes have gone up. If Senator Baume listened occasionally instead of talking all the time he would know that taxes have not gone up; taxes remain exactly as they were when the coalition Government brought in its last two Budgets-that is, as a proportion of GDP revenue contributes 26.2 per cent in this year, just as it did in 1981 and 1982. So revenue is the same. A deficit of $9 billion has been turned into a surplus of $9 billion. There is no mystery about that. Outlays have been brought down in real and absolute terms four years in a row while at the same time the economy has been growing.
