If Senator Baume's Party ever gets back into government, I will be amazed if it produces a Budget bottom line or a fiscal record anywhere near that. Throughout the 26 years that those opposite were in government-between 1953 and 1983, with a break of a few years in between-it did not produce one Budget surplus.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Stone Sen J.O.

TALK.START.PARA: —In light of the heat generated by the Minister for Finance, I would like to give him the opportunity to shed a little light by addressing a question to him. I refer the Minister to page 2.60 of Budget Paper No. 1, which states:

QUESTION.PARA: With the economy slowing during 1989-90, through-the-year rather than year-average changes will provide the more meaningful guide to emerging trends for many aggregates.

This is true, for example, of inflation and the current account deficit. The latter, in particular, may show little improvement in year-average terms (relative to GDP) while narrowing progressively over the course of this financial year and into the next.

Similar statements are repeated in at least two other places in the same Budget Paper No. 1. Given this urging by the Government that analysts should examine the through-the-year figures for economic growth, and in particular the rates of growth in the last two quarters of 1989-90 and the development of the balance of payments on current account during the year, I ask: Has the Treasury produced forecasts of 1989-90 gross domestic product growth and the other aggregates on a quarter by quarter basis and, if so-because I think I know the answer to that question-will the Minister table these forecasts to enable journalists and other economic commentators to undertake the proper analysis of budgetary forecasts, as he and his colleagues have urged?

TALK.START.PARA: —The rough division of time is that the preamble took two and a half minutes and the question took about 10 seconds. The question was: Do I know whether Treasury has produced forecasts on a quarter by quarter basis of the estimated current account deficit and consumer price index changes? The answer to that is: I do not know; I will ask the Treasurer.

—Is the Minister representing the Treasurer aware of concerns in the business community about an imbalance in the pattern of investment in favour of commercial real estate at the expense of productive capacity for producing export income? Does the Government agree that this is a problem and, if so, what can be done to rectify it?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have heard expressions of concern about the matter that investment might be secured in favour of real estate investment, or non-factory construction investment which, with the possible exception of tourist hotels, is not likely to have any significant impact, or any impact at all, on our external account problems. At a breakfast which I attended in Melbourne this morning, Mr Loton from Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd echoed those concerns. Many of us share those concerns.

ANSWER.PARA: There was a spectacular example reported on the front page of the Daily Telegraph this morning that the New South Wales Government has a particularly grandiose plan to blow a lot of money on a bit of construction investment that certainly will not do anything for our current account problems. I know some people might say that the same could be said about this building, but the plans to construct this building were really set in concrete about 10 years ago. Whether it was a good decision at the time or not, there was not any realistic option but to continue with it from the time this Government came into office. In saying that I am not being particularly critical of the Government which made the decision to build it, although I think its costings were probably a bit shonky, and deliberately shonky, from the beginning. It may be said that this is also an extravagant building, but the proposals by the New South Wales Government for its building are reported on the front page of the Daily Telegraph in these terms:
. . . become the headquarters of the Premier Nick Greiner, his deputy, Wal Murray, and other senior Ministers.

This is a particularly inopportune time, or stupid time, to be incubating plans to do that sort of thing. I would have thought it was painfully obvious that such a proposal would do nothing for the country's fundamental economic problems other than aggravate them. I may say that I am surprised that Mr Greiner is a party to this-if, indeed, he is a party to it. In my view, Mr Greiner, particularly taking into account the handicaps he has to work under-by which, of course, I mean having the lead weight of the National Party in his saddlebags-seems to have governed reasonably well. There have been occasions when he has not been able to keep the National Party Ministers away from the honey-pot. He has not been entirely successful at that, but policy-wise he seems to have adopted the gratuitous advice I gave him about 12 months ago, which was to ignore members of the National Party, just ride roughshod over them and put the boot into them. Basically he seems to have done that, and I am very pleased that he has taken my advice. I wish he could also keep them away from the public honey-pot more successfully than he has done, but perhaps he will improve in that respect. If the report in the Daily Telegraph is correct, I trust that Mr Greiner in his own interests, in the interests of the State of New South Wales and in the broader interests of the nation puts a stop to it very quickly.

TALK.START.PARA: —Will the Minister for Local Government advise the Senate whether the Hawke Government is supporting the International Union of Local Authorities (IULA) worldwide declaration on local self-government and, if so, what that support means, particularly bearing in mind that five of the six State governments of Australia are opposed to the declaration and have expressed that opposition to her? Will the Minister further advise what the legal and constitutional implications of the declaration could be for intergovernmental relations between Federal, State and local governments in Australia? Will the Government give an undertaking that the declaration will not be used as a basis for legislating pursuant to the external affairs powers on any matter relating to local government?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Reynolds Sen The Hon M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I can certainly give an assurance on the last part of the honourable senator's detailed series of questions. The question of the IULA declaration has been discussed with members of the coalition. I know that there are members on her side of the chamber who are in total agreement with the stand the Government has taken in this regard. There is a great deal of misunderstanding about the declaration. The declaration is not a treaty. I know that one can ask, as some of the correspondents to me on this subject to me have indicated: When is a treaty a treaty and when is it a declaration? The fact is that Australia has not and will not be a signatory to anything in relation to this declaration.

ANSWER.PARA: The IULA worldwide declaration on local self-government was considered at the March meeting of the United Nations experts in public administration and finance. The meeting of experts considered responses to the declaration from several countries. All responses were in support of the principle of local self-government set forth in the declaration. I understand that the meeting of experts intends to ask member states which have no forwarded responses to the declaration to do so as soon as possible.

The Federal Government supported the declaration at the meeting and thereby confirmed the in principle support it provided when the declaration was originally considered by the United Nations Economic and Social Committee in May 1987. The Government did consult with the States and the Northern Territory in developing its position on the declaration. However, the legislative responsibility of the State and Territory governments for local government is explicitly mentioned in Australia's statement of support for the declaration. The declaration is a code of conduct for dealing with local government. It does not have the status of a treaty, as I said before. The Government recognises that the declaration can act as a useful guide in developing the relationship between central governments and local government.

There have been moves in relation to this by individuals and organisations of fairly dubious political merit. I do not say that in any gratuitous way because I know there are senators on the honourable senator's side of the chamber who do agree with the Government's stand in relation to giving this in principle support. I will not embarrass them by naming them, but I know because I have spoken with them about it. So regardless of what the honourable senator's official Party position will be on this matter, I know that those members who genuinely support local government agree with this in principle support.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask a supplementary question, Mr President. I asked the Minister specifically for an undertaking that she would not legislate pursuant to the external affairs power. The answer she has given me is largely irrelevant. The question of its having a treaty or a non-treaty status is, after the Lemonthyme decision, irrelevant. I ask the Minister again: Will she give an undertaking-whether the declaration has treaty status or not-that she will not legislate pursuant to the external affairs power concerning local government?

—I thought I had made it quite clear. I can give that undertaking. I will give that undertaking. I know that no two legal experts can agree but on the advice of the Attorney-General we could not legislate under the Australian Constitution. We cannot legislate under the external affairs provision because this declaration does not have the status of a treaty. We have not, will not and cannot sign anything.

—Is the Minister representing the Minister for Administrative Services aware of reports that the sitting member for Barker, Mr James Porter, is under pressure to stand aside to make way for a Mr Ian McLachlan? Can the Minister advise the Senate of the cost to the Australian taxpayer of holding such a by-election at this time?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: IMMIGRATION, LOCAL GOVERNMENT AND ETHNIC AFFAIRS

TALK.START.PARA: —No, I was not aware that Mr Porter was under any pressure to resign. I am certain that sort of behaviour never occurs in this Parliament. It is unthinkable that such a thing could occur. I have gone on the public record, maybe in a sense of history, in justifying by-elections. I certainly justified the by-elections in Adelaide and Oxley. I certainly did not mind the other one that occurred in Groom. I really think that politics is a process of renewal. I do not want to get renewed yet. However, politics is a process of renewal, and I think an occasional by-election on both sides of the House is a pretty good idea, especially if it is not in a marginal Labor seat. The cost-at least in a direct sense, including public funding and the various costs-of the last three by-elections was $231,000 for Adelaide, $198,000 for Port Adelaide, and $195,000 for Groom. That does not include all the hidden costs that come to the taxpayer by Ministers and shadow Ministers uselessly trooping through one after the other like a troop of baboons trying to get votes. All those hidden costs probably double the total cost in the end, but they never show up in any of the expenditure. I am sure that if there is a desire by Mr Porter to leave parliamentary life now he has no future in politics he would attune that to his future employment needs. I do not think we can condemn someone, if a job comes up and his own Party has deserted him, for jumping at the opportunity and for allowing-what was his name?-Mr McLachlan to come into Parliament. We should not begrudge a couple of hundred thousand dollars now and then for Parliament to renew itself, otherwise it will become like the Senate.

—Has the Minister for Justice and Minister representing the Attorney-General, seen the statement by the Attorney-General, Mr Lionel Bowen, that it is quite likely that no-one will be prosecuted under the War Crimes Act? Does this not confirm remarks made at the time the Bill was being debated that, in addition to the Bill being socially divisive, legally reprehensible and probably unconstitutional, the evidence would be tainted and fair trials would be impossible after nearly 50 years? How much longer will this expensive farce be allowed to continue? How much has it cost so far, and how much more is it expected to cost? In particular, can the Senate be assured that no pressure, direct or indirect, will be put on the Director of Public Prosecutions to bring someone to trial as a means of justifying the millions already wasted?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —There are several elements to the question asked by Senator Hamer. As to the last point, I can give him an absolutely categorical assurance that the Director of Public Prosecutions-being an independent statutory officer and to that extent I guess we could say created and protected by this Parliament-would not be subject to any pressure whatsoever from this Government in relation to the discharge of his very onerous responsibilities. It is in a sense to the contrary as this Parliament has indicated, particularly by the amendments that were properly carried late last year, that it wants all the ordinary processes, both at the prosecution and trial levels, which are a feature of our criminal trials system in Australia, to operate. That would, of course, include, as I said, the independence of decision making by the Director of Public Prosecutions. He would certainly be under no pressure from this Government to, in the honourable senator's terms, justify the legislation by securing a prosecution.

ANSWER.PARA: As to the cost of the Special Investigation Unit, the total expenditure as at 30 June 1989 has been $3,713,871.76. I will table the complete breakdown of that expenditure. As to the state of the particular investigation that has been undertaken, I believe that the 609 files that have been opened as at 11 August 1989 have been divided into categories. This more or less accords with the information I have relayed to the Senate before. Some 345 have been suspended for such reasons as the person not being able to be located in Australia, or an Australian citizen is permanently living abroad and extradition is not appropriate, and so on. The remaining 264 files have been categorised as being still active. Of those remaining 264 files, it is Mr Greenwood's opinion that fewer than 50 will result in probative evidence being obtained with only a percentage of those possibly resulting in prosecution. There is no indication of any number that might be subject to prosecution.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Minister for Local Government aware of continuing criticism from local government of the Federal Government's efforts in the provision of road funding? What is the current position regarding such road funding, particularly in relation to local roads?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Reynolds Sen The Hon M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am continually reminded by local government that road funding is a very important issue for it. I know it is difficult for local government to maintain roads to the levels that it believes it should keep. However, I believe that the Federal Government has been extremely responsible in the level of road funding that it has given over its period in office. This year $1.3 billion has been allocated for Australian roads. This level of funding represents an increase of $120m, or almost 10 per cent, over the 1988-89 levels of funding. Local government, along with all fair-minded people in this chamber, will recognise that a 10 per cent increase for road funding in the current economic climate is extremely responsible. I am sure Senator Walsh would agree that it is extremely generous. Of this money, $890m will be spent on the national highway and the national arterial road systems, and more than $440m will be allocated for State arterial and local roads. The local road element will be maintained in real terms again this financial year at $303.1m for 1989-90, and an estimated $297.4m will be passed on to local government for its purposes. Mr President, I think you would agree that, as much as the Opposition might criticise the Government for every effort it makes in its Budget Statement, nevertheless we have been extremely responsible-indeed, generous.

ANSWER.PARA: I take this opportunity to acknowledge the interest of honourable senators opposite in raising the matter of road funding and funding to local government. In reference to my earlier answer to Senator Bishop, it is good to know that there are honourable senators on the other side of the chamber concerned about local government and road funding issues. However, while Senator Panizza, Senator Bjelke-Petersen, Senator Calvert and I am sure a number of others have raised concerns in the past, I am sure that they will be somewhat surprised to find that Senator Stone, who would have responsibility for determining levels of finance in any unlikely future coalition government, has a very different view in relation to local government and certainly in relation to road funding. At a public meeting in Goondiwindi in Queensland, with local government representatives present, Senator Stone said:
I do not know if we, as a Nation can afford good roads . . .

I am not sure why Senator Boswell is smiling, because here is his colleague in Queensland, a senator representing the National Party of Australia, I assume, saying that he does not believe that we as a nation can afford good roads. Wait for this! He also said:
I would not be prepared to increase road funding.

The local government people present at that meeting in Goondiwindi, being generally of a mind to support the parties sitting opposite-represented by people such as Senator Boswell, Senator Stone and Senator Bjelke-Petersen-were most concerned to hear this. No doubt they gave Senator Stone their No. 1 vote, yet he then turns around and says, `No money for road funding'. In fact they subsequently passed a resolution which, Mr President, if you will permit me, I will take up the time of the Senate to read:
This conference appoint a Deputation to meet with leaders of the Liberal and National Parties in Canberra to discuss road funding, particularly in rural areas.

So it is quite clear that when it comes to road funding there is considerable division in the ranks of the coalition. I think it is appropriate to say that Senator Brownhill, who sits almost next to--

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I take a point of order. This is a very long answer. I think the Minister has moved to the debating point with respect to this answer and I ask you to call her to order.
—It has been a very long answer. I ask the Minister to conclude as quickly as possible.
—It is really childish.

—I do not think emphasising the importance of road funding is childish. If Senator MacGibbon believes that discussing road funding is childish, that is his prerogative. I believe that I have made my point quite clearly.
—What did Brownhill say about it?
—Senator Brownhill advocated doubling road funding. Senator Brownhill should discuss that with Senator Stone.
—Does the Minister representing the Prime Minister believe that interest rates will move down before the end of the financial year?
—I am not disposed to speculate about interest rates, but I believe that that is likely.

—Is the Minister representing the Treasurer aware of proposals discussed in the media recently to adjust the income tax law so that the treatment of interest payments excludes the component which compensates the lender for inflation? Has the Minister seen the paper distributed by the Treasurer on 9 August 1989 which argued, amongst other things, that such proposals would introduce major distortions into the tax system? Can the Minister explain the nature of those distortions and indicate what impact they would have on productive business investment in Australia if the proposals were ever to be implemented?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The question of the inflation adjustment of interest payments for tax purposes has been discussed for a long time and was the subject of 20 or 25 pages in the 1985 draft White Paper on taxation policy that was prepared by the Australian Treasury. Debate on the issue appears to have been sparked off by some rather loose comments made by the Leader of the Opposition a couple of weeks ago during his mock election campaign, and it is not at all clear what Mr Peacock plans precisely to do. I note that most of the senior members of his front bench have been running away from the proposition at 100 miles an hour ever since. But I did see the Treasurer's paper delivered last week which sets out eight problems associated with implementing a Peacock-type proposal and of course it would, as the Treasurer's paper showed, introduce major distortions into the taxation system.

ANSWER.PARA: I will not attempt to deal with all the distortions or all the points the Treasurer made but a very important distortion relates to the type of grandfathering of existing debt which is a key element of most of the proposals of this type which are put up. I can give one example. It was reported in the Australian on 5 June that the shadow Treasurer, Dr Hewson, in partnership with one of his merchant banker mates, had spent $900,000 on a property at Bowral. The property was reported to be rented for some $15,000 a year-a very low return on a $900,000 property. If Dr Hewson and his partner borrowed, say, $800,000 of the purchase price and were paying 18 per cent interest and they had equal shares, the exercise would provide Dr Hewson with a tax deduction of at least $64,000 and a tax benefit of around $32,000. If the proposition were to be introduced and to be grandfathered, as I understand was suggested, those sorts of investments would be totally protected from the change in the rules. So purely passive investment-some people might even call it speculation-would be grandfathered but, at the same time, a genuine entrepreneur who wanted to borrow new money to build a factory, start a mine or do something that would actually help to deal with the country's fundamental economic problem, the continuing current account deficit, would be penalised. It is difficult to see where the economic efficiency is in that sort of proposal or where the fair go is.

As I said earlier in Question Time, I attended a breakfast in Melbourne this morning sponsored by Ernst and Young and the Business Review Weekly, at which Senator Chaney spoke, I spoke and Mr Loton of the Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd also spoke. In reply to a question on this matter Mr Loton said:
Inflation has skewed our saving and investment patterns.
We have got to level the playing field by making equity more available not, subsidised debt.
Not by artificial means such as indexing . . . ?
No, no, no. If you want to see indexation at work, go to Brazil.

I do not know whether the Leader of the Opposition intends to go to Brazil to see indexation at work. If he does I suppose that he could repair his suntan and sharpen up his brain while he was about it.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Employment, Education and Training. Why has the Government so mismanaged its programs for research in higher education that a civil war is now raging between the Australian Research Council (ARC) and the National Health and Medical Research Council, whilst uproar and anger consumes all our university medical faculties? I draw the Minister's attention to the letter to the Adelaide Advertiser from the medical deans of my State's two universities which calls the current and unprecedented decisions of the ARC and this Government `arbitrary and irrational' which `actually threaten health research in medical schools'. Will the Minister reverse his mismanagement and overrule Professor Aitkin and the Australian Research Council's decision to exclude medical research from receiving grants now available for research infrastructure in higher education institutions?

—I have a note here which does not specifically deal with this question but with the much broader issue. I will not read out the whole note because it is rather lengthy. As I am sure Senator Teague well knows, changes were made last year to research funding for tertiary institutions in general. There will be more reliance on people applying for funds and having them approved by the Australian Research Council for specific projects. Senator Teague referred to a civil war going on between the National Health and Medical Research Council and the Australian Research Council. I am not aware of the details of that. I will refer the question to Mr Dawkins and try to get an answer.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. The Minister referred to a briefing note that he has from the Minister. Would he table it or at least give me a copy so that I may be that much more fully informed?
—I am quite happy to table it, but it does not deal specifically, as I have said, with the question asked.

—My question is to the Minister representing the Minister for Social Security. I preface my question by acknowledging the improvements to the young homeless allowance made in the Budget by indexing the allowance and raising the weekly payment by $7.50 as well as reducing the waiting period for some applicants. However, given the announcement in the Budget that a prerequisite for the receipt of the young homeless allowance will, from 1 November 1989, be the provision of a tax file number, has the Government any plans to cater for the strong likelihood that young people who have left home, sometimes fleeing from a violent situation, will not necessarily have stopped to ensure that they have the necessary documentation such as a birth certificate, school report or whatever? Is the Government prepared to negate the possible benefit of the positive Budget action of reducing the waiting period from six to two weeks for those most in need by imposing and enforcing the tax file number prerequisite?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —There is a fair degree of inaccuracy in the information that Senator Powell has presented to the Senate.
—How long will this take?

—This will not take very long. It is probably of interest to Senator McGauran as he is probably young enough to qualify for these. In terms of the Government's commitment in this area, the Government has been keen to provide adequacy and accessibility through the youth homelessness allowance and to provide assistance. In the Budget brought down two days ago these two priorities were met. In doing so, we were mindful of the Burdekin report which asked us to address assistance levels and the waiting period problem. We were also mindful of a Department of Social Security survey on long term Jobsearch allowance recipients which showed that those who were in receipt of the youth homelessness allowance were among the most disadvantaged young people. They had the highest housing costs and were also the most unlikely to have family support. So the initiatives that Senator Powell mentioned provide for an increase in the allowance of $7.50 a week and also indexation from January 1990 in line with the annual indexation of the independent rate of Austudy for 16- and 17-year-olds. There are also changes to Austudy payments for those who qualify for the living at home rate, as well as higher rates for Jobsearch allowance recipients under provisions announced on Tuesday night.

ANSWER.PARA: Another part of Senator Powell's proposition relating to reduced waiting periods should also be tackled, because waiting periods are not only being reduced-generally, across the board, waiting periods will be reduced from six weeks to two weeks-but also they will be abolished in circumstances where young people cannot live at home either because of domestic violence, sexual abuse, or for comparable exceptional circumstances. In essence, that is a picture of some of the Government's initiatives in this area.

The other part of the question goes to the utilisation of the tax file number. It is true that the tax file number will be used, but it is also fair to say that under an agreement which has already been reached with the Australian Taxation Office the problems that Senator Powell raised should and will be accommodated. The problem was raised of those clients who cannot under a normal regime prove their identity. Under the existing procedures there is already allowance for that. The Department of Social Security will be able to certify as to people's identity in cases where applicants would have difficulty under the guidelines used in post offices and, in so being able to certify, the sorts of problems raised should be accommodated. We do not intend to negate the direction of our policy in this area. It is a policy which has been comprehensively worked out, and we will ensure that the people to whom Senator Powell refers, who are probably the most in need, will not miss out on benefits because of that sort of hiccup.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Patterson Sen K.C.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister for Finance and Minister representing the Treasurer. I draw his attention to a letter that his colleague the Hon. Peter Morris, the Minister Assisting the Treasurer, wrote in reply to a representation I made on behalf of the Nursing Mothers Association of Australia (NMAA), in which he said:

QUESTION.PARA: The Government believes that in virtually all cases the most efficient way of providing assistance to worthy organisations is through the expenditure side of the Budget, and not through the tax system.

Is the Minister aware that the reason that the NMAA is seeking specific listing under section 78 (1) (a) of the Income Tax Assessment Act as an organisation eligible for tax deductable donations is that its grant of $76,200 in the 1988-89 Budget to assist with the training of breastfeeding counsellors, administration and coordination has been cut to zero in 1989-90?

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not sure whether the years stated are correct. I do remember hearing that a grant had been paid to the Nursing Mothers Association in some year and that it had been discontinued, but I am not sure in which year it was paid and in which year it was discontinued. I have not seen Mr Morris's letter, although I have seen similar letters. I have seen a press report today-and it is no more reliable than that-which indicated that there had been some grant, if not to that specific Association, then for that general purpose, but I do not remember, since I do not know such fine details of the Budget figuring, what grant for that organisation or for similar organisations, if any, has been made. I will check that out and send Senator Patterson an answer.

—My question is to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade and relates to that group of people in South Africa who have become known as the Upington 26, all of whom are under sentence of death for their alleged common purpose in the death of a police officer in 1985. Can the Minister advise the Senate of the current position of these people and what steps the Australian Government has taken to communicate its position on this matter to the South African Government?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The situation is that 14 of the 26 defendants in what has become known as the Upington case were sentenced to death in South Africa on 26 May for the death of a black policeman on 13 November 1985. The court ruled that there were no extenuating circumstances. As Senator Collins has said, they were convicted on the basis of so-called common purpose with a mob of 300 that attacked the policeman's house. The Upington murder took place against a background of heightened racial tension after police tear gassed a meeting, and the murdered policeman is alleged to have fired on the crowd in question. The case is very similar to the case of the Sharpeville six who were sentenced to death on the basis of that same doctrine of common purpose. The Sharpeville six were reprieved last November after diplomatic pressure from many nations including Australia.

ANSWER.PARA: The Upington sentences have been very widely condemned. Critics point to the striking disparity in the sentences. Those on death row were in fact convicted on the same evidence as the 12 who were given custodial and suspended sentences. Lawyers for the Upington 14, as they now are, have petitioned the Chief Justice of the Appellate Division for leave to appeal against their conviction and death sentences. Leave to appeal was originally refused by the trial judge. This current petition constitutes the last step in the legal process. Should it be rejected, clemency will be sought from the State President. The Australian Government, in accordance with normal practice in these matters, will await the outcome of the appeal process before taking any further action on the matter. However, should the appeal fail the Government would wish to make further strong representations in order to try to save the lives of these people.

Finally, the Australian Government deplores any act of wanton violence, particularly if it leads to death. However, we have consistently and universally opposed the imposition of the death sentence as being a cruel and inhuman form of punishment. If the sentences are proceeded with, as many people fear will be the case, they will only exacerbate an already very tense political climate which is caused by the continued denial of political freedoms to the vast majority of South Africa's people.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —On Tuesday Senator Knowles asked a question of Senator Richardson, who was then the Minister representing the Minister for Community Services and Health. Since I have returned and I am now in that position, I can answer the question that was put on notice then by Senator Richardson. I presume that Senator Knowles's question related to a general slur on the medical profession by Dr Andrew Dunn of Perth which appeared in an article in the West Australian newspaper on Monday. Dr Dunn made the extraordinary and baseless allegation that doctors are abusing Medicare bulk billing systems to line their own pockets and to overprescribe drugs to drug addicts.

ANSWER.PARA: The facts of the matter are that within the last week the Medical Board of Western Australia has advised the Health Insurance Commission (HIC) of the names of three doctors who have been before it in relation to prescribing practices. One doctor has been suspended for three months while the other two have been found guilty of improper professional conduct and have been reprimanded. Four other doctors are believed to be under investigation by the Medical Board. I point out that Medicare data held by the HIC does not contain information about the nature of a consultation, such as what drugs a practitioner might prescribe for particular patients. The HIC can examine a doctor's medical servicing profile to determine whether there are any irregularities. The HIC has provided advice that it believes in this instance these doctors' medical servicing profiles should be examined. However, the Government believes that the Medical Board of Western Australia is the appropriate body to examine these doctors' prescribing habits. I also point out that the Board has made no reference to these doctors' use of bulk billing and neither would it be logical to do so.

The fact is that doctors would be able to exchange a quick easy prescription for a consultation charge, as Dr Dunn puts it, whether or not bulk billing existed. A doctor could just as easily bill the patients but accept the rebate as full payment as many doctors do and have done under Medicare and under previous private health insurance arrangements. Thus the patient has not been bulk billed but still faces no out of pocket costs; the effect is the same. In any event, it seems strange that Dr Dunn could seriously argue that `druggies', as he calls them, who want additional prescription drugs are not going to be prepared to pay an extra couple of dollars above the Medicare rebate for doctors' visits. After all, unless they are pensioners or disadvantaged people the prescriptions which they get are still going to cost them up to $11 or $12.

As to the insinuation about doctors who bulk bill, experience under Medicare has demonstrated that doctors who bill their patients are just as likely to overservice as those who bulk bill Medicare. I point out that some 60 per cent of all general practitioners' services in Western Australia are bulk billed. That means that most Western Australian GPs bulk bill at least some of their patients and many bulk bill a large number of patients. The Government therefore regards the allegations made by Dr Dunn about `unscrupulous bulk billing doctors' as an unsubstantiated slur on a largely honourable profession.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yesterday Senator Vallentine asked two supplementary questions of me regarding the Broome airport. The relevant Minister has provided me with the following response. As to the first question, there has been no feasibility study undertaken by the Federal Government to determine the need for an international airport at Broome. Should there be an application to designate Broome airport as an international gateway or an application for international services to an airport in the Broome area, the Federal Government would assess such cases on their merits.

ANSWER.PARA: As to the second question, whether Lord McAlpine has permanent resident status in Australia, that is not a consideration that is relevant to the Federal Government's negotiations with the Shire of Broome on the transfer of Broome airport.

TALKER.NAME: Senator STONE
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I claim to have been misrepresented, Mr Deputy President. During the course of Question Time the Minister for Local Government, Senator Reynolds, made a number of wild assertions about what I am supposed to have said at a meeting at Goondiwindi some time ago on the question of road funding. There is no truth in those assertions but it is true that I did attend a meeting in Goondiwindi and the subject of roads did arise. It is also true that since that time a local affiliate of the League of Rights has been spreading rumours to the general effect quoted in this place by Senator Reynolds. I only want to say that I regret very much that the Minister should lend the weight of her ministerial authority to rantings from League of Rights quarters and to say, apart from that, that the Opposition's policies towards road funding after we take office will be revealed in the not too distant future.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jenkins Sen J.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I claim to have been misrepresented, Mr Deputy President, and wish to make a personal explanation. During the adjournment debate last night Senator Panizza spoke on the matter of child migrants and misrepresented me with regard to fact and motivation. I would like to address the misrepresentation with regard to fact more appropriately in an adjournment speech, probably this evening. With regard to misrepresentation of motivation I wish to make a brief statement now. Senator Panizza said:

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Jenkins at this time needs any band wagon that she can get on for the coming election.

That is a gross misrepresentation of my motivation. I obtained the eleventh Senate seat in Western Australia with a first vote quota of 0.75 per cent; that is, some 46,000 votes. I am a realist and I therefore believe that it is possible that I only have three years to fulfil my election promises. I undertook to truly represent my constituents, especially with regard to social justice issues and, in particular, to those issues not being addressed elsewhere. As the sole Australian Democrat parliamentary representative in Western Australia I am run off my feet in seeking to do this. As with many issues, I have not to date issued a single media release on the subject of child migrants. These people came to me having in past times gone to other parliamentary representatives. Calling representing one's constituents standing on a band wagon is a misrepresentation of a most offensive and small-minded nature.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise on a point of order, Mr Deputy President. Could I have a direction from the Chair as to whether it really does constitute a personal misrepresentation to simply say of an opposing politician that he or she is seeking to jump on to any political band wagon that might be passing. I would have thought that was part of the cut and thrust of politics. If Senator Jenkins is going to use that as an excuse for retailing her position on a number of issues, it seems to me to be a gross waste of the time of the Senate.

—The grant to Senator Jenkins of leave to speak was made to make a personal explanation. That is interpreted fairly broadly. I should make it clear to senators, though, that in the course of a personal explanation it is not proper to criticise another senator. I was listening carefully to see that Senator Jenkins did not do that. As long as remarks are relevant to the misrepresentation, the leave of the Senate to make a personal explanation is just that-a personal explanation. If it goes on too long I will call the senator to order; but other than that, the right is there. Have you finished, Senator Jenkins?
—Yes. Thank you, Mr Deputy President.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crichton-Browne Sen N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-Mr Deputy President, I claim to have been misrepresented and wish to make a personal explanation. During the period shortly prior to the last recess I, on behalf of the Liberal Party of Australia, was invited to address a group that, if my memory serves me rightly, described itself as the Mortgage Action Group, in South Perth, Western Australia. When I arrived I quickly discovered that the group was actually a front for the Australian Democrats and the convener was the endorsed Democrat candidate for the Federal seat of Stirling. However, I addressed the meeting, as did Senator Jenkins.

SPEECH.PARA: During my speech I made it clear that it was not the view of the Liberal Party that anyone could arbitrarily reduce interest rates for home loan mortgages by simply passing, as if with a magic wand, legislation through this chamber or any other chamber of any parliament. I would have thought that that is a view subscribed to by most reasonable and sensible people.

TALK.START.PARA: —I raise a point of order. Mr Deputy President, I would ask you to inspect this personal explanation in the light of your previous rulings to see whether it is in fact a personal explanation.

—I am waiting for Senator Crichton-Browne to come to his personal explanation. He has not yet abused anyone else so he is in order in that respect. Senator Crichton-Browne, the leave you were given was leave to make a personal explanation.

—I went to this meeting believing that I was addressing a group of people who were concerned at the level of their home loan repayments. They had a common interest in being there. I did not expect that it would simply be a meeting of pro-Democrats seeking to grab cheap publicity from any journalist who was silly enough to go. Following that meeting a number of such meetings have been held throughout Western Australia which also appear to be fronts for the Democrats, who have not had the guts to say--
—Order! Senator Crichton-Browne, you are getting wide of a personal explanation now. To discuss the general conduct of meetings is not in order in a personal explanation.

—I am arriving at the choice of words to be used by the Democrats at future meetings. I can do that, sir, with respect, only by explaining that subsequent meetings have been held by the same group for the same purpose. I have discovered that the main purpose is simply to promote the Democrats behind the facade of another name. A number of Democrats have been standing up at these meetings and saying, `Senator Crichton-Browne has claimed that the Liberal Party and the coalition could not reduce interest rates'. I have to say for the benefit of those who have used that expression that it is a blatant lie, reeking with the obvious dishonesty which pervades one political organisation in Australia known to all of us. I take grave exception to those parliamentarians and those belonging to political parties who hold themselves out as `keeping the bastards honest' lying at these public meetings.
—Order! Senator Crichton-Browne, you must not in the course of a personal explanation criticise the motivation of others.
—I find it highly offensive and most hurtful that the Democrats should suggest that I would tell other than the truth.

DEBATE.TITLE: PULP MILLS: MODERN TECHNOLOGY AND ENVIRONMENTAL PROTECTION

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper:

The Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation (CSIRO) report on bleached kraft pulp mills is of great significance to the future of the pulp and paper industry of Australia, an industry which in this time of record balance of payments deficits offers a positive solution to this problem. This report followed recognition by the Government that it was not equipped to evaluate properly the technical status of North Broken Hill's proposed bleached kraft pulp mill for Tasmania, or the status of the bleached kraft pulp mills in general. CSIRO scientists with experience in chemical pulping technology, oceanography and fisheries went to Finland, Sweden and North America to investigate modern bleached kraft mills and government controls in other countries, and to report on possible alternatives to chlorine bleaching.

The findings of this committee, in summary, were as follows. Firstly, the only significant international market for short fibred pulp obtainable from eucalyptus is bleached kraft pulp, and to achieve the brightness demanded by the market there is currently no alternative to using chlorine. Secondly, the countries visited, although often having a history of intense environmental concern compared with Australia, were not curtailing the development of their bleached kraft pulp industries.

Thirdly, modern bleached kraft pulp mills were using considerably less chlorine than a few of the old mills which had been associated with environmental problems and there appeared to be no short to medium term risk of damage to the environment. Because none of the new mills had been operating for a long time, the possibility of some environmental damage in the long term could not be discounted. However, the scientists noted that so long as base line studies were conducted, followed up by continual monitoring and a commitment to introduce new commercially proven technology, if appropriate, then the long term risks to the environment, if any, would be minimal or insignificant.

The report is not only significant because it supports the belief that modern bleached kraft mills can operate at an acceptable level of risk to the environment but also significant for Australia because 4.8 million tonnes of woodchips-which, when exported, are currently valued at approximately $350m-have the potential to earn $1,200m as bleached kraft pulp. The difference represents an $850m net reduction to the deficit. Australia has a significant and growing trade deficit in forest products. The deficit in forest products has grown from a mere $573m in 1980-81 to over $1.6 billion in 1988-89-a threefold increase in less than a decade. During the decade exports doubled but were overwhelmed by the doubling of the value of imports from a much greater base.

The major component of the forest product trade deficit is paperboard and pulp. Yet the major export category is woodchips. During the history of the woodchip export industry a combination of economic and market constraints has prevented the development of an export based pulp and paper industry. When these were overcome last year environmental concerns further delayed development. Hopefully, the adoption of the CSIRO report, coupled with the production of environmental guidelines acceptable to government and industry, will result in our wood resources being fully processed at home, thus greatly increasing our export earnings.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sanders Sen N.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am afraid to say that this report-Pulp Mills: Modern Technology and Environmental Protection-is very disappointing. It is quite obvious that the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation (CSIRO) team came back with the information which it knew would most please the Government, which controls its purse strings. The blinkered findings are nothing more than a chlorine bleached whitewash of the Wesley Vale type kraft pulp mills. If we need any verification of that it is that Senator Watson supports this report. Of course, he would support anything which would be environmentally hazardous to the State of Tasmania.

SPEECH.PARA: The report reveals its bias in a number of areas. For one thing the CSIRO dismisses the wood efficient thermomechanical pulping process, even though the Swedes have just built a new plant to supply environmentally friendly paper for the highly demanding computer industry. An article entitled ` ``Green'' look for computer print-outs' in the New Scientist of 15 April states:

One of Europe's largest suppliers of paper this week launched the world's first `environmentally friendly' stationery for computers. Roffs Stralfors, a Swedish paper company, has run trials of the paper on the Swedish market and now plans to exploit the large potential market in Britain.
I will refer to that market later because CSIRO said that it is declining. The article continues:
This market has been created by growing concern over the use of chlorine as a bleaching agent in the paper industry-
CSIRO says there is no concern and that there is no market for this paper; the New Scientist seems to indicate differently-
. . . and its implication in the release of harmful dioxins into the environment.
This report by the CSIRO also does not seem to realise the present state of thermomechanical pulping in Tasmania. It says:
Thermomechanical pulping in its present stage of development is not suited to processing mature eucalypts.

What has Australian Newsprint Mills Ltd (ANM) been doing at Boyer if not using mature eucalypts from our Tasmanian virgin forests-400-year-old trees? The CSIRO people are not even experts. They are biased, certainly, but they are not experts. They take the line of always saying what will please the people who want Wesley Vale kraft-type pulp mills. They dismiss biological damage. On page 6 of the report, it is stated:

Such findings and actions are obviously cause for concern. However, in the Australian context these must be evaluated in the light of a modern pulp mill discharging effluent into receiving waters which have not been subjected to some 80 years of pollution from pulp mills.

Bass Strait has been subject to pollution from pulp mills for many years. The CSIRO scientists do not seem even to recognise the fact that Associated Pulp and Paper Mills Ltd (APPM) has been pouring effluent into Bass Strait for years.

The most damaging indictment of the CSIRO I can make is that it distorts the facts on the future need for unbleached paper. Unbleached paper is the fastest growing section of the paper industry. The demand for it is burgeoning. In this country the paper products division of the oil company Castrol has signed contracts with the Swedish Government to import unbleached toilet paper, unbleached sanitary napkins and unbleached coffee filters because of the growing demand for such paper. All over the world people are turning to processes which are environmentally friendly. They are now aware that the environment is harmed by chlorine bleached papers and kraft-type pulp mills.

There are other ways of making paper. We can re-cycle paper, certainly, but we can make new paper in an environmentally friendly manner by using thermo-mechanical pulping and hydrogen peroxide bleaches, methods which the CSIRO dismisses because it knows that this Government and the industry wants to use the cheap, nasty and dirty kraft pulp mill process and chlorine bleaches. It expects us to swallow it; we will not. As a nation, we will not swallow the stuff. That is why I am reiterating my call for a full-scale inquiry into pulp mills. This report is nothing but a whitewash and should be disregarded.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce)

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not normally interrupt Opposition senators' time in discussion of government reports, but I find it nothing short of despicable that Senator Sanders should come in here and attack officers--
—Have you read this thing? Have you read it?

—Yes, I have. Senator Sanders does no good by shouting at me. He can shout at his Australian Democrat constituents in Tasmania, while they last. It is no good his shouting at me. To come in here and attack scientists of the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation (CSIRO) in the way he did is nothing short of despicable. The sooner he is out of this place, the better. To come in here and say that CSIRO scientists are incapable of scientific objectivity because they are a publicly funded sector is nothing short of despicable, as I said. If Senator Sanders wants to disagree with them, that is all right; it is fine; he can do so. But to come in here--
—Don't give him your preferences in Canberra.

—I do not want any advice from Senator Baume today. He can make me angry on his own, and this bloke has already done pretty well today. The fact is that Senator Sanders is surrounded by a fog of ignorance. From time to time he emerges from it such as on this occasion, when he came into the chamber to deliver this attack: These men are paid by the taxpayers; therefore they are intellectually corrupt in their scientific activities. That is what the honourable senator said, and he cannot run away from it now.
—I said the Government. You are cutting their purse strings.
—Order!

—Senator Sanders is leaving Tasmania and coming to Canberra, but one thing for sure and about which I am very grateful is that he is not coming back to this chamber. If he said outside the things he says in the chamber, he would be sued for libel, and properly so.

SPEECH.PARA: I also take Senator Sanders up on one other point. On the basis of an article in the New Scientist, Senator Sanders said that there was a burgeoning market for unbleached paper. He wants to believe that, because it happens to suit his position. The market for unbleached paper in terms of the development of the pulp and paper industry in this country is totally unrealistic for us. One reason is that we would then belong to a captive international market-place largely held by the Japanese, not an open market-place. If Senator Sanders wants to enter into those sorts of sub-economic activities, I suggest he go elsewhere to advocate that sort of thing.

I do not want to waste the time of other honourable senators, so I will just say that the tone of Senator Sanders's remarks is totally wrong and offensive. I find them ignorant in some respects, but that is a matter which Senator Sanders can debate with me. I would welcome such debate. But it is not fair to make such remarks about people who are not here and to attack their professional reputations in the way in which Senator Sanders did.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Puplick Sen C.J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before making specific comments on the report entitled Pump Mills: Modern Technology and Environmental Protection, I associate Opposition senators with the comments made by Senator Button in defending the scientific integrity of Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation officers who were responsible for the production of the report. Whatever one may think of the conclusions of the report, it is not correct to impugn the scientific reputation and integrity of the officers who produced the report. Indeed, the only thing I can say is that I am not surprised that the attack was made, given the fact that the report is a scientific analysis which, on the basis of the known facts, has come to conclusions fundamentally unacceptable to the Australian Democrats. It has been evident today that Senator Sanders, therefore, instead of playing the ball, has played the men and impugned the integrity, motivation and competence of those who prepared the report. I join Senator Button in rejecting that attack.

SPEECH.PARA: The report would not have been produced had the Government not been forced by pressure put upon it by the Liberal and National parties to undertake a proper evaluation of the circumstances surrounding the construction of pulp mills in Australia following the debacle of the Wesley Vale pulp mill proposal, which was occasioned primarily by the Federal Government's failure to develop and promulgate guidelines which investors and people who might be interested in establishing pulp mills in Australia needed to have available to them.

In the statement released by Senator Button, by the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, Mr Kerin, and the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories, Senator Richardson, on 20 July, an undertaking was given by Senator Button that guidelines would be finalised and made public by no later than 30 November. I hope it will be possible for the guidelines to be finalised at an earlier date so that the Parliament will have the opportunity before it rises to debate the pulp mill guidelines which the Government will develop. I would not like to see those guidelines brought down during the parliamentary recess period and not available for immediate public debate.
It is important to note some of the primary conclusions of this report. In part, the report states:

The complete elimination of toxic substances from the effluent of a bleached kraft mill is presently not possible. However, large reductions in the toxicity of these effluents have occurred during the past ten years, and, with the continued intensity of research that is being undertaken around the world, further significant reductions are likely.
The report also states:
There are a number of reasons why the complete replacement of the chlorine with chlorine dioxide is not a practical alternative in a pulp mill producing bleached pulp for export.
The report indicates quite clearly that the future trend in the development of pulp mills throughout the world will be in terms of pulp mills using the kraft process. The report states:
The kraft or sulphate process is the most commonly used of the chemical pulping technologies and its predominance is increasing.

It goes on to indicate that in the countries which were visited-Sweden, Finland and Canada, which are major producers of pulp and paper-despite the fairly stringent environmental controls which countries like Sweden have pioneered, there is no indication that they will allow regulation to seriously impact the contribution of this industry to their economy. The report states that in all of these countries capacity is being expanded.

This is a useful and significant report because it analyses a large number of controversial scientific questions which need to be addressed. It makes quite clear that development of our paper and pulp industry will be in a particular direction, that the kraft process will be the predominant process used, and that demands for a totally toxin-free waste from these facilities is impracticable but that substantial progress already has been made and will continue to be made in getting down the levels of toxic emissions. We welcome the report. It will allow us to continue the debate about appropriate guidelines and we hope that the Government will produce those at the earliest possible date.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vallentine Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to reiterate and support the call by Senator Sanders for a full inquiry into the whole question of pulp mills in Australia. Unfortunately, when this report, Pulp Mills: Modern Technology and Environmental Protection, was commissioned, non-government environmentalists were invited as observers, yet three members of industry were taken along with the Government Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation (CSIRO) scientists.

SPEECH.PARA: The bulk of analysis in the review focuses on bleach kraft mills, with only a brief and dismissive treatment of non-chlorine pulp processes and marketing opportunities for unbleached pulp or non-chlorine bleached pulp. With the exception of its scant analysis of the market potential for unbleached and chlorine-free bleaching of chemo-thermo-mechanical pulp, the CSIRO study's findings are generally logical within its terms of reference if certain assumptions are made. I want to question these assumptions. It is important to highlight, as well as to question, them precisely because they have not been subject to analysis and are not automatically accepted by many community groups and concerned individuals, nor should they be.

The first assumption is that a pulp mill in Australia will be based, at least initially, on the forest industry's access to mature native eucalypt forests as per current woodchip licence arrangements. This allows the further vertical integration of the dominant forest products companies from logging to merchandising paper. Despite the stated success of the chemo-thermo-mechanical process with hardwood pulp in Canada and its experimental use with eucalypts in Australia, that process is rejected because of its current limitations in processing mature eucalypt, which is expected to provide the bulk of the raw material for an Australian export pulp industry, as stated on page 45 of the report. In this regard it is interesting to note that F. H. Phillips of CSIRO's Forest and Forest Products Division in Victoria writes in a recent edition of Australian Forester:

. . . the sawlog tree is not necessarily the ideal pulpwood tree . . . eucalypt pulp from selected species grown under more or less ideal conditions is equal or superior to other hardwood pulps, e.g. birch kraft pulp. Unfortunately, this does not apply to the bulk of domestic eucalypt pulp made in Australia or to the potential of a large part of the current eucalypt wood resources. These resources are mainly mixed-age, mixed-species, cut-over native forests and will not provide premium-grade pulpwood.

In other words, we appear to be locking ourselves into the sacrifice of mature native forests for woodchips for pulp production when even-aged eucalypt plantations are a superior resource for this purpose. This is quite aside from the enormous cost to conservation values when mature native forests are logged for the supply of woodchips.

The second assumption is that a pulp mill primarily will produce for the export market. The Federal Government is committed to tariff reduction to ensure that industry investment is channelled into areas where Australia can be internationally competitive, restricting pulp and paper industry investments to international-scale operations. That needs to be questioned.

The third assumption is that the current market definition of `high quality paper' means bright, white paper for a vast range of uses. The proportion of world paper consumption that must be bleached for essential functional reasons, as opposed to lack of choice and concerted marketing effort, is not seriously addressed. In addition, the report does not question the criteria for marketing quality pulp, such as the arbitrary industry standard of bleaching to a brightness intensity many degrees beyond which the human eye can distinguish. In the report's discussion of essential characteristics of paper which are achievable only by chlorine bleaching and `perceived quality perceptions of the marketplace' the report's discussion is disappointing in its ready acceptance of what could be defined only as luxury so-called needs in paper quality. For example, the potential for newsprint to be modified to facilitate the use of colours in newspapers is mentioned in relation to essential paper qualities.

The fourth assumption is that poor recycling records in Australia, West Germany, Great Britain and Sweden prevent the use of recycled waste paper for high quality uses. This is a very fatalistic attitude in the context of high public awareness and the widespread desire to do the right thing environmentally if only recycling were given appropriate Government support. The fifth assumption is that the only way to really test the toxicity of a bleached kraft mill effluent using eucalypts in Australian conditions is to build a full scale pulp mill-that is, experiment for ourselves.

Obviously these assumptions deserve objective analysis because they effectively restrict any future pulp mill developments in Australia to kraft or modified kraft and chlorine bleaching processes. Not surprisingly, the CSIRO delegation found that bleach kraft pulp mills pose long term environmental impacts of great concern which are impossible to predict with current levels of understanding. In relation to the prediction of the environmental impacts of bleached kraft mill effluent (BKME) in Australia the report states on page 22:
There is no doubt that BKME contains a variety of compounds that exhibit chronic toxicity-some at very low concentrations-to equatic organisms.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Archer Sen B.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —Today's news in Tasmania emphasises the closure of two major building concerns. Last week the Government announced that it was putting a stop to development of a whole range of public works. Two months ago there was an announcement that there would be no pulp mill, that there would be no entrance to existing forests, and that the Government would prevent exploration of all sorts of mining operations in Tasmania as well. Where is Australia heading? What will we sell to pay our bills? How much debt can this country stand?

SPEECH.PARA: We will soon be facing a debt of $150 billion. Do we want it to go up to $180 billion? Do we want it to go to $200 billion? Investors coming to Australia at present consider three particular items. The first is that we are totally unreliable on supply, quality and delivery, and that our industrial relations are just not good enough. Secondly, potential investors are up against these ridiculous prevent-everything groups. Their attitudes-Australia-wide, and in Tasmania in particular-are threatening us every day. Thirdly, we have this crazy pumped up dollar that nobody in the world can live with and nobody can understand. Who is prepared to gamble on that right now?

The pulp mill was a very spectacular issue. It resulted in a campaign of fear and mis-information second to none. I regret that the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories (Senator Richardson) fell for it and got involved with all these matters without bothering to get the facts that he should have had. However, I think that, unwittingly, he has done us a public service. The committee that was commissioned to investigate modern technology and environmental protection in relation to pulp mills was as good as could have been selected in the whole of Australia. There was not a thing wrong with the committee. Whether I like its findings or not, in every case I accept it as being the best we could have obtained. It was widely representative, highly skilled and most professional. The terms of reference were most adequate and the results are very clear.

It should be remembered that we are facing this on the basis that we have a $135 billion deficit, growing at the rate of $1.7 billion a month. The wood products deficit alone has grown from $250m a year in 1977 to $1,500m a year in 1988-or six times. We must grow more trees and harvest more wood. We must get the turnover and pull our weight in the international situation. We must continue to make the timber industry cleaner and safer. Tasmania is already by far the cleanest State in Australia and we want that improved still further. We must pull our weight in wood production internationally. We must add value to the 4.5 million tonnes per annum of exported woodchips and we must do more in the whole area of wood treatment.

The report, Pulp Mills: Modern Technology and Environmental Protection, says that we are on the right track and that the rules and regulations which were laid down by the Tasmanian Government were first class. The effluent treatment has been vastly upgraded. The stack emissions are virtually approved to background levels. Dioxins became the big fear word of the whole campaign, but I am told by a leading Canberra scientist that there would be more dioxin emitted in Canberra on a sunny, Sunday summer afternoon around the barbecues than there would be from a pulp mill at Wesley Vale.

The last paragraph of the summary says that new pulp mills in Australia will create a demand for well trained researchers in relevant fields. Let us concentrate on the positive aspects. There is so much in this that we can make into positives. Let us not fall for this useless, negative group of people who just want to see Australia become a third world country, carrying water, hewing stone, and things like that. This country has got to get to where it pays its bills and survives.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Stone Sen J.O.

TALKER.NAME: Senator STONE
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —It was not my intention to speak to this paper. In fact, I had left the Senate and had gone back to my room when I heard on the broadcast the quite disgraceful remarks by Senator Sanders relating to the authors of this report. Both Senator Button, the Leader of the Government in the Senate, and my colleague, Senator Puplick, have addressed themselves to that matter. Nevertheless, having taken the trouble to come back into the Senate because of my feeling of outrage at what I heard, I propose to spend just 60 seconds addressing those remarks.

SPEECH.PARA: Having been a public servant myself-admittedly within a departmental structure and not within the structure of an institution such as the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation-I know what it is to be assailed in the Parliament of the Commonwealth and not have the right to respond. The remarks by Senator Sanders, if I recall them correctly, were along the lines that the nature of this report was to provide the Government with the answers which it wants, because the Government pays the salaries of the scientists concerned. I cannot remember many more gross reflections upon the personal integrity of individuals unable to defend themselves that even the history of this Parliament, I am sure, could reveal. I see that Senator Sanders has fled the chamber.

TALK.START.PARA: —He usually does.

—As Senator Calvert quite rightly reminds me, he usually does, having made an outrageous statement such as this. Without taking the time of the Senate unduly I want to unreservedly condemn the actions of-I should not say senators because I cannot think of anybody else in the Senate who behaves in the manner of Senator Sanders-Senator Sanders in uttering the remarks that he uttered today.

—My remarks are directed to Senator Button who, I think, was quite despicable in his attack on Senator Sanders. The point that was being made was that if the terms of reference are set for an inquiry into something that will, in some sense, determine the outcome of that inquiry. What we have here is an assumption that the demand for bleached paper will continue and somehow there is a need to meet that. Whether that demand continues in the way in which Senator Button is indicating depends very much on what sort of tax structure is set, and what other impediment the Government chooses to put into the system to protect the environment. What we heard from Senator Button was clearly a defence, a higher priority put on the economy than there was on environmental protection.
