SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tambling Sen G.E.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.
I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! On behalf of the President, in accordance with the provisions of section 81 of the Reserve Bank Act 1959 I present the report of the Reserve Bank of Australia Board on the operations of the Bank, together with financial statements and the report of the Auditor-General for the financial year 1988-89.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.

This report is of major significance. It gives the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) an overwhelming clobbering. It denies the basis upon which the Budget was brought down this week and it rejects outright his total bunkum on expectations of falling interest rates. It denies the nonsense that the Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Button) of all people, went on with today in response to a question when he said that he expected there would be a fall in interest rates. This damning of the Keating Budget is quite striking in the Reserve Bank of Australia annual report. It is very heartening to see the Reserve Bank being prepared to stand up to this bullying Treasurer (Mr Keating), this bullying Prime Minister, this incompetent Government, and to report things as it sees them without fear or favour. In relation to interest rates the Reserve Bank report actually states:
. . . may need to remain high for quite some time to achieve the desired effect.

That is, dampening growth in private demand to an extent where all categories of spending would be diminished effectively so that the economy would be in a sound state. It does say that the current setting of monetary policy is now dampening growth in private demand but, I repeat, it will need to remain high for quite some time to achieve the desired effect.

Why, therefore, do we keep having the Prime Minister and Senator Button creating this totally false impression that cuts in interest rates are just around the corner? The Prime Minister said this before the Western Australian election and that produced a 2 per cent rise in housing loan interest rates. Now we have him saying it again, so I suppose that must indicate we are about to have a Federal election. Heaven knows why. An election is not due until the middle of next year, but the fact that the Prime Minister is already panic stricken enough to be waving this carrot of reduced interest rates seems to suggest the potential for an earlier date than the one popularly expected. Even worse, the Reserve Bank warns as follows:
The size of the task should not be underestimated.
That is the sort of mess this Government has got this economy into. It continues:
Inflation appears set to remain above the average for industrial countries, even if demand pressures are contained.
Even if the high interest rate policy works, according to the Reserve Bank inflation is set to remain above the average for industrial countries. The report goes on:

The inevitable rise in debt servicing costs will add to the turnaround required in our trade performance if the current account deficit is to be reduced. Nevertheless, it is imperative that there be a return to the progress on reducing both the rate of inflation and the current account deficit over the coming year.

The Reserve Bank says it is imperative. What does the Budget do? Under the Budget, inflation gets worse and the balance of payments deficit gets worse. This Government has let the ball go through to the keeper on both the issues that the Reserve Bank says it is imperative something be done about over the coming year. In this Budget it has done nothing to improve either of those matters. In fact, the Budget forecasts that they will get worse. I repeat: this Budget has done nothing to resolve the two elements on which the Reserve Bank has said it is imperative that there be a return to progress.
Another crack at our incredibly economically literate Prime Minister comes in the next sentence of this report:
The Bank does not share the opinion expressed in some quarters that, since most of the debt-
that is, foreign debt-
is owed within the private sector rather than by government, it is a matter of little consequence.

TALK.START.PARA: —Who said that?
—The Prime Minister. The economically literate Prime Minister said, `Don't worry about the foreign debt; it is all private'.
—A pedlar of false hope.

—Yes. The Reserve Bank is not prepared to be intimidated by this Government, its leader or its Treasurer. It has been prepared to say it does not share the opinion expressed in some quarters-I suppose that means quarterwit rather than halfwit-that since most of the debt is owed in the private sector it is of little consequence. The Bank goes on to say:

SPEECH.PARA: The extent to which resources must be diverted to its future servicing is the same whether the debt is publicly or privately owed, and the investment which it has enabled will not automatically ensure that these resources are available.

The Reserve Bank, in its summary, goes on to say that monetary policy simply cannot carry everything. There is a clear inference that perhaps it has been overused. Certainly in the detail later on it says that the exuberance of markets led to an easing of monetary conditions before the other policies had taken up the slack. This is basically an admission that the other policies were inadequate and there was an excessive reliance by this Government on monetary policy. I remind the Senate that as this was in the early months of 1987 this was just before the last election. Quite frankly, I do not find it very comforting to see that these magic mistakes seem to occur just prior to an election. The corrections of these mistakes have then involved us in major disasters with interest rates and the foreign exchange situation.

The Reserve Bank reinforces a point I made during the last session about the perverse effect of tight monetary policy on the balance of payments. In fact, an exchange rate appreciation can be produced which brings about exactly the opposite results to those the Government is seeking to achieve. As the Bank states:
On its own, monetary policy will not produce the longer-term structural benefits Australia is seeking.

Yet once again in this Budget there is undue reliance on monetary policy, particularly because of this Government's failure to bring about any vestige of the micro-economic reform we need. There is excessive dependence on monetary policy, despite the Reserve Bank's warning that it will not produce the longer term structural benefits Australia is seeking. The report states that it may even inhibit the structural change because of the effect of high interest rates on investment of all types. Here we have consistent, strong, persuasive and effective criticism of the whole economic strategy that is evident in the Government's Budget. The Reserve Bank says, in what is clearly a criticism of the failure of the Budget to address the need for structural change:

Australia needs a major shift of resources into the traded goods sector to stimulate increased exports and, more importantly, to replace imports. This cannot be achieved if domestic demand is growing faster than productive capacity but simply slowing demand is not enough either.

That is one of the problems with this Government's economic policies. It has set out to slow demand and to clobber the corporate sector with additional taxes of $1.4 billion this year at a time when it is supposed to be helping invest Australia out of its problems. The report states:
There is also a need for greater productive capacity, improved productivity and a better overall price performance, at least as good as our competitors.

They are the Reserve Bank's priorities, and those priorities do not appear at all in the Government's Budget brought down this week. No attention has been paid to those problems; they are not addressed. Yet the Reserve Bank says they are top priorities. It says there is a need for greater productive capacity, improved productivity and a greater overall price performance. It is almost as if the report were written by members of the Opposition as part of our economic policy because these are exactly the sorts of policies that we have been encouraging the Government to adopt-policies that will bring economic recovery, not the sort of economic disaster, massive interest rates, worsening debt and higher overseas interest payments that are a direct result of this Government's deliberate economic policies, particularly deliberate pre-election economic policies. The Bank goes on to state:
We need also, if possible, to fund a greater proportion of investment from our own resources and not by borrowing abroad . . .

In other words, we need more savings and less consumption. The Senate is certainly well aware of that fact. For many years the Opposition has been stressing the need for an increase in savings and for policies that encourage such increased savings. The Reserve Bank report also notes:
. . . income moderation must continue to be pursued in the interests of lower inflation and the increased competitiveness of our goods and services.

We have to see to what extent the Government will provide that vital lead because in the Budget we saw a threat of further increased costs to employers, certainly by way of additional superannuation costs. In particular, there are the increased costs of $1.4 billion as a result of fiddling with the timing arrangements of corporate tax payments so that businesses will be paying tax on profits they have not yet received. Senator Watson's question at Question Time today was very perceptive, but Senator Button's answer revealed the depths of the Government's incompetence in this area. Apparently it had not struck the Government that when businesses deal in 30, 60, 90 or 180 day terms they do not even have the money in on which they have illegally made a profit. Yet they are required to pay tax to this Government and have to borrow the money, at the huge interest rates this Government's policies have brought about, to pay the tax on profits they have not yet received.

TALK.START.PARA: —What is that going to do to consumer prices?

—Exactly. In order to satisfy the Government's window- dressing of its phoney $9 billion surplus, it is pushing increased prices on to the consumer and increased costs on to business-that includes small business. It is doing exactly the opposite to what it should be doing, at least according to the policy objectives set out by the Reserve Bank. The Reserve Bank then states:

SPEECH.PARA: The setting of incentives and disincentives at the microeconomic level has played a role in creating some of our present economic imbalances. Changes there are essential-
the Bank does not say `preferred'-
if we are to avoid a re-emergence in the next upswing of problems of the past year, but the vital key is inflation.

The vital key is inflation, which will get worse this year because of this Government's incompetence. It is essential that we have changes at the micro-economic level, and none are brought about in this Budget-none at all. So the two matters that are essential and vital, the Government does nothing about. The Reserve Bank continues:
Restructuring is much more difficult, even impossible, in a high inflation environment which destroys competitiveness and discourages saving. Altering this situation must have top priority.
What priority has it in the Budget?

TALK.START.PARA: —Zero.

—As my colleague from Tasmania says: `Zero'. The Reserve Bank talks about things that should have top priority, that are vital and essential, and they have not been addressed in this Budget that has been presented to us. It is a window-dressing Budget, a phoney Budget, a massive tax Budget, an attempt to buy votes Budget, but is it a restructuring Budget? Not on your life. Is it a Budget to reduce inflation? Do not believe it. Is it a Budget to provide incentives to business? Not on your life; business gets taxed more and has to pay higher interest bills. All the issues that the Reserve Bank annual report raises this Government has either ducked or done a disservice to. This Reserve Bank report is a very timely reminder to us all of how vital it is to maintain the independence of the Reserve Bank, an independence from the Treasurer's influence over it. I must say that I commend the former Governor, Mr Bob Johnston, for his continued and determined stand for independence.
—The Treasurer says, `They do as I say'.

—Senator Stone says that the Treasurer asserts that they do as he says. I am glad that Mr Johnston, in his farewell annual report-I presume that he had some influence over it-has been prepared to declare the Bank's independence at least by way of public comment. If there is any diminution of the sort of spirit that allows a Reserve Bank to tell the Government how incompetent it is-because that is what this Reserve Bank report does-and how misdirected its policies are, if there is any reduction of that independence under this arrogant Treasurer who seeks to assert that dominance, then I believe that we are facing an even more serious problem because it is only by public airing of these policy disagreements within the arms of advice to government that we can get a fair and reasonable view of the extent of this Government's incompetence despite the best advice.

SPEECH.PARA: It is also vital that members of parliament also have access to this kind of comment so that we and the people of Australia can judge what sort of advice this Government is rejecting when it goes on with economic policies that have brought us to economic disaster, that are forcing people out of their homes because of huge interest rates, that are increasing costs to levels far higher than those of our trading partners, and that are pushing us further and further into debt internationally, for which this Government is directly responsible, as the Reserve Bank points out, despite the attempt by the Prime Minister to say that because the debt is largely from the private sector it does not matter.

This Government stands condemned by this document, this Budget stands condemned by this document, and if this arrogant Treasurer seeks to assert authority and control over the Reserve Bank, then I believe that Australia's economic management under a government such as this will get even worse.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Stone Sen J.O.

TALKER.NAME: Senator STONE
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise also to speak on the annual report for 1988-89 of the Reserve Bank of Australia. As my colleague Senator Michael Baume has just said, that document is a remarkable one. I have read a good many Reserve Bank annual reports during my time, and indeed I suppose participated in the preparation of five or six.
—As a director.

—As a director of the Board and a member of the Board ex officio. Normally it is fair to say that the Reserve Bank is noted for the caution-indeed some people might even say circumlocution-of its language. While that characteristic is true also of this report to a degree, nevertheless there are a number of most significant statements in this report relating to the conduct of policy, including particularly monetary policy, during the past year and to the future of the Government's economic policies as presently constituted. I think that those particular remarks gain added weight from the fact that the Reserve Bank has not in the past been noted for the total frankness of its language. One has always been able to find what it meant, but one has sometimes had to read between the lines to do so. There is no need to read between the lines in many aspects of this report today. Let us start with one or two comments of the bank on developments during 1989. On page 6 it is stated:

SPEECH.PARA: This package of policies-
the package I have just been describing-
produced a marked increase in investment spending in 1988-89.

We certainly have been aware of that. The Treasurer (Mr Keating) has emphasised that point at almost every press conference he has had during the past 12 months. He has been trying to explain to the increasingly sceptical journalists why it is that the balance of payments deficit for the month just past has, once again, hit a new record. The Treasurer has time and again referred in that connection to the large rise in investment spending in 1988-89. We all know that that is only a partial explanation, indeed not even the major explanation, of what has been happening; nevertheless the Treasurer has laid great emphasis upon it. Having acknowledged the fact that investment has risen significantly, the Reserve Bank goes on to say:
While much of the investment should contribute to future productive capacity, some of it. . .was in areas not especially oriented to increasing output in the traded goods sector.

In other words, it was directed to meeting Australian domestic consumption demands rather than to delivering an improvement in the balance of payments. After going on to comment about the rapid rise in the level of our current account deficit on the balance of payments, the bank notes:
Our international indebtedness rose in consequence, resuming the upward trend as a ratio to GDP that it had followed in the years up to 1986.
Now we come to the present. What is the current economic situation? The bank expresses the following view:
While the indicators are still mixed, the Bank believes the current setting of monetary policy-
monetary policy, mark you, not fiscal policy-
is now dampening growth of private demand. Higher interest rates gradually seem to be having an impact on all categories of spending.
It then goes on to say, and I think this passage was also quoted by my colleague Senator Michael Baume:
However, the general buoyancy of the economy has been such that rates may need to remain high for quite some time to achieve the desired effect.

That is not quite what the Treasurer has been saying in his Budget Speech and not quite what the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) has been saying at various breakfasts, dinners or other occasions that he has been attending since the Budget was delivered. The bank is not content to make that rather blunt statement. It goes on to warn the Government, stating:

The size of the task should not be underestimated. Inflation appears set to remain above the average for industrial countries, even if demand pressures are contained. The inevitable rise in debt servicing costs will add to the turnaround required in our trade performance if the current account deficit is to be reduced.

In a later passage in small print on page 13 of the report there is a further comment on that same point. The bank specifically again draws attention to the external debt servicing problem and, more generally, to the risks to which the Australian economy is presently being subjected. The passage states:

The external debt servicing burden increased, making the task of correcting the current account deficit position that much more difficult. The higher level of Australian dollar assets held overseas also adds to the potential for sharp movements in both the exchange rate and security yields in response to shifts in demand for such assets.

That, if I may say so, is an example of what I call Delphic Reserve Bank language. It means that we now have an economy which is extremely vulnerable to shifts in confidence on the part of overseas investors in this country. We are extremely vulnerable to such shifts in confidence and the shifts in hot money which can flow from those shifts in confidence. The bank goes on to say, on page 7:
Nevertheless, it is imperative-
I ask honourable senators to note the word `imperative'-not merely desirable or needful, but imperative-
that there be a return to progress on reducing both the rate of inflation and the current account deficit over the coming year. The Bank does not share the opinion-
and again my colleague has referred to this paragraph, but it is sufficiently important and authoritative to be worth quoting again, indeed more than once-
expressed in some quarters-
by that it means `expressed by the Prime Minister'-

that, since most of the debt is owed within the private sector rather than by government, it is a matter of little consequence. The extent to which resources must be diverted to its future servicing is the same whether the debt is publicly or privately owned, and the investment it has enabled will not automatically ensure that these resources are available.

What the Reserve Bank is saying there is rather like what the Treasurer, Mr Keating, said to, I think, an Australian Financial Review luncheon a few weeks ago in Sydney when he was referring to some ideas that the Prime Minister not long before had been putting into the public arena. He referred to these ideas as `simplistic nonsense'. He did not name them as actually having come from the Prime Minister, but we all knew who he was referring to. In the same way we all know who the Reserve Bank is referring to today in this document. It says it is simplistic nonsense. The bank has not used that term but that is what it means.
The Reserve Bank, again in expressing its view about the current course of policy, refers to the policy of keeping interest rates very high. It says:
This should, with a lag, cut into the demand for imports and thus the current account deficit. However, this is not the primary objective. In fact, in the short run-
It is now a rather long run; it is already 17 months old, having begun in April last year-
there may be perverse effects on the balance of payments if higher interest rates produce an exchange rate appreciation. Some of those effects were evident in 1988-89.
If I may say so, they are still evident. The bank has obviously felt sufficiently concerned about that matter to refer to it again, on page 11 of the report, where it says:
Tighter monetary policy, by slowing aggregate demand, will tend to slow imports.
That, we understand, is what the Government has been trying to produce-a slowing in imports. The bank goes on to say:
It also raises the cost of investment through higher interest rates and a higher-than-otherwise exchange rate, and thus tends to slow the likely growth of future productive capacity.

What that boils down to is that the bank is totally dissatisfied with this Government's unidimensional policy. It uses an exorbitantly high level of interest rates, which has been maintained now at an increasing level for the last 17 months, as the Government's only apparent instrument to deal with what it regards as the excessive demand in this country. The bank further states:
On its own, monetary policy will not produce the longer-term structural benefits Australia is seeking. Beyond the point-
and I would say that that point has been well and truly reached-
it may even inhibit the structural change because of the effect of high interest rates on investment of all types.

Yet what view was taken in the Budget Speech last Tuesday night to the existence of that clear and, by the bank at least, clearly perceived, threat? We have seen simply a policy of `Stay on course; steady as she goes'-or I should say, `Steady as she sinks'. There is to be `No change', the Treasurer has said, in the existing one dimensional higher and higher interest rate policy.

The bank goes on to note, as every analyst does, that we need a major shift of resources into the traded goods sector to stimulate increased exports and, more importantly, to replace imports. The bank says:
This cannot be achieved if domestic demand is growing faster than productive capacity-
but very significantly it adds:
but simply slowing demand is not enough either.

That is, of course, what this Government is doing at the present time. It is simply slowing demand by the application of crushing interest rates. The bank then touches upon a particularly sensitive point. It remarks:
The setting of incentives and disincentives at the microeconomic level has played a role in creating some of our present economic imbalances.

There is another example of what I call Reserve Bank Delphic language. What it is saying there is that at the micro-economic level-by which it means the price of labour-the setting of incentives and disincentives at that level has played a role in creating some of our present economic imbalances. It goes on to say:
Changes there are essential if we are to avoid a re-emergence in the next upswing of the problems of the past year, but the vital key is inflation.

Again I ask: What attention did our Treasurer give to that vital key, inflation, in his Budget Speech last Tuesday night?-apart from telling us that inflation this financial year would run at virtually precisely the same level as it ran in 1988-89; in other words, that inflation is stuck at 7 1/2 per cent, according to the Government's own forecast, for the year as a whole, and it does not even decline significantly during the course of the year, although the Government has been very keen to tell us that we should be focusing our attention on this occasion not upon the year on year averages but upon the way in which the economy is moving through the course of the year. Although the Government is very keen to direct our attention in that regard, apparently it is not displaying much eagerness to publish any information, such as quarterly breakdown of the national income forecasts, which will enable us to make those kinds of judgments. But we will see what Senator Walsh has to say on that tomorrow, by which time I have not the slightest doubt he would have had time to consult the Treasurer as a result of the question I addressed to him at Question Time today, at which time he said that he did not know whether such forecasts existed. I think he will find that they do exist. I am sure that, when he has satisfied himself on that point, he will be only too happy to bring them to the Senate for our information and the information of the general public, including the media.

TALK.START.PARA: —He doesn't give us the Forward Estimates any more.

—As Senator Baume has said, he does not give us the Forward Estimates any more. Nevertheless, I have much faith in Senator Walsh; I am not referring to the Treasurer; I am referring to Senator Walsh, the Minister for Finance. Undoubtedly, tomorrow he will bring those quarterly forecasts into the Senate for our better guidance.

SPEECH.PARA: I propose to conclude on this point: the Reserve Bank looks briefly ahead in one small paragraph. I will quote that paragraph, which appears on page 13 of the report, in full:
Retention of the present stance of policy-
of very high interest rates-

should produce more significant restraint of spending as 1989/90 progresses. Whether this will also be sufficient to lay the groundwork for winding back the current account deficit is uncertain; there are risks that it may not.

The Reserve Bank of Australia is talking about the retention of the present stance. It is not holding out the hope, the optimistic bauble which the Prime Minister is holding out to his listeners, that interest rates will come down. The Reserve Bank is saying:
Retention of the present stance of policy should produce more significant restraint of spending as 1989/90 progresses.
It goes on to say:
Whether this will also be sufficient to lay the groundwork for winding back the current account deficit is uncertain; there are risks that it may not.
The Reserve Bank concludes on this point:
These risks will be much greater if there is a substantial slowing of world growth and a decline in commodity prices.

I join my colleague Senator Michael Baume in expressing my gratitude to the present Board of the Reserve Bank of Australia, which no longer has on it Mr Bob Johnston-I think he retired in mid-July. The Reserve Bank is presently under the chairmanship of the Deputy Governor, Mr John Phillips, who, as we all know, was passed over for the position of Governor. I congratulate the Board for having produced, by Reserve Bank standards, this very frank account of Australia's problems and the unlikelihood of the present policies of this Government producing real and, above all, sustainable answers to those problems.
Debate (on motion by Senator Hill) adjourned.

DEBATE.TITLE: STANDING COMMITTEE ON APPROPRIATIONS AND STAFFING

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crichton-Browne Sen N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.

This is the 1988-89 annual report of the Senate Standing Committee on Appropriations and Staffing. I shall not detain the Senate for longer than a few minutes. The thrust of the report ought not to go unnoticed by honourable senators because it goes to the very heart of the processes of funding the activities of the Senate, its duties and responsibilities and the responsibilities of all its members. The Appropriations and Staffing Committee, of which I have the dubious distinction of being a member, met on five occasions during the year 1988-89 to determine its charter, the estimates and the additional estimates of the Department of the Senate for that year and for the purpose of considering any other matters relating to departmental administration.

Let me paraphrase from the report because it very much summarises what I want to say. The Committee, at its very first meeting for the year 1988-89, considered the processes by which the Minister for Finance, Senator Walsh-he is notorious for this-reduced the levels of funding for the Senate, or at least reduced the estimates proposed for the Department of the Senate. These had been determined by the unanimous vote of the Appropriations and Staffing Committee on 31 May 1988 in accordance with that Committee's terms of reference. Of course, I need not remind my informed colleagues that the Appropriations and Staffing Committee is made up of--

TALK.START.PARA: —Highly intelligent members.

—I was not going to say `highly intelligent members'; I was going to describe the parties but, to the extent that the honourable senator has reminded me, he is absolutely right. The Committee is made up of highly intelligent members of this chamber-senators from all political parties-and includes, ex officio, the Leader of the Government in the Senate, Senator Button. He is on the Committee presumably for the purpose of ensuring that the Government has a proper opportunity to consider the appropriations and, where the view of the Government ought to be put, that view is put by Senator Button. In the event that the Government considers that the appropriations being proposed are too high, Senator Button will proffer that opinion and demonstrate where he believes the appropriations can be properly reduced. Of course, that goes for all political parties.

SPEECH.PARA: That process was undertaken carefully and diligently by all present and the appropriations so arrived at were carried unanimously by resolution of 31 May. The Minister for Finance did not at that point, or at any material point immediately afterwards, suggest any substantial reductions in the estimates until very late in the procedure of determining the content of the Appropriation (Parliamentary Departments) Bill. In other words, the Committee, including the Government's representative, resolved a determination. Departmental officers from the Senate and from the Department of Finance had informal and formal negotiations outside those meetings and agreed to the levels of funding. On the very eve of the introduction of the Budget the Minister for Finance, capriciously and in a delinquent and irresponsible way, wrote to the Department unilaterally announcing that the appropriations would be reduced to the levels he judged to be sufficient for the proper functioning of the Senate. Let me remind the Senate of that Committee's responsibilities and its terms of reference. The report states inter alia:
(a) in relation to the Estimates-
(i) determine the amounts for inclusion in the Parliamentary Appropriation Bills for the Annual Estimates and the Additional Estimates, and
(ii) report to the Senate upon its determinations prior to the consideration by the Senate of the related Parliamentary Appropriation Bill;
(b) In relation to staffing-
(i) make such recommendation to the President as it sees fit, and
(ii) report to the Senate on any matter it considers necessary; and
(c) make an annual report to the Senate on the operations of the Senate's appropriations and staffing, and related matters-

which is the consequence of this report. In other words, the Senate has charged the Committee to determine the amounts for inclusion and that was done. The resolution of 2 December 1985 reinforced that reference. If my memory does not escape me, that resolution of 2 December 1985 was moved by Senator Richardson, who was the Chairman of the Committee and is now a member of the Government. The resolution was carried unanimously by the Senate. As I say, the report says that it envisaged the Department of the Senate's estimates should be-not could or might-those determined by the Standing Committee on Appropriations and Staffing. The resolution goes on to say, to paraphrase it, that any disagreement on the part of the Government, represented by the Minister for Finance, with the estimates determined by the Committee would be resolved by a process of discussion involving the President, the Standing Committee, the Leader of the Government in the Senate and the Minister for Finance. Due to the lateness of the hour in the Minister for Finance's correspondence, that process of course did not take place because it was impossible.

At its meeting on 2 March 1989 the Committee resolved, again unanimously, that Mr President should write, as Chairman of the Committee, to the Leader of the Government in the Senate regarding the importance of ministerial representation at Committee meetings at which the Department's estimates were being considered. That letter was written to ensure that never again would the Committee be confronted with correspondence by the Minister for Finance at the twelfth hour, unilaterally determining that the estimates should be less than those judged to be appropriate by the Committee. That mechanism would ensure that the Minister representing the Government and, presumably, the Minister for Finance-unless he stands outside the Government in these determinations-is in a position to proffer the views of the Government in respect of appropriate funding for the Senate. It was hoped, and certainly intended, that the Minister representing the Government would be properly informed, properly briefed and properly equipped with the views of the Government when he attended the meetings. It was hoped that that would avoid a repetition of events that took place in the previous year and would resolve irreconcilable differences of view between the Committee and the Government.

At meetings on 5 and 8 June 1989, the Leader of the Government in the Senate was represented by Senator Bolkus, the Minister for Consumer Affairs. Senator Bolkus advised the Committee that it would be his aim to represent the views of the Government in respect of the estimates of the Committee at the meeting. Senator Bolkus attended the meetings on 5 and 8 June and made a contribution. At those meetings the level of funding was, after very careful deliberation, determined unanimously by the Committee-with, as I say, Senator Bolkus in attendance.

I had hoped that the presence of the Minister would ensure that the level of appropriations as determined by the Appropriations and Staffing Committee would be the level to be appropriated. Although the matter has not been determined and it is inappropriate for me to enlarge upon the facts, difficulties have again surfaced. The Minister for Finance, Senator Walsh, has again conducted himself in the same way as he did the previous year. That ought to come as no shock to any member of this chamber, because when I raised the matter of the unanimous resolution in this chamber with Senator Walsh, which he supported and voted upon, he said, `Well, I voted for it because it was irrelevant, useless, a waste of time then, and it still is'. In other words, he was contemptuously dismissing the resolution of this chamber. We now find ourselves confronted with the same situation with the Minister for Finance corresponding with the Committee and arbitrarily seeking to make sharp cuts in the level of funding.

Without going into any detail, in the event of this matter not being resolved fairly and reasonably I hope that Appropriation Bill (No. 2) can be amended to contain a funding level which the Senate deems to be appropriate for its functioning and provide it with a capacity to fulfil the obligations with which it is charged. The Committee has bent over backwards to be frugal and careful in determining the level of funding, to the point, if my memory serves me correctly, without disclosing the activities of the private meetings, where with the assistance and initiative of the Opposition cuts have been made to the point where funding is now barely tolerable.

In respect of requests from the Minister for Finance to move certain items out of Appropriation Bill (No. 2) into Appropriation Bill (No. 1), in each case we have, with a caveat in one case, complied with the wishes of the Minister. Of course, the reason for moving those line items out of Appropriation Bill (No. 2) into Appropriation Bill (No. 1) is that one Bill can be amended and one cannot. I am quite sure that if Senator Walsh had his way he would have all the funding and appropriations for the Senate in a Bill which could not be amended. It will be over my dead body if that is unanimously agreed to in this chamber.

It is to be hoped that this Government will act with decency, and if not with decency with common sense, in respect to funding for the Senate for this coming year. Sadly, this Government has got a long, miserable record of seeking to reduce the funding of the Parliament per se and the Senate in particular to the point now where the view of three political parties represented in this chamber is that it is not fulfilling its obligations to the level it ought simply because of a reduction in funding. We know the regard in which this chamber is held by Senator Walsh and a number of his colleagues. That has been demonstrated by their endeavours to introduce Bills into the Parliament to amalgamate the Department of the Senate with other departments so that we have one super department, no doubt having the Speaker as the titular head dancing to the tune of the Executive Government. When the Executive Government manages and controls the Parliament one no longer has an independent parliament. One no longer has a parliament able to make determinations and decisions and arrive at conclusions free and unfettered; rather one has a parliament bending, dancing and bowing to the wishes of a government, which is bound to cast it into disrespect and simply make it a rubber stamp for the Government.

TALK.START.PARA: —You're talking about the Westminster system, I hope you remember.

—To the extent that we reflect the Westminster system, I am talking about it. But it is not a system that seems to suit the Minister's sort of government. If this Government had its way it would simply have the Parliament rubber stamping its determinations and decisions. The very fact that it guillotines legislation through the House of Representatives prior to the conclusion of proper and exhaustive debate demonstrates the lack of regard it has for the processes and forms of parliament. The only reason why the Senate conducts itself with some pretence of freedom, democracy and single spirit is that the Government does not have the numbers in the chamber. If the Government had the numbers in the chamber without doubt any Bill which was difficult, controversial and took time to deliberate would be guillotined. If this Government had the numbers we would not have had the fulsome and healthy debate we had on matters such as the identity card, the Bill of Rights and all those other obnoxious pieces of legislation which the Government in its subtle and surreptitious way sought to slip through the Parliament without the public noticing and without the attention and diligent application of senators.

SPEECH.PARA: I conclude by saying that I hope that when the next annual report of the Senate Standing Committee on Appropriations and Staffing is tabled it will show that there has been proper cooperation and contribution by the Government in determining levels of funding for this chamber which are appropriate and necessary.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Burns Sen B.R

TALK.START.PARA: —In accordance with the provisions of the Public Works Committee Act I present the following report: Construction of Facilities for 2nd Cavalry Regiment, Darwin. I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard a short tabling statement.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The statement read as follows-

The report I have just presented relates to the construction of facilities for the relocation of the 2nd Cavalry Regiment from Holsworthy near Sydney to Darwin at an estimated cost of $62.7m at December 1988 prices. The proposal comprises the construction of new barracks and training facilities for the 2nd Cavalry Regiment on a new site at Palmerston, approximately 20 kilometres east of Darwin, upgrading of existing administrative support facilities at Larrakeyah Barracks in Darwin and construction of new ammunition storage facilities at RAAF Base Darwin. In recommending to the Parliament that the proposal proceed the Committee has drawn attention to the following:
the need for a dedicated water supply main for the barracks site to be installed by November 1989 to eliminate water cartage cost penalties;

the need for the Defence Housing Authority to have further consultations regarding the details of its strategy for meeting the housing requirements of the 2nd Cavalry Regiment including the amount of housing to be provided in the Palmerston area;

the need for Defence to give consideration to the provision of a permanent community facility for Defence families in Darwin and that in the interim it makes available a more suitable facility at Larrakeyah Barracks for community purposes.
I commend the report to the Senate.

DEBATE.TITLE: OPERATION OF THE FISHING INDUSTRY RESEARCH ACT 1969

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 25 May, on motion by Senator Archer:
That the Senate take note of the paper.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Calvert Sen P.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak briefly on paper No. 1, the operation of the Fishing Industry Research Act 1969, on which I intended to speak on 25 May. Unfortunately, this is the first opportunity we have had to discuss this matter. I would like to make a few points. I want to draw the attention of the Senate to the significant contribution which has been made by Tasmania in the field of fisheries research. As most of us would know, the fishing industry has been of vital importance to Tasmania for many years. I am very proud to say that Tasmanian scientists and other professionals working in the field have established a worldwide reputation for the quality of their research work and the products themselves.

SPEECH.PARA: For some time Tasmania has fostered a very valuable export industry. These days when we need to bring in export dollars it is good to see that we have an industry that is growing quite quickly. It is not uncommon to find Tasmanian seafood products in such destinations as the United States, Japan and Asia. During a trip by a parliamentary delegation to Asia last year I was very pleased to hear that importers were very impressed by the high quality of products being exported by our fledgling aquaculture industry, particularly products such as Atlantic salmon, Pacific oysters and trout.

The report notes that Tasmania was allocated $1,787,703 during 1987-88. It spelt out a further allocation of $2,523,048. This represents a figure of something like $4.3m. I am sure that in research terms it is money very well spent. It will enhance a very major growth industry in our State. There are numerous projects outlined in the report. I refer in particular to work that has been done in the scallop industry. Many Tasmanians would know that unfortunately our scallop industry has been decimated by overfishing. Research work has been done into receding scallop beds in the State. Similarly, research has been undertaken by the tuna fishing industry on the movement of tuna, which will benefit the Tasmanian industry.

The matter I am really concerned about relates to the orange roughy situation. In 1987-88 an amount of $170,000 was spent to determine the size of the orange roughy resource on the continental slope and to estimate the potential sustainable yield for orange roughy. For those who are not aware, at present on the east coast of Tasmania, off St Helens in particular, two new hot spots, as they are called, have been established. Very large catches of orange roughy are being taken. Unfortunately, research to date has shown that these hot spots occur when the fish are spawning. This leads one to believe that fishing when they are spawning will reduce the resource. I am very concerned that we do not know enough about these fish at this stage. There is a real risk that they will be overfished and decimated, as have been our other fishing industries over the years. When we see boats being able to harvest between $250,000 and half a million dollars worth of fish in a day, we can understand how quickly this industry can be devastated by pure greed. Something should be done to further research so that perhaps the resource can be maintained.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.TITLE: INDUSTRIAL RELATIONS (DIRECTIONS TO STOP INDUSTRIAL ACTION) AMENDMENT BILL 1989

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 16 August, on motion by Senator Chaney:
That this Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Aulich Sen T.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to oppose the Industrial Relations (Directions to Stop Industrial Action) Amendment Bill 1989 and to indicate quite clearly that the Government regards this Bill as, first of all, an unnecessary measure and, secondly, a measure that could cause more problems than it is intended that it solve. It is predictable because this is not the first time that Senator Chaney or other Opposition spokesmen in the industrial relations area have pursued this particular course. The course that the Opposition has basically been pursuing and is suggesting that the Government take is that of enforcing compliance in the industrial relations arena, separating industrial relations from the prevailing governmental ethos and the social and political ethos that surround it, simply turning it into another aspect of the law.

SPEECH.PARA: The solutions that the Opposition has been advocating over a long time have centred on the need to use the law to enforce compliance, as the Opposition puts it, upon both parties in any industrial dispute. Yet Opposition members know full well that in any industrial dispute the advantage necessarily accrues to the group which, first of all, has legality on its side and, secondly, is in the box seat. That box seat in most industrial disputes is generally held by the employer in the sense that employee organisations and individual employees have nothing to negotiate with but their labour. That labour can be withdrawn: that is the only weapon they have. I will return to that point later because it relates very much to some of the provisions laid down in Senator Chaney's Bill.

This Bill, to put it colloquially, has a very cute title, just as a number of the provisions contained in it could be described as cute. But the Opposition is covering up for a very hard line taken on industrial relations matters. Some very hard solutions are being propounded by the spokesman that occupies the industrial relations chair for the Opposition. It is not the first time that the Liberal Party of Australia has pushed this particular line. It is in fact an overreaction to a significant industrial dispute.

One recalls during the Fraser period when the Liberal Party and the National Party of Australia were in government that there were a number of industrial disputes-single, one-off disputes. For one reason or another, probably related to vote buying or vote getting, the government of that day decided to bring in what it regarded as important or emergency legislation. The net result was that that proposed legislation did not get through this Parliament, was irrelevant to solving a particular industrial dispute or, in some cases, was embedded in an ever growing Conciliation and Arbitration Act or in the Trade Practices Act. That did nothing to help provide a better industrial relations climate in this country. As with economic and taxation measures, the Fraser Government for a very long time sought to fiddle with the Conciliation and Arbitration Act and other Acts relating to industrial relations in this country, usually stimulated by one significant dispute. The Fraser Government would pick a dispute which made the press at the time, in which there was some concern by the public and probably by all members of parliament, and use that as an excuse to try to change the framework. We ended up with an Act that was in many ways unworkable, complex and subject to challenge in the courts and in the field.

Once again the Liberal Party brings forward its traditional approach to industrial relations, as embodied in the Bill. The Liberal Party is wrong in more than the specifics of the way the Bill is set out. The approach of the Liberal Party to industrial relations as a whole is wrong. Its basic mistake is that it has not learned from the past. Senator Chaney, of all people, should have learned from the mistakes that he and his Government made when they were in office. I know that Senator Chaney is very touchy about any mention of his term as a Cabinet Minister in the past failed Fraser Government. He usually takes a point of order when it is mentioned. I think even he is bored with his Bill. Senator Chaney has some problems not only in taking an active interest in his Bill, but also even in getting people to come and listen to him speak at dinners about industrial relations. That is how irrelevant the Liberal Party's approach to industrial relations has become.

To get back to the point I made, it is not that the Liberal Party is technically wrong in the amendments it may want to make to the Industrial Relations Act. It is just that it does not understand that industrial relations is part of an integrated activity that bears upon a number of areas of Australian society: inflation, social welfare and pensions, taxation, and employment are all part of the industrial relations arena or are interwoven with the industrial relations system. When the Government came to power it did not seek to make minor and ad hoc amendments to the Conciliation and Arbitration Act. It said to the unions and to the employers, `We have to take a new look at industrial relations in this country'. What we write in the Bill as it comes through Parliament is only part of the picture. What we create by way of an understanding or a prevailing ethos in the community is much more important. We are talking, first, about the prevailing ethos and, secondly, about the way in which people act in accordance with the spirit of the law. Thirdly, we are talking about the degree to which all parties in industrial relations consider the interests not only of themselves but also of the whole community.

This ad hoc amendment to legislation that has been passed only within the last 12 months or so is an example of the Liberal approach which is to play around with the law and not seek to create a new ethos in the community. Its approach does not seek to get cooperation, but to punish. We must have learnt from experience, through industrial relations history, that enforced compliance with the law or with the spirit of good industrial relations is not the solution because, in the end, industrial relations is not just about bargaining between employers and employee organisations. It is not just about enforcing compliance with some agreements or awards. It is about the understanding that people have that they are operating in the interests not only of the people whom they represent, but also of the whole community. I know that some people on the Opposition side of the chamber believe that that is the appropriate way to go in industrial relations. Many say that there has to be give and take.

We cannot write industrial relations Acts in the way we can Acts that can be interpreted in other jurisdictions, for example, equity law or other areas of the law where the black-letter is absolutely necessary. Many Opposition senators have that view. Unfortunately, the decline of Ian Macphee in the Liberal Party has indicated symbolically that the Liberal Party has been hijacked by people who will take a harder line on industrial relations, people who are the New Right radicals. Perhaps in some ways the influence in the community of such people has waned in terms of their capacity to sell their theories and ideas. It has not waned within the structure of the Liberal Party. This Bill is very much an example of the approach that has been taken by these Old Right or New Right radicals.

Senator Chaney was made the shadow Minister for industrial relations in an attempt by those forces further to the right than the average person in the community to put a passable front on their extreme approach to the solution of industrial relations in this country. They thought, `Here's a gentleman; here's a man with a reasonable image; here's a man who during his time as Minister for Aboriginal Affairs showed that he could talk to people and knew what consensus was about'. Here was a man who was known as Red Fred, slightly left of centre, a Minister who was prepared to take on his Prime Minister over a number of issues, for example, those related to Aboriginals. He was a man with a reasonable left of centre image. Members of the Liberal Party thought that by putting him in this position they could then help to sell a much more extreme view of industrial relations than the Australian community would otherwise have tolerated.

I sincerely hope the Bill is not all Senator Chaney's own work. Senator Chaney has to take advantage of one industrial dispute which he knows will upset the Australian community if and when it goes into full operation some time this weekend, that is, the airlines dispute. He has taken that one dispute and his solution has been to whack another Bill through Parliament. This has to be the most ham-fisted approach ever taken towards solving an industrial dispute or towards creating a better climate to ensure that such disputes do not occur. It has to be the most ham-fisted attempt I have seen to head off a dispute and then to create a better climate.

There is every evidence that the Government, the Opposition, and the Australian community will not tolerate the banditry of the airline pilots. None of us in this chamber will tolerate people who, first, are so naive or, second, so aggressive about pursuing their aims that they cannot understand that times have changed around them. No-one in this chamber will accept the approach that they are taking.

I was interested the other day to hear that one of the airline pilot officials indicated that he and his union would be seeking equity only with judges and politicians. I was with two or three politicians at the time when I heard that come over the news. We calculated that in order for the airline pilots to get equity with us in this chamber, they would need to drop about $25,000 to $30,000 a year in salary. That is how naive they are. I have indicated that their naivety is also shown by the fact that they do not understand that industrial relations in this country has changed-and significantly-for the better. It has changed in terms of the number of man-hours lost through industrial disputes and the responsible approach that the trade union movement has taken in looking at the interests of the total economy and the total community when it takes action and pursues its long-term goals and also in terms of the way the employers have responded to the consultation process that this Government has opened to all bodies in the industrial relations arena, bar the extremists who want to blow the whole system apart.

It is not a perfect system. Industrial relations is primarily about negotiation. A negotiation that ends perfectly is one I have yet to see. The industrial relations arena is not a court of law; it is an arena that can be messy, where there are long-term consequences that sometimes flow upon bad decisions being taken where there are problems right in front of people. For example, every one of us here in this chamber can make decisions about changes that were made to section 45 of the Trade Practices Act and changes to various other provisions that flow from that. We could all make a decision about whether or not the moves that were made by the Fraser Government or the decisions that were made by this Government in relation to section 45d were appropriate. We can ask, `Did those changes work? Were they appropriate?'. The answer is that nobody really knows. We can say, for example, that the Mudginberri disputes had an effect. We know that certain unions that had been a little more likely than others to lead with their chin, and occasionally engage in industrial disputes which were not in the interests either of the community or of their own members on some occasions, learned a lesson and that the responsible unions around this country said, very quietly-in some cases publicly-`Mudginberri is a lesson to us'.

In some ways I am not even pushing aside the viewpoint that has been expressed by members of the New Right. They had their viewpoints on particular disputes and taught us that in the end the worst possible thing to do to improve industrial relations in this country is to get people into the courts and the common law system. That is the worst possible way for people to go if, first, we are going to solve individual disputes on the whole or, second, we are going to create a climate of industrial relations harmony that helps us as a country to maintain a reasonable reputation.

I was in Japan in 1987. I met the former Japanese Prime Minister, Mr Suzuki, a number of Japanese unions and some of the important business people in the Japanese community. One comment they had to make about their perception of Australia under the Hawke Labor Government concerned what they described as the dramatic improvement in industrial relations in this country. They said that it was such an improvement that it actually affected decisions that they were making about investment and joint ventures; it affected their long-term views about investment in Australia. That was the view of members of a society which, on the whole, does not have much time for unions-all appearances to the contrary.

Amongst many of our trading partners and people in the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development who have looked objectively at the labour relations situation in this country there is nothing but praise for the dramatic improvement that the Hawke Government has brought about in the industrial relations area. I would never be the first to say that our record is perfect but at least we have been the first government to have taken industrial relations and put it in the public arena. We have put it into the public forums of this country and said, `Industrial relations is a broad activity; it is not just wages and conditions or bargaining between employers and employees. It has to do with the whole ethos of the way a nation looks at work, handles its tax system and social welfare system and the way people live'. Industrial relations is not to do with the 40-odd per cent of people who belong to trade unions or the thousands of businesses and business organisations that belong to their peak councils in the business area. It is not their province to run industrial relations as a club; industrial relations belongs to the whole community.

The whole community has an interest in industrial relations; therefore what counts is the ethos that is created in the whole community and the understanding that is created about the way people ought to look at work, the way we get governments and unions to cooperate with employers in long-term strategies for this country, not these minor ad hoc amendments to the Industrial Relations Act, which went through this Parliament only last year. That is not how we solve industrial relations problems. As compelled as members of the Opposition may be to gather votes out of a dispute which they know--

TALK.START.PARA: —What did Willis say in 1987?

—I am not listening to Senator Chaney just as half the business community of Western Australia did not want to go and listen to him. I will make my comments and he will make his. This is his Bill; he will get the opportunity to talk about it. This scrappy piece of paper, this rather scruffy piece of thinking, is the Liberal Party's approach to industrial relations. Why? Because there is a dispute which may escalate this weekend and leave people stranded in airports. An irresponsible trade association, against the wishes of the majority of the trade union movement, has decided that it will tell the Government and the employers to get lost. It has decided that it will tell the Australian community that it will take what it wants for its members regardless of whether its demands in any way are justified in the current economic climate on any work value basis, comparative wage justice basis or any other basis that has been used as a measurement for gaining increases in wages and conditions in this country over the last decade. This Government does not support this union or tolerate its viewpoint, but we are not prepared to look for this so-called easy solution: whack another Bill through Parliament.
—Willis promised he would enact this.

—They ought to call him Bill Chaney! He believes that this bit of paper is going to solve this industrial relations dispute and improve industrial relations, on the whole, throughout this country. If he believes that, he is as naive as Tony Street, Ian Macphee, Andrew Peacock and Ian Viner. They were the four industrial relations Ministers who came in, walked around for a while in the industrial relations arena under Fraser and then went down the chute again, leaving behind them a legacy of similar sorts of amendments and an industrial relations situation that was in absolute tatters. It was the joke not only of the rest of the world but even of the business community in this country. Those people left the economy in tatters, with inflation and unemployment sitting up at 11 per cent. Even now they do not have the decency to understand and acknowledge that one of the strong points of this Government, one of the most productive activities that this Government has been involved in, has been the creation of a better industrial relations situation. It is not perfect but it is certainly something that has worked beyond the dreams of anyone who in 1983 thought that the accord would bring long-term intelligence into the industrial relations arena, at a time at which intelligence had gone out of the window. We were left with an appalling industrial relations situation when we came to government in this country.
—It is the most stupid, ignorant speech I have ever heard.

—Senator Chaney, who at that stage was probably doing a good job up in the Pilbara talking to Aboriginals about sacred sites and basically keeping out of Fraser's way, was never in a situation, as I was, where he sat and listened to the business community as a group during conference after conference. That business community was saying to people like Viner, `This is a disgrace. This country is being ruined and you, as Minister for Industrial Relations, are either doing too little too late or coming up with amendments to inappropriate Acts, and you are going to go'. If I heard that once I heard it probably 20 or 30 times around this country in the period 1981 to 1982.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Chaney says this is an ignorant speech. I am fascinated to know what Senator Chaney has to give us in this chamber beyond this scrap of paper-a scrap of paper which, for example, allows people to take action three years after the event, which allows disputes, bad blood, vendettas to remain in the system long after a dispute has been solved. If that is his approach, then I suggest that Senator Chaney, before he leaves this chamber, try to patch up his reputation, try to get back the reputation he used to enjoy before he went into this particular-

TALK.START.PARA: —This is an ignorant speech.

—Madam Acting Deputy President, is it not intriguing? This man, who is known as the moderate gentleman, is sitting opposite me with nothing but abuse. Here is a man who brings in a Bill, cannot bear to listen to criticism of the Bill and his approach, and resorts to abuse. One day Senator Chaney will be out of this House. He will have some time in the House of Representatives--
—That is not certain either.

—Some time, if he gets another safe seat. I suggest that he take that time to sit down and talk to a few people in Australia about industrial relations. He should talk to some of the people who sit to his right, trying to force on him particular viewpoints and approaches to industrial relations. He should be his own man before he leaves this chamber. It might be good for him. It might be good for the Opposition. It might be very good indeed for this Parliament if we could lift the level of debate about industrial relations. Instead of having to deal with a Bill such as this, why do we not have from Senator Chaney a position paper about industrial relations which sets out his total approach? Let us debate that, but for heaven's sake, Senator Chaney should not come here on the eve of a major dispute, hand us a slip of paper and say, `This is the solution'. If he thinks that is the solution he ought to be moved to another shadow portfolio. I oppose the Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McLean Sen P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Industrial Relations (Directions to Stop Industrial Action) Amendment Bill grasps the political opportunity created by current industrial actions of pilots to make the point that there are inadequate compliance provisions in the Industrial Relations Act 1988. While that is a reasonable point to make, the irony of the situation is that the compliance provisions introduced into the 1987 version of the Industrial Relations Bill could have been used today if the Opposition and employers had supported the 1987 provisions instead of putting pressure on the Government to drop them. The 1987 Bill also spelt out what penalties would apply for non-compliance with the directives of the Industrial Relations Commission. The Bill before us today leaves the magnitude of penalties open-ended-an inadequacy which the Australian Democrats cannot accept.

SPEECH.PARA: One of the most contentious aspects of the 1988 Industrial Relations Act is the extent of the powers of the Commission. Some employers argued that the powers of the Commission were too expansive and trouble would flow from too broad a definition of the Commission's powers. They complained, as was argued by the Opposition in the debate in relation to the 1988 Act, that the Commission created by the Act would prove to be an even more all-embracing institution than the one it replaced. It is still feared that the Act will undermine the possibility of a shift to the enterprise level. The Opposition is now trying to give the Commission more power and also increase the power of employers in relation to their employees.

It is interesting to note in this context that recent national wage case decisions have included in wage increases some direct negotiations between employers and employees to implement productivity and restructuring trade-offs. We believe that is still likely to be the future path of the industrial relations scene in Australia. It is working at the moment because it has the imprimatur of the Commission. To reduce the powers of the Commission now and to throw all negotiations on to the employer and employee at enterprise level, which the coalition would still like to achieve, would be a radical lurch away from the path we are already travelling with much success. Such a radical move would endanger this success. It would create industrial relations chaos, which would undermine our international trading position. Surely an evolutionary process that is working is preferable to that.

It is not surprising that employers tend to regard existing compliance provisions, such as stand-down provisions, as not good enough. It is similarly not surprising that unions regard the existing compliance procedures as being too tough on unions. In the 1987 Industrial Relations Bill, to satisfy employers' demands the Government proposed a new directions and injunctions process with higher monetary penalties for non-compliance. It also introduced a more efficient process for resolving secondary boycotts before sanctions were necessary. That Bill had the virtue of pleasing neither of the major combatants, which was probably a reasonable indicator that it hit the right spot. The Australian Democrats indicated then that they were prepared to support that legislation; however, the Government withdrew it before the 1987 election.

The Opposition Bill now before us is designed to introduce a compliance system which is heavily weighted towards employers but which does not have a complementary list of penalties for non-compliance. I do not believe that all employers would welcome this as the reaction of the unions would create industrial chaos. I understand that the Opposition must attempt to woo back to its fold business people who increasingly prefer a Labor Government to the ideology of the New Rightists who have hijacked the Liberal-National Party leadership. Their amendments cannot be seen as a constructive addition to a sensible industrial relations policy. Even the Australian Council of Trade Unions was reluctantly prepared to support the compliance provisions in the 1987 Bill in return for legislation to bring sections 45d and 45e of the Trade Practices Act into the Industrial Relations Act. As I said, the Democrats indicated to the Government their willingness to support those provisions. The Liberal and National parties, however, opposed this. As a result, the Government announced early in the 1987 election campaign that it would drop from the 1987 Bill the compliance provisions and the proposal to bring sections 45d and 45e of the Trade Practices Act into the Industrial Relations Bill, which it eventually enacted in the Parliament in 1988.

The Democrats agree that this is an area which is sadly inadequate in the field of industrial relations. We would welcome discussions with the Opposition and the Australian Labor Party with a view to reintroducing into the industrial relations legislation some form of a balanced range of compliance and penalty provisions which were dropped from the 1987 Bill. That would be a sensible way of addressing the problem. We are not, however, inclined to support a piece of political grandstanding designed to make a cheap political point and likely to hinder, rather than help, the current situation with the pilots.
The 1987 Industrial Relations Bill included a directions process quite fundamentally different to the process proposed by the Opposition at the time and espoused by the Bill before us today.

During the committee stage of the Industrial Relations Bill, the Opposition moved to include in the Bill a directions process involving directions being given by the Commission and injunctions for breaches or attempted breaches of such directions, with the ability to make applications to the court for damages resulting from any breach. This bears some similarity to the proposal before us today, and it is useful to look at the reaction at the time of the Government to that amendment. The Government gave several reasons for opposing the amendments suggested by the Opposition, in particular the vague nature of the wording, and the fact that the proposed scheme might delay the availability of remedies for industrial action because there is a clear risk that enforcement proceedings in the court could undermine attempts by the Commission to resolve the underlying industrial issues. Given the severity of the remedies and the lack of a sensible process of cooling-off, it would be understandable if the Commission and employers treated directions as a process of last resort and were reluctant to use them for fear of inflaming a dispute. These problems are equally evident in this legislation.

The wording of the proposed section 187a, such as `impending' and `probable', is likely to incite rather than resolve conflict. The wide interpretation possible would not promote stability in the field of industrial relations. Similarly, the term `such directions as it thinks possible' would be open to very wide interpretation and could be used to impede the operation of small businesses and trade unions. Section 187c would enable a person to sue an individual involved in an industrial dispute carried out in breach of section 187a and which has resulted in loss or damage. This provides the opportunity for any one individual to be isolated and victimised because of loss or damages arising from an industrial dispute. That individual could be sued by members of the public and such legislation could bring a small business to its knees or destroy a trade union official. The ability to sue three years after the loss or damage has occurred virtually places into the legislation automatic retrospectivity once this provision is accepted by the Parliament, and one involved in industrial disputes over the previous three years would be liable to be sued.

Although the Opposition is making a political point by bringing about a debate on this Bill now, it is unlikely that a parliamentary debate based on the pilots industrial dispute now will be at all helpful. It is more likely to inflame and encourage industrial unrest rather than be conducive to providing a settlement. I believe at the moment, at least temporarily, the pilots are complying with the directives of the Industrial Relations Commission. Perhaps they do not intend to continue to do so. Pilots are, of course, a powerful union because so few people are trained to do their job, and it is one which many of us find convenient, if not essential, to make use of. Strangely enough, what the pilots are doing in this dispute is engaging in free collective bargaining. They are, in effect, doing what the Opposition theoretically wants every employee to do under the coalition's industrial relations grand plan-to reach agreement with their employers outside the guidelines of a centralised industrial relations system.

It can be reasonably argued that the pilots dispute brings into focus the effects of that alternative model. We are experiencing the industrial chaos of a type that the Opposition industrial relations policy may possibly inflict on Australia. We are facing a wages breakout because of this industrial action. We are facing the realities of increasing strike action and the massive inconvenience this will cause. We are facing a decline in our tourism industry-an industry which earns foreign currency for Australia, and which has already been damaged by this dispute. All of this is likely to get worse rather than to get better.

In short, the Opposition's position on industrial relations has been and still is extraordinarily inconsistent and contradictory. The Opposition's response in this Bill is to give to the Industrial Relations Commission-which it wants to abolish-the power to enforce its decisions on a group that is engaging in the very process of collective bargaining which is the centrepiece of the Opposition's industrial relations policy. If the Opposition had acted sensibly instead of playing politics in 1987, or if the Government had proceeded with the 1987 legislation, the Commission would have had compliance provisions to use today. But the Opposition does not appear to be interested in a workable industrial relations system which can help resolve disputes without grave disruption to the economy. It is potentially inflaming the situation in making a political point which is inconsistent with its own industrial relations alternative model. This inconsistency is an important one. Today Senator Chaney has on his Napoleon hat. He is ready to inflict unspecified penalty, under the provisions of this Bill, on those who want higher wages. At other times, wearing his John Stuart Mill hat, he talks of free collective bargaining and espouses the liberty of individuals to make decisions without legislative direction. What does the coalition stand for in the industrial relations field? Does it stand for a centralised system, a decentralised system, both, or neither, or perhaps no system at all?

This is the second Opposition attack on the industrial relations system we have seen in this chamber in the three days we have been sitting this session. Could Opposition senators too be playing in the pre-election political games of which they have today so disparagingly accused both the Government and the Democrats? Of course they are. The Democrats will not be supporting this Bill. We would, however, as I have said, welcome discussions with the Opposition and the Government about the introduction into our industrial relations legislation of a set of sensible, balanced and comprehensive compliance provisions, with attached and understood penalties.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chapman Sen H.G.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —The inadequacies in the compliance provisions of the Industrial Relations Act have been highlighted on numerous occasions by the Opposition. Quite contrary to what Senator Aulich claimed in his remarks earlier today, the reintroduction of this legislation is not an overreaction to a particular dispute. There have in fact been a number of like disputes over recent years which highlight the need for more effective compliance legislation. Quite simply, there is no effective mechanism under the Act to make those who seek to take advantage of our industrial relations system effectively subject to it. Senator Aulich should remember that this is the third occasion in less than two years that the Opposition has introduced legislation to establish effective compliance provisions. So it is not simply in reaction to this current dispute that we have introduced the Industrial Relations (Directions to Stop Industrial Action) Amendment Bill. We have introduced it on two previous occasions because over a period of years we have recognised the inadequacies of the present situation.

SPEECH.PARA: While there may be a current dispute involving the airline pilots, as I said at the outset, over the past couple of years we have seen numerous examples of like disputes.
