Strong economic growth, sustainable increases in real wages, and improved living standards can only come from increased productivity. That is best achieved by a co-operative and flexible approach within individual enterprises. Our proposal to allow negotiation of voluntary agreements is an important step in this direction.

2.2 As part of making the system of determining wages and conditions of employment more flexible, where employers and their employees agree, they will be free to have wages and conditions of employment determined by an agreement between them instead of by an award. Agreements may take into account such factors as regional economic conditions, the availability of labour and the recognition of skills.
2.3 We will actively encourage the making of voluntary agreements. Such agreements will assist in developing a common purpose between employer and employees, for the benefit of all.
2.4 To encourage their use, we will publish guidelines on their drafting and contents and will publish model forms of agreement that may be used by employers and employees.

2.5 We will also advocate that agreements of this sort should be used as a means of increasing efficiency, introducing new technology and management methods, removing archaic work practices which limit the productivity and profitability of firms, improving employer-employee relations and introducing more flexible work practices. In particular, more flexible hours of work, permanent part-time work and flexible rewards for skill and ability will be able to be introduced by this means.
2.6 Agreements may be negotiated individually by employees or groups of employees.

2.7 Employees may appoint an agent, including a union, to negotiate on their behalf. Former officers or employees of an association whose registration was cancelled for misconduct will be prohibited from acting as agents. Other measures will be taken to prevent de-registered unions playing a role in the negotiation of voluntary agreements.

2.8 An agreement must provide for at least the relevant minimum award rate of pay for ordinary weekly hours of work for the particular classification of the employee. For the purposes of the agreement, that award rate of pay shall be calculated as an hourly rate.
2.9 Voluntary agreements may then determine other rewards and payments, conditions of employment and changes to work practices that are agreed upon.
2.10 Agreements made under this proposal will be in writing, signed, dated and witnessed.
2.11 Agreements made by minors will require approval by the minor's legal guardian or other appropriate adult.
2.12 An agreement may contain its own dispute settling procedures for dealing with disputes arising while the agreement is current.

2.13 To assist in this regard, we will make regulations under the Act setting out private dispute settling procedures which may be used by the parties. Parties may have access to the services of members of the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission on a fee for service basis as part of their dispute settling procedures.

2.14 Agreements must contain a clause acknowledging that both parties accept the terms and conditions set out in the agreement for the period of its duration and will not take any industrial action designed to vary those conditions over that period.

2.15 An agreement will have a specified term of operation. An agreement may provide that it continues in operation after the expiration of the term and until one month's notice is given of the intention to bring the agreement to an end.

2.16 Subject to the requirement for the payment of the hourly rate of pay calculated by reference to the relevant minimum award, an agreement may determine one, some, or all of the terms of employment between the employer and employees:
if the agreement covers one or some of the terms of employment, then to that extent the relevant award and any new award shall not apply to the employer and employees;
if the agreement covers all of the terms of employment, and is expressed to do so, then the award and any new award shall not apply at all to the employer and employees;
an award of the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission will therefore only apply to the extent that the terms of employment are not provided for in the agreement.
2.17 Voluntary agreements will be available to enterprises of any size.
2.18 The Act will be amended to give voluntary agreements the status of awards.
2.19 The Act will also be amended to provide that the Commission will not have jurisdiction over those industrial matters that are covered by a voluntary agreement whilst the agreement is current.

2.20 To prevent flow-on into awards of the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission, the Act will be amended to exclude the provisions of a voluntary agreement from the matters the Commission may have regard to when it is hearing and determining an industrial dispute. We will also legislate to the extent necessary to ensure that there is no flow-on from voluntary agreements into awards of the Commission.

2.21 Should a trade union take industrial action calculated to have the provisions of a voluntary agreement granted or incorporated into an award of the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission to which the union is a party, the taking of that action shall be a ground for the Commission's suspending or cancelling the award so far as the award applies to, or is in favour of, the union or its members.

2.22 The grounds for de-registration of an organisation will provide that any persistent conduct which, in the opinion of the Federal Court has been deliberately engaged in to frustrate the proper workings of the proposed system of determining wages and conditions by voluntary agreement, shall be a ground for de-registration or suspension from registration for a specified period.
3 EMPLOYEE PARTICIPATION AND INCENTIVES
3.1 It is fundamental to this policy to encourage a common purpose and mutual interest between employee and employer.

3.2 The evidence is clear that enterprises which foster good relations with their employees consistently perform better than enterprises with a poor industrial relations record. More and more Australian businesses are realising that their workforces are potentially their greatest asset-to the benefit of the enterprise and employees alike.

3.3 The Liberal and National Parties strongly support and will encourage all forms of employee participation-ranging from employee consultation through to financial incentives, profit-sharing and employee share ownership. It is essential however that any initiatives are developed on a voluntary basis. The Liberal and National Parties oppose enforcement of employee participation, or `industrial democracy', through legislation.

3.4 The Liberal and National Parties are convinced that as increased competitive pressures compel employers to look for new ways to increase productivity, employee participation and incentive schemes will flourish.

3.5 The task of the next Liberal and National Party Government will be to ensure that their introduction is facilitated. Our policy to return responsibility for industrial relations to the workplace, will provide a framework conducive to all forms of employee participation while more specific initiatives may be required to encourage particular schemes.

3.6 For example, in March 1988, the Liberal and National Parties introduced legislation into the Senate to remove the tax penalty imposed by s.26AAC of the Income Tax Assessment Act on employees who purchase shares in their company at a discount price. This legislation encompassed proposals announced in the 1982-83 budget and affirmed in the 1987 policy speech. This initiative has since been adopted, in more limited form, by the Hawke Government.
4 THE ARBITRATION COMMISSION AND WAGES POLICY

4.1 This policy will reduce the role of the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission. However, the Commission will, for the foreseeable future, continue to settle disputes and determine wages and conditions of employment for a significant proportion of the workforce. Therefore, it is essential the conciliation and arbitration system itself continues to develop a more flexible approach, one that encourages negotiations at the workplace and is responsive to the needs of individual enterprises and industries, while at the same time taking into account the impact of its decisions on the national economy. In short, decisions of the Commission must reflect economic realities at the national, industry and enterprise levels.
Establishing the Economic Framework

4.2 To achieve this, it will first be necessary to ensure that the Commission, unions, employers, and employees are well-informed about the state of the economy. A future Liberal and National Party Government will publish regular economic assessments which will provide a sound basis for sensible economic decision-making.
4.3 As well as reviewing economic conditions, these assessments will provide a basis for establishing a desirable goal for aggregate unit labour cost outcomes.

4.4 A crucial objective will be to keep unit labour cost movements, including on-costs, in Australia in line with or lower than labour cost movements in our trading competitors. This is essential if this nation is to be internationally competitive. Over recent years nominal unit labour costs have increased at two to three times the overseas average. The best way of reducing unit labour cost growth is by improving productivity, as this offers the opportunity for higher real wages and living standards. Moreover, such an objective is perfectly compatible with a range of wage outcomes across individual enterprises or industries, depending on their productivity and economic circumstances.

4.5 The Commission will be required to assess the economic impact of its decisions, in particular the effect that they will have on productivity, employment, inflation and international competitiveness. We will amend the Act to ensure that these factors are taken into account in all relevant Commission proceedings, and the Commission will, further, be required to provide estimates of the effects of its decisions on these factors.
Approach to Wage Fixing

4.6 Once these broad economic constraints have been specified, we will urge the Commission to adopt an approach to wage-fixing which, as far as possible, seeks to achieve outcomes appropriate to individual enterprises and industries.

4.7 Since the release of the Liberal and National Parties' Industrial Relations Policy in May 1986, there have been some significant changes in the attitudes of the parties and the Commission's approach to wage-fixing, and some of these have been along the lines recommended in that document. For example, the 1987 National Wage Case which introduced the two tier approach moved away from the principle of wage indexation and reduced the role of comparative wage justice.

4.8 The ``second-tier'', though far from perfect, acknowledged the importance of the workplace in determining wages, by encouraging negotiations at the enterprise level in pursuit of productivity improvements as a basis for wage increases. Such developments potentially provide a start in introducing much greater flexibility into the conciliation and arbitration system.

4.9 The position of a Liberal and National Party Government before the Commission will be that the Commission should build on the advances made under the second-tier. In particular, against the background of the broad macro-economic requirements, it should allow changes in wages and conditions to vary between firms and industries. Such diverse outcomes are perfectly compatible with achievement of competitive aggregate unit labour costs so long as wage increases are based on the economic realities confronting the firm or industry.

4.10 A major Commission role will be to assist the parties in removing impediments to increased productivity and higher real wages. Primary responsibility for negotiations should rest with the parties themselves-employers and employees-preferably at the individual enterprise level. This will help promote a sense of common purpose and, in turn, increased efficiency and productivity. We will urge the Commission to develop appropriate guidelines which will provide a basis for negotiations between the parties as well as for making its own decisions.
These would include:

Adopting higher productivity as a central objective. Eradication of restrictive work practices, the introduction of flexible working arrangements, and improved training and skill formation are important ways to improve productivity.

Introduction by the Commission of more flexibility into its awards so that it can accommodate the needs and wishes of individual enterprises and their employees. Legal impediments to variation of awards by the Commission in their application to individual enterprises and workplaces will be removed, for example, the requirement that there be uniformity of conditions throughout an industry.

Recognition that benefits from increased productivity flow in a number of ways including lower prices and therefore increased real wages and higher employment. Improvements in productivity should not, therefore, be taken necessarily to justify equivalent increases in nominal wages. Importantly, adequate returns must flow to investors to encourage further investment for the production of wealth in the future.
A much greater emphasis on conciliation and negotiation, with arbitration only being used as a last resort or where the conciliation process is being flouted by resort to industrial action.
Ensuring that proper regard is had to the specific conditions of the enterprise of industry concerned, including its capacity to pay any increase in labour costs.
4.11 We will encourage and facilitate, by legislation if necessary, the restructuring of awards on an enterprise or industry basis.
4.12 In addition, we will encourage the continued use of agreements between employers and unions, such as certified agreements, for the prevention and settlement of industrial disputes.
4.13 We will oppose the Commission extending its jurisdiction to areas which, traditionally, have been determined outside the award system. We will legislate to this effect if required.

4.14 We will prevent the extension of superannuation via arbitrated awards, although we will continue to encourage individuals to participate in superannuation schemes to provide for their own retirement.

4.15 We will encourage the conversion of paid rates to minimum rates awards, particularly where such awards have failed to maintain themselves as true paid rates awards, or where a large number of employers is covered. We will prevent the creation of new paid rates awards. Paid rates awards, which stipulate actual rates of pay and proscribe over-award payments, limit the capacity of employers to respond to labour market conditions or to introduce more flexible methods of remuneration such as productivity or performance bonuses.

4.16 Where paid rates awards are retained they should contain properly assessed and identifiable minimum classification rates. We will oppose the insertion of new supplementary payments in minimum rates awards and will legislate to prevent the Commission making recommendations about over-award payments.
Youth Wages
4.17 The Commonwealth will institute proceedings, in co-operation with the States, to have junior wage rates set in all applicable awards.

4.18 We will also ensure, by our submissions to industrial tribunals and by advocating a training wage, that youth wages are set at levels that encourage the employment and training of young people and are not obstacles to their employment and training.
5 LIMITS ON INDUSTRIAL ACTION

5.1 A principal objective of this policy is to make parties responsible and accountable for their actions. We believe that this will develop in an evolutionary fashion as individual workplaces increasingly become the focus for decisions on wages and industrial relations. To ensure the efficacy of any contractual system, legal remedies must be available when one party fails to meet its obligations. The disturbing imbalance of power within the conciliation and arbitration system where unions frequently defy Commission orders with impunity will be redressed.
The Rule of Law
5.2 We will ensure that employees, employers, their representatives, and others involved in industrial relations are equal before the law, that the law applies to all, and that it is enforced.
Common Law
5.3 We will encourage the use of the common law in the civil courts in appropriate cases as a means of obtaining redress for unjustified industrial action.
5.4 In co-operation with the States, we will endeavour to streamline procedures for such court actions to ensure simpler and swifter hearings.
Compliance with Commission Decisions

5.5 We will enact legislation already introduced in the Senate to ensure that there are effective sanctions for those who fail to comply with the decisions and orders of the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission.

5.6 This will enable the Commission to issue directions to stop or prevent industrial action. Such directions would be enforceable by injunctions issued by the Federal Court. Failure to comply with injunctions would constitute contempt of court.
5.7 In addition, any person who suffers loss or damage as a result of industrial action in breach of a direction would be able to sue the responsible organisation for damages in the Federal Court.
5.8 We also will review all penalties under the Act to ensure that they are appropriate and effective.
Compliance with Voluntary Agreements
5.9 A voluntary agreement will be legally enforceable and the normal remedies provided under the law of contract will be available to all parties.

5.10 In addition there will be statutory provisions to ensure that where industrial action in breach of an agreement takes place, the aggrieved party may apply to a civil court for an injunction against the industrial action. Failure to comply with an injunction would constitute contempt of court. There would also be provision for the aggrieved party to sue for damages resulting from action in breach of an agreement. Similar remedies would apply to those who induce either employers or employees to break agreements they have made.
Financial Support for Oppressed Parties

5.11 In general, industrial disputes are a matter for settlement between the parties. The Government's offer of financial assistance to firms complying with its code of conduct in defiance of the Builders Labourers' Federation is an example of how in extreme circumstances direct financial assistance may be warranted. We will give assistance in appropriate circumstances.
5.12 We will also grant legal aid in appropriate circumstances to employers or employees, in cases, for example, concerning secondary boycotts or breaches of voluntary agreements.
Grievance Procedures
5.13 We support much wider use of grievance procedures as a valuable method of dealing with disputes at the workplace level without resort to industrial action.
5.14 We will foster forms of voluntary agreements which contain appropriate grievance procedures to deal with disputes arising during the term of the agreement.

5.15 We support the widest possible use of grievance procedures in awards. Unfortunately, while many awards already contain grievance procedures they are often not adhered to. Failure to comply with a grievance procedure will constitute grounds for the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission to issue a direction that industrial action cease.
Secondary Boycotts
5.16 We will maintain the effectiveness of, and if necessary strengthen, the secondary boycott provisions of the Trade Practices Act.
5.17 We will use the powers of the Minister to bring proceedings under the Trade Practices Act in appropriate cases.
Essential Services

5.18 Industrial action may sometimes pose a real threat to public order, or to the safety, health or life of individuals. The States have at their disposal a variety of essential services legislation, and where such threats arise in State jurisdictions, they will be best able to act accordingly.

5.19 The Commonwealth currently has no essential services legislation. We will enact comprehensive legislation to protect the public and the national interest in the Commonwealth area where unacceptable threat to health and safety arises, and where economically essential services or the defence of Australia are prejudiced.
Strike Pay
5.20 We will make it an offence for any employer to pay, or any employee to accept, strike pay.
5.21 The Act will be amended to prohibit a union from taking industrial action in pursuit of a demand for strike pay.

5.22 An employer may seek an injunction terminating such action and any person or organisation inciting such action shall also be liable for damages for any loss suffered. In addition, conduct of this kind shall be a ground for deregistration of the trade union.
Stand-down Provisions

5.23 The Conciliation and Arbitration Commission shall not have any power to require an employer to pay wages to any employee who cannot be productively employed because of the consequences of industrial action.
5.24 We will ensure that employers have effective stand-down rights to deal with rolling bans and strikes.
Secret Ballots
5.25 A Liberal and National Party Government will strengthen the provisions in the Act relating to secret ballots to make ballots compulsory before industrial action.

5.26 Any person who either suffers harm or is threatened with harm from industrial action where a secret ballot has not been held will be able to seek an injunction in the Federal Court to prevent or terminate the action. There will also be provision for parties who have suffered from such industrial action to sue for damages.
5.27 We will legislate to ensure that stringent standards are satisfied before a valid secret ballot will be regarded as having taken place.

5.28 Industrial action taken after a secret ballot has been held will not in itself have general legal immunity. For example, secondary boycotts or industrial action in breach of a Commission direction would still give rise to injunctions whether a secret ballot had been held or not.
6 PUBLIC SECTOR INDUSTRIAL RELATIONS
6.1 A Liberal and National Party Government will adopt a more flexible, market-oriented approach to industrial relations in the area of Commonwealth employment.

6.2 Public sector pay and conditions will be such as to enable employers to recruit, retain and motivate the staff they require in order to achieve their objectives. In determining pay and conditions the following factors will be taken into account: economic conditions, cost, the need to be fair to employees, and the need to reflect differences in market conditions, individual performance, skills and experience. Public servants will as far as possible be provided with terms and conditions of employment that are broadly comparable to, but not more generous than, the private sector.

6.3 A Liberal and National Party Government will not tolerate the use of bans and limitations by Commonwealth employees. We will restore the ``no work as directed-no pay provisions'' of the Public Service Act, and will ensure that in addition to essential services legislation the Commonwealth has effective powers, including stand-down powers, for dealing with industrial action.
7 TRADE UNIONS
Freedom of Association and Union Structure

7.1 The Liberal and National Parties' approach to trade unions is conditioned by the fundamental goal of promoting close, co-operative, flexible and productive relationships within enterprises for the mutual benefit of employers and employees.

7.2 We believe that genuine voluntary unionism and greater scope for workers to choose their union combined with an increasingly enterprise-based industrial relations system, will help to bring about a union structure which is more accountable to the membership and more likely to contribute to good industrial relations.

7.3 The existing union structure is a significant impediment to improved relations between employers and employees in many enterprises. Most employers are forced to deal with several unions, which tend to vie with one another and press narrow sectional interests within the labour force, thus creating demarcation disputes and disrupting employer-employee relations.
7.4 The existence of unions largely based on occupation, rather than industry or enterprise, also encourages the rapid flow of wage adjustments from one part of the economy to other areas.
7.5 The Liberal and National Parties will ensure that:
(a) membership of trade unions is genuinely voluntary;
(b) the closed shop is outlawed;

(c) the structure of registered trade unions in enterprises which are operating under the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission and its awards will be determined by the wishes of the members of those unions. Freedom of association will be preserved subject only to Commission supervision of matters relating to the formation of new unions and amalgamation or fragmentation of existing unions with a view to ensuring that, as far as possible, new union structures contribute to the objectives of:
ensuring that employers and employees within an enterprise deal directly with each other;
minimising interference by people or bodies with no direct interest in the enterprise;
facilitating the consolidation of single enterprise bargaining units.
A variety of union structures and sizes could meet these criteria including unions organised on an industry or enterprise basis.
Interested parties will be entitled to have their views heard by the Commission on these issues. There will be provision as appropriate for appeals to the Federal Court.

7.6 In addition, where there are disputes between unions over union coverage such disputes will be determined where applicable by reference to the workforce. In such cases the role of the Commission will be to define the choices available to the workforce and it may indicate which choice, in the view of the Commission, is likely to facilitate the desired employer/employee co-operation.

7.7 Where employees wish to form a new union to represent them or to vary existing union structures to represent them more effectively there will be secret ballot provisions to enable the wishes of the workforce to be determined. When those wishes are established by secret ballot the desired structure will be approved unless, in the opinion of the Commission, it will provide a less effective structure to promote the objectives set out in (c) above, or, in the absence of special circumstances, there has been a determination on union structure within the previous three years.
7.8 Specifically the Liberal and National Parties will:

make it an offence for any person or body, including a trade union or employer, to require a person to join or remain a member of a trade union against his or her will. It will therefore no longer be necessary to obtain a certificate of conscientious objection before being entitled to protection against being coerced to join a union. It will also be an offence for a union to take or threaten industrial action with the purpose of seeking a ``closed shop''. Employers or employees facing such action may seek an injunction for its termination and damages will also be available.
legislate so that a member of an organisation who has not paid his or her subscriptions for a period of six months will be deemed to have resigned from that organisation;
prohibit collection of union dues by employers except where there has been a specific request by the individual employee and the employer consents;
legislate to enable any group of employees proposing to form a union or to amalgamate or fragment an existing union to approach the Commission to set in train the procedures outlined in (c) above;

ensure that the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission shall not have the power to grant any form of compulsory unionism or clauses giving any preference to members of a trade union over employees who are not union members;

legislate, if necessary, to ensure full portability so as to preserve both voluntary unionism and legitimate superannuation rights where an employee's desire to resign from a union is compromised by his or her membership of a union superannuation fund.
De-registration
7.9 When circumstances justify de-registration of an organisation we will ensure that it occurs swiftly and in a fully effective manner.

7.10 In addition to using the present provisions on de-registration we will introduce specific legislation where appropriate, along the lines of the legislation used to de-register the Builders Labourers Federation. Such legislation would enable the Minister to apply to the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission for an enquiry into an organisation's behaviour. Such enquiries would be conducted as expeditiously as possible.

7.11 If the Commission certifies that the organisation has engaged in serious industrial misconduct, the Minister would then be able to effect the immediate cancellation or suspension of the organisation's registration.

7.12 Where questions of liability for fines, penalties or damages may arise, the Commission shall have the power to sequester an organisation's funds and to place them in the hands of an administrator until such questions be resolved.
7.13 Office-bearers of de-registered organisations will not be permitted to hold office in the same or any other organisation for a period of five years.
Independent Contractors

7.14 The Act will be amended to make it an offence to force, or attempt to force an independent contractor, partner or self employed person to join a union. It will also be made an offence to discriminate against such a person on the ground that he/she is not a member.

7.15 We will at all times encourage and preserve the rights of independent contractors, partners and self-employed persons. In particular, the jurisdiction of the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission shall be strictly confined to relations between employers and employees.
Accounts and Audits

7.16 We will conduct a thorough examination of the operation of those sections of the Act which deal with the accounts and auditing practices of registered organisations, and will amend them where necessary to ensure that organisations keep proper and audited accounts which are readily available to members.
7.17 We will also amend the Act to ensure that the accounting, auditing and other financial obligations of organisations are as nearly as practicable the same of those of companies.
8 STATE-COMMONWEALTH JURISDICTIONS

8.1 Maximum provision will be made for the reciprocal and complementary exercise of State and Commonwealth jurisdictions by means such as joint sittings of tribunals, to achieve greater consistency and integration, reduce anomalies and injustices and prevent the leap-frogging of industrial claims.

8.2 We will ensure that a proper balance is maintained between Federal and State jurisdictions. For example we will prevent the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission from making a Federal award covering an area of employment which is satisfactorily handled by a State jurisdiction.
9 CONSULTATION

9.1 We will consult regularly with employee and employer representatives on all aspects of industrial relations policy. Consultative mechanisms should promote the co-operative ethos embodied in this policy.
9.2 We will discuss with employer and employee representatives the development on a tripartite basis of a voluntary code of conduct to govern the behaviour of the parties in industrial relations.
Policy issued 29 June 1988

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate. I go on to quote a couple of paragraphs which are vital to an understanding of that policy. Paragraph 1.13 states:

SPEECH.PARA: The role of the Federal Government is primarily to set the framework within which employers and employees conduct their affairs. In particular, the Government has a responsibility to ensure there is a proper legal framework which encourages good industrial relations and protects the rights of the individual. This means ensuring that neither employers nor unions are able to abuse their power.

I repeat what I said earlier in the debate: It is just as vital to me to see the protection of employee interests as it is to see the protection of any other interests in industrial relations. The other two paragraphs I wish to refer to which are relevant to the accusations which were made in a very wild way, in my view, by Senator Aulich start at paragraph 1.18 and read as follows:

1.18 There is a growing realisation that efficient, productive and competitive enterprises require a vision shared by both the workforce and management. This means breaking down the barriers that have traditionally existed between management and employees and building up a relationship of mutual trust. Our policies will give management both greater incentive and a greater capacity to develop and improve its employee relations. There is no doubt however that to get the full benefit of these policies will require greater effort on the part of management.

1.19 The Liberal and National Parties believe that unions have an important role to play in representing the legitimate interests of their members. We welcome responsible unionism and support the right of all employees to joint a union. However, we totally reject compulsory unionism. Just as employees should be free to joint a union so they should be free not to join. This is fundamentally a matter of civil liberties. Genuinely voluntary unions are also more likely to act in a responsible manner and to concentrate on properly providing for their members.

I make no apology at all for reintroducing into this Parliament a Bill which would remedy one of the defects in the Government's industrial relations legislation. Again, I will respond to a point made by Senator Aulich, who waved the Bill around and said, `This is the industrial relations policy of the Opposition.' I will not, for reasons of frugality, seek to incorporate this document into Hansard, but I will table, again, the extensive amendments which were proposed by the Opposition to the Government's industrial relations legislation. I seek leave to table that document simply to illustrate the broad concerns over a range of areas of industrial relations which reflect the policy which I have had incorporated into Hansard.
Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate. I turn briefly to what was said by Senator McLean. I wish to point out to him that the decision by the Government to withdraw the directions and compliance procedure was, as I said earlier in this reply, made after an express undertaking to the contrary made just prior to the 1987 election in a debate between me and Mr Willis on station 3LO in Melbourne. The tradition of the Australian Democrats, as originally established by, then, Senator Chipp, was that their role in this Parliament was `to keep the bastards honest', if I may quote Senator Chipp. I would have thought that in this case it would be a serious matter for consideration by the Democrats that the relief we are seeking to put into the Bill is of the same nature as the relief which was promised by the Government at the time of the 1987 election. This is not the last time, I suspect, that we will be debating this matter. I certainly will engage in further dialogue, as Senator McLean has suggested. But I say that the passage of this legislation through the Senate would be one step towards keeping this particular Government honest on this particular issue.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Cooney raised two matters which I would wish to address. The first is the possibility of limiting the power of the court to punish for contempt by excluding the option of imprisonment, and that is a matter which needs serious consideration. As I said, it was always the intention of the Opposition to promote pecuniary penalties, not the court discretion to imprison. Of course, the court has unlimited discretion to punish for contempt of court as was shown in the plumbers and gasfitters case where it chose to fine the plumbers and gasfitters union $280,000 for its contempt of the court's order.

The other point of substance made by Senator Cooney was whether in all cases the remedies which the present Industrial Relations Act provides are adequate to protect the interests of employees whose rights are being flouted by employers. I am sorry that Senator Cooney is not here for me to answer directly. The point I make in response to Senator Cooney is that this Bill, if enacted, would give the employees about whom he expressed concern the capacity to obtain a court injunction and to put exactly the same sanction on the employer as I have just described. In other words, there would be unlimited power of the court to punish for any continuing contempt by the employers. I think that is a fair coverage of the issues raised in the debate on this legislation.

I remind the Senate that this legislation is not raised simply to deal with the pilots' dispute, although that is a classic example of the capacity of an organisation to thumb its nose at the Commission, to accept its benefits on the one hand but refuse to accept decisions which it does not like on the other. This amendment was first put forward by us in 1987. It was again put forward by us in 1988. It has represented the long considered view of the Opposition, completely in accord with the views expressed by the former Minister for Industrial Relations, Mr Willis, in 1987 that a change of this sort is essential if we are to have a more orderly system of conciliation and arbitration in this country.

I close by repeating that the present system has let the workers of Australia down. If Senator Burns had been asked in 1983 whether he thought there would be any possibility that an outcome of 6 1/2 years of Labor Government would be a decline in real wages, I think he would have said no. Senator Burns and other honourable senators with a long history in the trade union movement should ponder the failures of the present system and its failure to produce a lift in productivity, which is essential if real wages are to be improved in this country. I commend the Bill to the Senate.
Question put:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the negative.

DEBATE.TITLE: ABORIGINAL AND TORRES STRAIT ISLANDER COMMISSION BILL 1989

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Boswell Sen R.L.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tonight we are debating the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission Bill, version two. The first version could not even make it to this House. The Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission (ATSIC) legislation is born out of chaos and will be destructive if it eventually goes through this Parliament. Since it was first introduced last August there has been nothing but disarray and an uproar in the Aboriginal affairs portfolio.

SPEECH.PARA: There have been five inquiries into Aboriginal affairs investigating the administration, financial management and personnel management of the Department of Aboriginal Affairs (DAA), the Aboriginal Development Commission (ADC) and the possible interference with witnesses appearing before the Senate Select Committee on the Administration of Aboriginal Affairs. In addition, the original ADC commissioners were sacked in a shameful display of tyranny by the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, Gerry Hand, who sent them back home to their communities in disgrace. This was followed two weeks later by a leaked press release claiming that $670,000 of ADC funds was misappropriated or missing. Then there was the sacking of the head of the DAA, Mr Charles Perkins, who has since been exonerated by the Menzies report into Allegations as to the Administration of Aboriginal Affairs.

There was the dismissal of the chairperson of the ADC, Shirley McPherson-if she was not dismissed she was certainly forced out of office-a person of undoubted competence and integrity, for daring to offer an alternative structure to ATSIC. She knew, and she is an Aboriginal person, that ATSIC was inappropriate. Mick O'Brien, the general manager of the ADC, got the boot and there have been resignations by just about all senior officers of the ADC or the DAA as they see their life's work disintegrate, because they know that the ATSIC legislation is inappropriate.

Even now the hand picked ADC commissioners are rebelling against the Minister because he has just about gutted the ADC in the last week. Not only that, the Torres Strait Islanders wanted to secede from Australia because they did not want to be a minority in a minority. Under the ATSIC regime they would be one voice in a 20-voice Commission and because they were so frightened of the ATSIC legislation they wanted to walk out of Australia. When Mr Hand tried to bring this legislation in I said that the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) was sending a boy on a man's job. I said that 18 months ago before any of this disaster had happened and I have been proved absolutely right. He is a boy trying to do a man's job and he does not know what he is involving himself in.

This is the sorry record of Aboriginal affairs since the Minister was appointed after the last election. There is a record of destruction, division, instability and a lack of direction in the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander communities. The Minister's booklet Foundations for the Future is turning into a sorry mess as he tries to get ATSIC up before this Parliament. This legislation has caused unprecedented destruction which will only become worse if it goes through with the support of the Australian Democrats.

Let me put it on the record at the outset that the Opposition does not support this legislation. The Opposition supports the view put down in the minority report presented by my colleague Senator Peter Baume and me, that the proposal for an Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission is unjustified, unnecessary and culturally inappropriate. The detailed proposal that has emerged in this Bill is faulty and unsafe. If pursued, it will operate to the detriment of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islanders. That is the position of both the Liberal and National parties in this Parliament. We are faced either with walking away from the legislation and voting against it in its entirety thereby leaving the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people in the lurch, having nothing more to do with this atrocious legislation, or with trying to improve the legislation by amendment. We have chosen the second course in order to alleviate, where possible, the more draconian parts of this totally inappropriate legislation.

I said in the Senate on 28 February this year that this legislation sets up a white man's bureaucracy, thrusts it on the black communities of Australia and calls it self-determination. This Bill establishes an Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission that incorporates under its huge umbrella the DAA, the ADC, and Aboriginal Hostels Ltd. This will be done by establishing 60 regional councils electing 1,200 councillors. In turn, these councils will elect 17 zonal commissioners who in Canberra will make virtually every decision on Aboriginals. The Government's answer to solving the Aboriginals, many problems is by setting up a black parliament with 1,200 elected members; dividing Australia into black and white; setting up apartheid in Australia; and developing Australia along split racial lines. That is what this Government has to offer Australia and the black community. After 200 years of settlement in Australia this is the worst possible way to address the needs and concerns of the indigenous people of Australia. The previous Minister, Clyde Holding, has said that for Aboriginal legislation to be enduring and successful it must have the support of the majority of all Australians. The present Minister, Gerry Hand, made the following statement:
The effective implementation of this proposal ultimately must rest on receiving positive endorsement from the Aboriginal and Islander community.
Later, he stated:
Aboriginal people need to decide for themselves what should be done-not just take on whatever the Government says is best for them.

He never had that endorsement from the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander communities and he has never had it from the white communities of Australia. Both Ministers' statements have been totally ignored by the introduction of this ATSIC legislation. The majority of white Australians will not support legislation that divides Aboriginal Australia into 60 regional councillors to elect 1,200 representatives-two democratic systems in one democracy. The ATSIC proposal does not have the support of the black or white communities.

On Tuesday this week the Prime Minister acknowledged in glowing terms the contribution that Charles Perkins has made to Aboriginal affairs in Australia over the last 20 years. These sentiments were endorsed by the Leader of the Opposition in the Senate, Senator Chaney. The same Charles Perkins has said that inadequate consultation is being offered to Aboriginals and Islanders on the ATSIC legislation, a conclusion also reached by the majority report of the Senate Select Committee. Mr Perkins's exact words about Gerry Hand on the PM program were:

He made a promise to Aboriginal people and he's got to fulfil that promise, to go back to them with the legislation, and discuss it with them before he proceeds. Now if he doesn't do that, he has no mandate.

Let me assure the Senate that Mr Hand never went back and consulted the Aboriginals. Mr Perkins also said in an interview that the present arrangement between the DAA, the ADC and the Institute of Aboriginal Studies should remain. The task should be to make them more effective. The mechanics of setting up ATSIC would be disastrous. Mr Perkins must feel that a great weight has been lifted off his shoulders now that he is free to give his own advice and honest opinion about how ATSIC will affect the black people of Australia. He is virtually saying exactly what the Opposition has been saying for the last 12 months; that is that the DAA, the ADC, the Institute and the Housing Commission should be retained and improved and that the mechanics of setting up ATSIC are disastrous. We have been saying that for 18 months. Senator Peter Baume, Senator Stone and I have been telling the Senate and telling Australia. Now Mr Perkins is saying exactly the same thing. It is now time for the Prime Minister to stand up to Gerry Hand and his band of socialist left comrades and act like a Prime Minister and not a captive of the Left.

TALK.START.PARA: —Why are the Democrats betraying Charles Perkins?
—I do not know. The Prime Minister cannot make statements lauding Charles Perkins as he did yesterday. Let me quote what the Prime Minister said:

SPEECH.PARA: Charles Perkins believed that one of the most important roles was to keep in close touch with as many individual Aboriginal people and as many Aboriginal communities as he possibly could.
Accordingly he travelled extensively and was able to bring to this and previous governments an invaluable insight into the concerns and abilities of his people.

If the Prime Minister believed in his own statement, his own rhetoric, that Mr Perkins kept in touch with the black communities and that he was able to bring invaluable insight into the needs of black communities, he should listen to Mr Perkins, because Mr Perkins is saying that ATSIC is not a goer. Members of the Hawke Government know that and they have told the Prime Minister so. The hardheads know that it is not a goer. The people on the other side of the chamber who know about Aboriginals know that it is not a goer. As soon as Mr Hawke realises that Mr Hand is totally incompetent and appoints someone like Senator Collins as Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, Aboriginals will be better off.

The indigenous people are being told that they will have self-determination and self-management through regional councils. That is blatantly untrue. Regional councils will have little or no power. All power will rest with the zonal commissioners, the 17 people who will go to Canberra to get their riding instructions from the Minister-appointed chairman of ATSIC and his two appointed lieutenants. We are told in this legislation that the function of the regional councils is to formulate a regional plan, to advise, to assist and to cooperate with the Commission and the other government authorities on its implementation, to make proposals for expenditure, and to pass on the local view to the Commission.

Regional councils are really only advisory bodies. They have no teeth or real power. They will be completely under the heel of the commissioners in Canberra. I do not want to criticise the advisers who are sitting in the advisers' area, but I would have thought that Mr Hand could have sent at least one black person to watch this legislation go through. The fact that there is not one black person observing these proceedings is another indictment and means that ATSIC will be under the thumb of white people. Regional councils cannot even hire or fire staff without the consent of their Canberra masters. This is not self-control or self-management. This will remove power from the local communities. This will take power out of the elected communities' councils and place it 3,000 to 5,000 miles away in Canberra. It will be the Commission, with its 20 commissioners-including the three ministerial appointed commissioners-that will control the 230,000 Aboriginals and 25,000 or 30,000 Islanders.

Let us not forget Gerry Hand. He will have ultimate power and control over the Commission. One must ask: Can Mr Hand be trusted? After the disastrous consequences of sackings, leakings, dismissals, resignations and gutting of the ADC, the answer has to be: no, he cannot be trusted. The action proposed in a Cabinet minute dated 17 July, which was leaked the other day, to remove funding and associated functional rearrangements for the ADC, was designed to gut it. That is the only true decision-making board that the Aboriginal people have had, but it is now rendered a shell. That shows the power that the Minister can exert from Canberra. The legislation sets out that the Minister will appoint five commissioners in the first 12 months-five commissioners to represent 230,000 people. The Minister will control ATSIC for 12 or 18 months as well as controlling its first two budgets. That is not self-determination of self-management for Aboriginal and Islander people. It is a cruel hoax and a farce to talk about self-management when this legislation deprives Aboriginals and Islanders of self-management.

The peak body of Queensland Aboriginal councils, the Aboriginal Coordinating Council (ACC), issued a press release claiming that it had been led up the garden path by Mr Hand and that he has a double agenda for Aboriginal people. The press release states:
Minister Hand's actions have now made it clear that ATSIC's role will be to report and recommend to him through a Board chosen and controlled by him, not the people as he told us.
It is the same old Government Policy that was used during colonisation. Black people against black people . . .
That is what the 20,000-odd Aboriginals who live in Queensland communities believe. I seek leave to incorporate the press release in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The press release read as follows-

The Chairman of the Queensland Aboriginal Co-Ordinating Council, Mr. Merv Gibson expressed grave concerns for the future of Aboriginal Australians after learning of the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, Gerry Hand, statement to Parliament on 11th April, 1989.

``We accepted ATSIC on the understanding that elections for Regional Councils and Commissioners would be the first things that happened once ATSIC was passed. One of Gerry's major selling points was that the current system does not provide for elected representation on the Board of the A.D.C., now he performs the old ``pea and thimble'' trick and informs Parliament that there won't be any elected Commissioners for the first twelve (12) months, ``He'' will appoint an interim Board of five (5)! You don't have to be very smart to work out who they will be,'' Mr. Gibson said.
``We feel we have been led up the garden path by the Minister. He made no mention of his real intentions at our ATSIC Workshop in Cairns.''

``His actions this week through the instructions issued to A.D.C. Commissioners under Section 11 of the A.D.C. Act, which takes away all their decision making power and gives it to the Minister and his clear statement that he will appoint an interim ATSIC Board for the first twelve (12) months, clearly indicated that he intends to ``rule'' his portfolio. We are disappointed that the A.D.C. Commissioners are going along with him.''
It is now clear that Mr. Hand had a double agenda all along. One story for us Aborigines and another for Parliament.

We have examined what the Ministers decision to appoint the interim ATSIC Board will mean for us in regard to our supposed involvement in the decision making process, as touted by Mr. Hand and the realities are quite alarming for us all, if ATSIC is passed this month.
The points are as follows:
11th April 1989: Minister issues Section 11 advice and gains Ministerial control over the A.D.C.
Assume ATSIC is passed this month (April).
1st October, 1989: ATSIC is created, five (5) months after being passed in Parliament. (Why the delay? Surely an election can be organised in five (5) months?).
1st October, 1989: 1989-90 Budgets are already in place as estimates are prepared April/May every year. No ATSIC elected Commissioners involvement.
1st October, 1989: Minister Hand appoints the five (5) Commissioners to ATSIC Board for twelve (12) months.
April/May, 1990: 1990-91 Estimates are prepared under the Stewardship of the five Hand picked Commissioners-no electee's input.
1st October, 1990: Elected Commissioners take up positions on ATSIC Board-current Budget is already in place-no input by electee's.
April/May, 1991: Elected ATSIC Commissioners formulate ATSIC's 1991-92 Budget, one and a half years after ATSIC's creation!

Bearing in mind that the Minister's platform to us has been that ATSIC will provide Aboriginal and Islander people a greater say in deciding our future, we feel that his actions this week confirm our initial fears that his real purpose all along has been to establish the `Governments Priorities' not ours. The fact that he made that point three (3) times in his Ministerial Statement of 11th April, 1989 that ATSIC will reflect the Government Priorities is evidence enough.

`Mr Hands Ministerial Statement could contain other traps for us that he has never disclosed. He speaks about the AEDC and the non transfer of the A.D.C.'s Housing function to it. He states, ``It would be inappropriate and would dilute the commercial nature of the AEDC to have it take on programs, especially programs which include quasi-commercial aspects such as grants and concessional loans.'

My concern is that this statement seems to indicate that concessional loans for housing and enterprise as are currently available through A.D.C. programs will no longer exist under ATSIC and Aboriginal and Islander people struggling to purchase a home or start a business will be charged the full commercial rate by the AEDC! Where is there any assistance to us in that system?
Minister Hands actions have now made it quite clear that ATSIC's role will be to report and recommend to him through a Board chosen and controlled by him, not the people as he told us.
It is the same old Government Policy that was used during the colonisation. Black people against black people to carry out the Governments wishes.
It's the same as the Old Native Police when Aborigines from N.S.W. were recruited to `disperse' Queensland Aborigines and vice versa.
It's the same process that the Queensland Police use now in Communities.
Get the Aboriginal Police to carry out the State Police duties and when things go wrong, blame the Aboriginal Police!
The sad part is that there are Aboriginal people in positions of influence who can't see this because they have been influenced by the Minister.

We support the statements made by Mr Neil Phillips of the Western Australian Advancement Council Inc., which condemns the Ministers actions as per the Section 11 advice to A.D.C. Commissioners. We feel that the only true decision making power that Aboriginal people have ever held has now been lost forever, and sadly Aboriginal people allowed it to happen!
It is painfully obvious that at the end of the day it is `Party Politics and Government Priorities' that are the real issues and not `Aboriginal Development'.
As they say, `The more things change, the more they stay the same'.

TALK.START.PARA: —The press release was issued by Merv Gibson, the Chairman of the ACC, arguably the largest Aboriginal peak council in Australia, which represents Aboriginals who live in 14 deed-of-grant communities in Queensland. It is not only Merv Gibson who is disgusted with the Minister for hand picking his commissioners for the first 12 or 18 months. Senator Coulter was interviewed on AM on 12 April and, as he is in the Senate now, I will quote him. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: We are disgusted with the way in which the Minister has proceeded with this. He gave no inkling whatsoever of the establishment of an interim commission of 5 hand picked people.

The AM report continued with Senator Coulter saying that the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission will remain on the drawing board until the Minister meets all the recommendations of the Senate Committee. I hope Senator Coulter is a man of his word. I hope the Australian Democrats will use their numbers in the Senate to protect the rights of black Australians.

The ATSIC proposal places in jeopardy the future of Queensland communities-in fact all Aboriginal communities-that have been set up under local government authority legislation. These communities in Queensland have been given seven million acres of land and they are about to receive another two million acres under deeds of grant-in-trust. They are funded by block grants from both the Federal and State governments and are completely self-managed. Each council sets its own priorities for roads, sewerage, housing, parks, and so on. The community assesses its own needs. That is self-determination; that is self-management. Black people are making decisions for themselves in their own communities. They are not going to a regional council to argue their case and then having to get the okay from Canberra, or from a commissioner who comes from Tasmania or Western Australia who does not even understand the needs of Aboriginals in Queensland.

Aboriginal people are taking pride in their communities. They are developing their own businesses. Community businesses are providing employment for 250 Aboriginals and Islanders. Hairdressing salons, dress shops, bakeries, butchers, and food stores have been set up by Aboriginals. The government community stores are now being run privately by the communities. During 1990 it is estimated that the number of businesses will have tripled to approximately 150. In December 1983 there were only three businesses, now there are 52 business enterprises in communities. That figure excludes crocodile farms, cattle farms and many other small farms.

The crayfish industry in the Torres Strait has increased turnover from $300,000 to $7m in the last six years, providing an economy and jobs for the Torres Strait Islanders. The industry is owned by the Islanders. A small trochus shell industry is being developed and is providing jobs. It is also owned and controlled by the Islanders. Cattle turnover has increased by 500 per cent in the last six years. All this success will be put at risk if ATSIC comes into force. Those people are making their own decisions. They are providing jobs and an economy. All those decisions will now have to be made in Canberra. These great gains made by Aboriginals will disappear. Every community will have to go cap in hand to their regional council which will set a budget and send it down to Canberra for approval before any decision can be made.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is not true.

—It is definitely true. The work of many people, many years of slogging, will be wiped out, all to satisfy Gerry Hand's socialist left philosophy that all power must be centralised in Canberra. His attitude is that the `bush murrays' have not got the ability to make a decision for themselves in their own communities. That is what ATSIC is all about. ATSIC denies Aboriginals their right to live in a secure community because it pushes various communities together in the same regional council which gets one voice at a zonal level. This may lead to the dominance of the more articulate urban Aboriginals whose priorities may be quite different from those of community Aboriginals. For example, urban Aboriginals may be more interested in legal and health services while Aboriginals in the communities may see water, sewerage, housing and roads as their priorities. The basic issue here is how to get adequate representation for all without denying Aboriginal people their ethos of relating to the people and needs of their own communities.

SPEECH.PARA: This legislation simply does not resolve that issue. It will be a nightmare for those living in the traditional communities and in the smaller communities in Queensland who have great difficulty with English. How will a councillor from these areas successfully argue his case on a regional council? How will he stand up for his community's share of the cake when he cannot even speak English? Many Aboriginals have difficulty with English. How would a councillor be received back home in his own small community when his council ignores his request or decides on different spending priorities for his community? Sometimes ATSIC even makes it impossible for the smaller communities to get representation.

The Minister has decided to start ATSIC without holding elections which, from his point of view, was the whole basis of self-management. On top of this, he asks this Parliament to sanction a Bill that omits the most basic mechanisms used to set up the ATSIC structure. The Senate has not been told how the elections for over 1,200 people are to be conducted. This Parliament is being asked to abdicate its responsibility to ensure that the elections for a very powerful body are held in the most democratic way possible. Who decides the conduct of elections? Is it the self-managing Aboriginals? No, it is the Minister. The Minister may also make rules to reduce significantly the costs of these elections. Does that mean that an Aboriginal vote is dependent on its cost?

The Minister is also asking the Senate to pass the Bill without having finalised the regional boundaries which are the grass roots structure of the whole ATSIC proposal. No-one ever knows what region he is in. This legislation lists only the names of zones and regions; it gives no clear picture of who and what are contained within each region. Last night the Minister's office informed my office that it cannot even provide a date on which these regional boundaries will be finalised. Senator Coulter went to Mr Hand and Mr Hand said, `Do not worry about it; we will fix it all up later'. Senator Coulter must believe in the tooth fairy! The Bill provides for the Minister to determine the regional boundaries. Obviously Parliament and the people of Australia do not need to know where those boundaries will be. What an uproar there would be if the Prime Minister decided to set divisional boundaries for Federal electorates. Mr Hand wants to do it. He also has the power. Is there no end to what power he will claim? The Minister can change these boundaries from time to time and make any provisions he thinks are necessary to transfer assets or liabilities between the affected regional councils. This is absolutely outrageous!

How can this Bill reflect consultation with Aboriginals when so much of the basic mechanics-the regional boundaries and the conduct of elections-are missing entirely? Either the Government has not worked it out yet-which shows it is completely incompetent-or it is too scared to put it in this legislation and leave it open to the parliamentary process. Obviously the Minister has given himself dictatorial power over a national black political structure. This is not black self-management; this is white supremacy.

This is possibly the most disastrous piece of legislation to come before this Parliament. It certainly will not meet the needs of the Aboriginal people. Their needs and immediate problems are: health, housing, water, education, sewerage, Aboriginal deaths in custody and a high proportion of Aboriginals in gaol. This legislation does not address those problems in the slightest and it will set the cause of Aboriginals back many years. As Senator Peter Baume has said, they may never recover from it. This legislation deserves to be thrown out because it is bad for the black community and it has no support from the white community.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McMullan Sen R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am pleased to have the opportunity to support the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission (ATSIC) legislation which we are debating tonight and which is a very important initiative. While I do not agree with Senator Peter Baume's view about it I share the comment he made at the beginning of his speech when he said that it is the most important piece of Aboriginal legislation that we will see this decade. I think that is right and I think its importance requires serious consideration. During the course of Senator Boswell's contribution I said to my colleague Senator Faulkner that if ATSIC were actually the organisation which Senator Boswell was describing I would not support it either. But, fortunately, it does not bear any relationship to the body that he has just outlined, so I think we can continue to discuss what is really proposed in the legislation and give it some serious and sober consideration.

SPEECH.PARA: I am pleased to support three elements in the legislation which together form the underlying concept of ATSIC. I referred to these elements in a previous contribution in the Parliament and I say again that the three aspects of the ATSIC concept are: firstly, the administrative consolidation envisaged within it; secondly, the establishment of a representative national structure; and, thirdly, a representative regional structure. I think those three concepts which form the core of ATSIC are worthy of support. They are aspirations for which Aboriginal people have expressed support in principle. It was acknowledged by all concerned that support in principle for those concepts was achieved by the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Mr Hand) irrespective of divergent views about the merits of subsequent consultation.

The legislation, as originally envisaged, was right in principle. It talked about self-determination and self-management. It was not a unique idea; it was not something that emerged from nowhere; it was a logical next step from previous initiatives which have been taken-for example, the Aboriginal Development Commission (ADC) and the National Aboriginal Conference (NAC). The ADC had many of the good features of ATSIC in that Aboriginal people were involved in making decisions about the allocation of resources, setting priorities and making hard choices. But one fundamental shortcoming-and I will come back to discuss the ADC subsequently-was that it was an appointed rather than an elected body. We hear passionate concern about the fact that an interim body of ATSIC may be appointed by people who are defending the continuation of the ADC which is permanently appointed. Conversely the NAC, which was elected, had some of those advantages but it had no power to make decisions about priorities and it did not have those obligations thrust upon it; therefore, it did not succeed and its members were frustrated. We find that the best principles of those two bodies together with devolution are brought together in the original ATSIC concept.

I regard the regional councils as the key to the success of ATSIC. There is no doubt from the consultations of the Senate Select Committee on the Administration of Aboriginal Affairs that the Aboriginal people were most attracted to the regional councils. I regard them as the key element of this development and I am not unhappy about the fact that we are proceeding slowly with the implementation of that key element because its success is vital to the success of the ATSIC project.

The other thing I want to say-I will come back to it subsequently-is that ATSIC will force Aboriginal people to make hard choices. I have quoted previously in the Parliament the former French Prime Minister Pierre Mendes-France who once said:
To govern is to choose.

It is about making hard choices. As the ATSIC task force put it in a submission to the Senate Select Committee, this scheme presents a challenge to the leadership of the Aboriginal community. To the extent that it provides government with professional objective advice, it will obtain access to information not otherwise available and obtain the opportunity to influence from inside the public sector and the development of government policy as it affects Aboriginal people. So those are the principles that underline the original Bill. I believe that the implementation of these principles has been substantially enhanced by the report of the Senate Select Committee and the Government's response to it.

I want to refer briefly to three main areas before concentrating on one of them. Those three areas are: accountability, the Institute of Aboriginal Studies, and electoral boundaries and procedures. I do not think I will have time to speak at length about the electoral boundaries and procedures. I simply say that they are a substantial improvement on the original proposals and should be able to work effectively. I have faith in the capacity of the Australian Electoral Commission to implement them effectively. The Australian Electoral Commission seems to find these proposals acceptable. I support the preservation of the separate role of the Institute of Aboriginal Studies, which is a body operating here in my own constituency. I thought it made a sensible submission. The Committee supported it, and I am pleased that the Government adopted our recommendation.

I want to spend more time talking about the question of accountability. One of the myths that are being perpetrated about ATSIC is that in some way the money is going to disappear, that the elected Commission is going to have control of $800m of the taxpayers' money to do with as it wishes, to have some sort of bonanza or blow-out with the money. ATSIC expenditures will be subject to all the normal public sector accountability measures. ATSIC will be audited by the Auditor-General. Most importantly of all, an office of evaluation and audit will be established within ATSIC to undertake ongoing evaluation and internal audit work and to report to the Commission and the Minister on evaluation matters. ATSIC will get its money by parliamentary appropriation. The Minister will have to approve, by approving the estimates, that money going to ATSIC, and the Minister, of course, will remain accountable to this Parliament for that money.

The most important thing is the establishment of the office of evaluation and audit, which will be able to undertake regular evaluations and audits of all the Commission's programs and officers and report to the Minister and the Commission regularly and to the Parliament annually; and, as I have said, all expenditure by ATSIC will be audited by the Auditor-General. Over and above that, because of that question of accountability to Parliament, the expenditures will be reviewed by this Senate through its Estimates committees twice a year. We all know the capacity for effective scrutiny and/or mischief which can follow from Senate Estimates committees. I will refer to some of that in a moment, but I do not want to diverge from the important things I want to say about accountability. The accountability proposals as originally envisaged were fairly orthodox accountability provisions, but I am pleased that they have been enhanced. I think this Bill goes a long way towards providing a new standard of accountability for taxpayers' funds and is something that is worthy of consequent consideration in other areas. Those are the things that I want to outline initially in talking about the case for ATSIC-the principles, the concepts, the way in which it will be implemented, and the question of accountability.

In the limited time I have I want to respond to some of the Opposition's attacks. Firstly, there was the old argument, with which I have some sympathy, that `if it's not broke don't mend it'. It is not a bad aphorism, but entirely inappropriate. My colleague Senator McKiernan, and subsequently Senator Coulter, talked very effectively about why we should not be complacent about saying, `This system is working all right; it does not need to be changed in terms of outcomes'. The problems confronted by Aboriginal people in Australia are so profound that it is unbelievable to me that people can say `If it's not broke don't mend it' as a case against change within the administration of Aboriginal affairs.

I do not want to duplicate that. There is little enough time to have a bit of fun in a speech reiterating what one's colleagues have already said, and I think Senator McKiernan said that well. What amuses me about that argument is that the very people who say `If it's not broke don't mend it' have for months in this Parliament been making impassioned speeches about how outrageous the Aboriginal affairs structures in this country are, making attacks upon the very bodies which currently constitute the structure of Aboriginal affairs and which they say are not broke. For example, the attacks that have been made on the Aboriginal Development Commission have been vehement. I want to come back in a moment to the personal way they have been handled.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about Gerry's attack when he sacked them all?

—I want to deal with Senator Tambling's double standards about that soon enough. He should just be patient. Those opposite have attacked this body. I should not be above criticism; I have criticised them. But having attacked the Commission because they do not like the people on it, they have now launched attacks on various decisions that were actually made by the Commission as previously constituted-by the body they supported, the people they lauded. I do not criticise those people. I acknowledge, and I have acknowledged it in this Parliament in the debate on the previous report when it was presented, that the previous commissioners were honest people trying to do a good job. I do not challenge that, and I accept that that is an appropriate point to make here again. I have said it before. I only wish that those who thought Gerry Hand should say that about the previous people-and he never said the opposite-had not been the same people making malicious and continual allegations under parliamentary privilege about the current commissioners. If they applied to the current commissioners half the standard they said should be applied to the previous ones, the standard of debate in this Parliament would be substantially enhanced and the capacity for reasonable discussion of Aboriginal affairs would be significantly furthered.

SPEECH.PARA: I have only been in this Senate now for about 18 months, but I have been involved very closely in the administration and the observation of politics for 15 years. I have to say that I have never heard a less justified, more outrageous public remark by an elected member of any Parliament than Senator Tambling's black mafia of corruption allegation. What is worse is that he knew it was not true. Not only did everybody else in Australia know it was not true, he knew but he did not care. I accept the integrity of very many people on the other side of this chamber about Aboriginal affairs. We disagree with integrity about the best means of achieving basically agreed outcomes. I do not have any difficulty with that. If that were not the case, we would not need the Parliament. There are legitimate disagreements, and Aboriginal affairs is one of those issues that bring them to the fore. But I think there has been in this Parliament-and the black mafia of corruption allegation was the nadir of the depths to which debate can sink-a level of debate about this issue which has done the Parliament no good and has certainly not enhanced the standing of the people who made those comments. I am happy to say that I believe that will be reflected when the electorate gets a chance to make its judgment.

I want to talk in another way about the Aboriginal Development Commission. One of the concerns that have been expressed is that ATSIC should not proceed because it leads to the abolition of the ADC, and the ADC has significant merits. There have been some merits in it, but I refer to two judgments made by the Auditor-General in reviewing it-not sordid personal criticisms about whether somebody made a mistake with a petty cash docket but substantial concerns about the nature of the organisation and whether in 1989 and for the rest of this century it is the appropriate structure for the conduct of economic enterprise on behalf of Aboriginal people. Firstly, the Auditor-General said:

One might also add that the ADC is hardly a commercial organisation. If there is a commercial organisation out there competing with it, that is giving grants and low interest loans, we have not found it. Indeed, if there were one in competition commercially with it, there would probably be no need for the ADC.

But I reiterate that the ADC is hardly a commercial organisation. I think that is true, even though it has done many good things. The Auditor-General showed up another fundamental flaw in the ambit of the ADC's responsibility. He was talking about one of the very good decisions that the ADC made when it provided capital for Yeperenye Pty Ltd for what it saw as the future benefit of Aboriginals, and I think correctly. The Auditor-General has expressed concern not that it was a bad investment but that it may have been outside the terms of reference of the ADC. No-one said that the investment was made other than with propriety and in this instance proper auditing.

The point that is made is that the Commission may not have been entitled to make that decision. If that interpretation is correct, and I think it is, it establishes a clear shortcoming in the ADC legislation which will be overcome by the Commercial Development Corporation set up under ATSIC. That limitation will no longer exist and the assistance to enterprises on behalf of Aboriginal people will be liberated from that constraint.

That is not to say that the ADC when it was first envisaged was necessarily a bad idea. It did quite a good job in its day. It is simply time to move on from an organisation which gets its management from appointed commissioners.
