The concept of self-management and self-determination is determined not only by the Aboriginality of the people making the decisions but also by the process by which they are selected.

Senator Boswell in what I thought would have been a good speech in support of ATSIC-had he fully understood what he was saying-made some significant criticisms about the problems that arise when bodies are run by hand picked appointed commissioners. It was quite an effective contribution. It highlighted why I believe we should be moving on from a body run by hand picked commissioners to a body run by elected representatives. That is one of the reasons why the ADC was a good idea in its time and it is now time to move on.

I would like now to refer to one other important area of the Bill which has not had the consideration that is deserves and which, when it was considered in the public domain in representations before the Committee, was either misrepresented hysterically or misunderstood totally, or both. I refer to the preamble. The majority report of the Select Committee concluded:
A preamble is of no legal force by itself. It is generally treated by the courts as an aid to ascertaining the intent of the Parliament in making a particular piece of legislation.

That is not a particularly wonderful perception by those of us who are the majority of the Parliament. It is a very straightforward comment. Everybody knows, or should know, that it is true. The Acts Interpretation Act makes it crystal clear. Some people have probably been misled and actually believe that in some way this preamble will have profound legal ramifications but that is only because they have been seriously misled by some of the more extreme critics. I will not name those people who came before the Select Committee because they would only revel in the publicity. They do not mind being on the front page even if it is on the basis of inaccuracies.

But the preamble does not have any legal force. That is clearly so. There is nothing in the words of the preamble that the Parliament should have the slightest concern about passing. We have already passed a resolution affirming our commitment as a Parliament to Australia's indigenous people. I do not see why we find it so difficult to recognise in a symbolically significant way through this preamble the facts of history and the Australian people's commitment to the recognition and protection of the rights of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people and the measures to overcome their disadvantage. That is what the preamble sets out to do. It is not a revolutionary Marxist doctrine. It is not a new manifesto. It is a reasonable statement that we think the Australian Parliament should be prepared to make on behalf of the Australian people in this Bill. I am happy to support it.

I would like to draw my comments to a conclusion by saying that there are no simple solutions to the problems we have created for Aboriginal Australians over the past 201 years. There is no one initiative which will right all the wrongs-not ATSIC, not the ADC, nor any other. The best we can hope for as legislators and as Australians is that each step we take is a step in the right direction, and I believe ATSIC is such a step. It builds on the experience of the National Aboriginal Conference and the ADC and others. This Bill shows that we have learnt at least some of the lessons which that experience has taught us.

I reiterate that ATSIC does not provide a hand-out to Aboriginal Australians. It provides them with a challenge to recognise the hard choices which have to be made, to set priorities, to accept responsibility for the decisions which are made. I believe they can and will meet that challenge. Therefore I support this package of legislation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tambling Sen G.E.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are addressing this very important package of legislation-the Ab- original and Torres Strait Islander Commission Bill 1989 and related Bills-that looks at the creation of the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission (ATSIC). This legislation has spent a long time in being developed and looked at. I would venture to say that every honourable senator has taken a keen interest in it. I think all of us are sympathetic to the plight and needs of Ab- original people and the natural progression and development that should be taking place so that Aborigines can play their proper role and take their proper part in the Australian community. I am disappointed that the contributions to this debate so far by Senators McKiernan and McMullan have not really spent much time justifying the legislation or going into the details of it.

SPEECH.PARA: I would like to take time tonight to highlight many of the issues that I think still need to be very seriously addressed. The consultation about the ATSIC proposal has been incomplete and inadequate and I believe that Senator Peter Baume in his initial speech addressed this very keenly and very interestingly. We need to remember that in May 1988 and on a number of other occasions the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Mr Hand) dismissed commissioners of the Ab- original Development Commission (ADC) and a number of other Aboriginal leaders in various places from their particular positions. These commissioners were shamefully treated. It has been demonstrated through many of the inquiries that other Aboriginal leaders were harassed and intimidated. The events of the past year have demonstrated that the administration of Aboriginal affairs has been shown to be in serious disarray.

ATSIC would do nothing to improve matters because the ATSIC concept is unsound. The Bill is deficient structurally and in detailed drafting, and accountability will not be assured. It has already been quite widely indicated that there will be amendments to this legislation-considerable amendments that will take some time to deal with-both from the Opposition and from the Australian Democrats. Sadly it is the Aboriginal people and the general body of Australian taxpayers who will be worst served by ATSIC compared with the existing arrangements. We must question the motives of the Government and the Minister.

I am not backing away from the fact that during the last 12 months I have been aggressive in my questioning of the Minister and of the Government in relation to the Aboriginal affairs portfolio. I believe quite firmly that the Minister has been involved in a whole series of deceptions and lies, scandals and issues that will not go away and that he has very seriously failed to consider the real legal implications of ATSIC.

ATSIC is not just the isolated instance of Mr Hand's neglect. We need to look at the Minister's relationship with the land councils, the way in which he is adjusting the funds of the Aboriginals Benefit Trust Account, the dissatisfaction that has been shown by Aboriginals, particularly in the Northern Territory, where there are six land council movements breaking away from the traditional organisations. The way in which the Minister has handled the issue of stock routes and excisions for living areas in the Northern Territory and on pastoral leases has been highlighted time and again in the media. Let me quote the former Secretary of the Department of Aboriginal Affairs, Charles Perkins, as reported in the Canberra Times of yesterday:

The Minister had surrounded himself with advisers all of a similar character to himself. They knew what was going on. They were in constant contact and discussions with the Central and Northern Land Councils.

What we have now is a most unsatisfactory situation in terms of some of the people ripping off Aboriginal affairs . . . vagabonds and hooligans, self-elected and self-seeking, and pretending to represent Aborigines here and overseas.

Charles Perkins was reported yesterday as having made those remarks about the Minister, Mr Hand. Mr Hand is the Deng Xiaoping of Australia and what he is developing is a totalitarian state in the heart of a democracy. If we draw the comparisons with China that we are all now familiar with we see, firstly, that there is a power struggle within the leadership of the Australian Labor Party. It has been obvious that there have been deep divisions between Minister Hand and the senior Ministers, the Minister for Justice, Senator Tate, and the Minister for the Arts, Tourism and Territories, Mr Holding. That has been well demonstrated. Secondly, the power is concentrated in the hands of a few radical Aborigines and a privileged political elite has been set up. This will be compounded by the fact that this clique of land bosses includes people like Foley, Mansell, and Yunupingu. They are now advising the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs instead of the Department and the ADC. Interestingly, the clique has most to gain from ATSIC.

Thirdly, there is the comparison we need to draw of promoting the concept of a class struggle. Totalitarian states use the common good as a way of suppressing dissenting voices. The ATSIC structure is similar in that it promotes the homogeneity of Aborigines rather than recognising fundamental differences between the urban and tribal people. It also fails to take into account the aspirations and the needs of individual groups and potential conflicts of interest in regions and zones.

Fourthly, there is the perceived and demonstrated maladministration in high places. The Estimates of 1988 and 1989 high- lighted maladministration in the Aboriginal Affairs portfolio. Now Aborigines and non- Aborigines are openly suspicious about ATSIC, a structure not fully accountable to Parliament. Minister Hand has created a civil war in the Aboriginal constituency. He has turned one Aborigine against the other. The argument is not about racism; it is about accountability. The Minister has also turned one sector of the community against the other.

Let us quickly retrace the ground. Since December 1987 when the Minister tabled in the Parliament the document Foundations for the Future he went out on the boardwalk with wide consultations. In March-April-May 1988 consultations were held around the community. He then presented mark 2 of the amendments to Foundations for the Future in the Parliament and to the Aboriginal community. The Senate Select Committee on the Administration of Aboriginal Affairs was set up. In September and October 1988 we had the Estimates, resulting in a number of inquiries which came down with reports. We then had mark 3 of the ATSIC proposals, again with no consultation. In August, of course, we have ended up with the ATSIC Bill.

TALK.START.PARA: —If we observe that since July 1987 Mr Hand has ignored the advice of the Department and the ADC, both of which were working well, we see that the Department has been rendered ineffective by the administrative style of the Minister. Its officers have been seeking transfers and retirements at an unprecedented rate, as has been well demonstrated. Many of the people from the Department and the ADC who were involved have been put under undue pressure ever since. This is at a time when we have been defining the plight and the need of Aboriginal communities.

SPEECH.PARA: After 20 years of centralised control of Aboriginal affairs in Australia the Federal Government has proposed another system of Aboriginal representation and administration. That system has the potential of furthering the self-seeking interests of small pressure groups, most of which are urban based, to entrench the paternalistic bureaucracy, to ignore the responsibilities of elected government and to be too remote from the very communities it is meant to benefit, rather than bringing about much needed improvements in health, housing, education, employment and welfare for Aboriginal people.

ATSIC complicates what is already a difficult problem. In the last 10 years billions of dollars have been spent with no result. I stress that money is not the answer. The answer is to be found in numeracy, literacy, health and dignity. The heart of this issue boils down to self-determination as distinct from self-management and the difference between them. Self-determination is a political concept. Self-management is an enterprise-based concept. There is no real disagreement that Aboriginal self-management is desirable and essential. The more that Aborigines assume responsibility for their own lives, jobs and enterprises, the better. We need to compare improved education and improved quality of life with the Minister's preoccupation with power and programs.

If we compare Aboriginal development with World Bank measurements of the economic development in the Third World, we find that although income standards are comparable between Aboriginal Australians and those countries which are considered to be middle developing by the World Bank, it must be understood that the majority of Aboriginals have not reached a basic standard of living, education, housing, and employment. Until this has been achieved, there is no way that ATSIC in its present form can work. We must remember that Aboriginal life expectancy is 20 years less than that for other Australians. Aboriginal infant mortality is still nearly three times higher than for other Australians. Aboriginal unemployment is four times the national average. Average Aboriginal income is two-thirds that of other Australians. The number of Aborigines with post-secondary qualifications is less than a quarter of the national average. Aboriginal imprisonment rates in some States are as much as 16 times higher than for other Australians. After six years of the Labor Government there is no measure of improvement.

What moves me and concerns me is that the composition of ATSIC is highly likely to facilitate a situation where the interests of traditional Aboriginal people will be subsumed by the radically different aspirations, pursuits and needs of urban Aboriginal people. I will quote from the Aboriginal Cultural Foundation which represents a broad range of traditional and tribal communities, which said that it feared that the power of the Northern Land Council would be tied to ATSIC. The Foundation said:
We want the Government to find a way to give a proper level of funding to the foundation every year, directly from the Government, without the interference of non-tribal Aboriginal people.
It wants a two-year delay and asks the Senate not to pass the Bill. It said:
After one year of so-called consultation, we tribal people have almost no idea what this new commission is all about.

Similarly, there is the concern of so many Northern Territory constituents, both Aboriginal and those who are not of the Aboriginal community. Representations to the Senate Select Committee stood out as needing to be looked at very carefully. The Northern Territory Government submission to the Select Committee said:

. . . the Commonwealth's answer to that question thus far is that `the redirection could be effected now, but trust us'. What the State and Territory jurisdictions need to know is what is the intention and what safeguards might there be against dramatic erosion of current State and Territory responsibilities and funding. Further, in the event of a dispute arising on interpretation of Commonwealth state financial relationship, which side would the Commonwealth favour, the State or ATSIC.

This is a major issue in the Northern Territory. Mr Acting Deputy President, I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard an extract from the Northern Territory Government's submission to the Senate Select Committee.

The Community Government system is an innovative form of local government specifically aimed at small remote communities, the majority of which are comprised of Aboriginal Territorians. TALK.START.PARA: —On the constitutional issues that are so terribly important I also seek leave to incorporate an article entitled Australia's Proposed Race Law by Professor Colin Howard.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The article read as follows-
AUSTRALIA'S PROPOSED RACE LAW
Colin Howard
A Bill currently before the Federal Parliament would establish a separate system of political representation for blacks.

The Australian Constitution includes a power for the Australian Parliament to make laws on the subject of the people of any race for whom it is deemed necessary to make special laws. This clause of the Constitution raises the question whether it is right and proper to make laws by reference to people's race at all. The widespread public assumption that such a legislative power is for the benefit of groups of people described by the imprecise term `race' has no legal foundation. The power can be just as well be used to oppress people identified by race as to assist them. But this is only the beginning of the problem. What is a race? It seems easy to distinguish between, for example, black Africans, Arabs, Polynesians and Chinese on a racial basis. But this line of thought will not get you very far. Difficulties arise when you consider groups of people who have some characteristics in common and others which are very different. Are Greeks a different race from Turks, Italians from Icelanders, Iranians from Iraqis, Zulus from Shona, English from Scots? Are the Jews a race? Only arbitrary answers can be given to such questions because each of them depends on what one means by race, and there is no agreement on that subject.

When one considers how vociferous the Hawke Government has been about racially-based laws in South Africa, it is worth remembering that no one has suggested that we repudiate the power to make laws with respect to race. It can be argued that we are different, we do not make laws directed against the people of any race and that any such policy would be politically unacceptable. As a justification this is a weak reed. The current danger is not that the power will be used to make laws which are crudely and overtly directed against one minority group in the community. The danger is that in the pursuit of a course of action believed to be good, damage will be done to our entire social structure by way of racially-based laws because nobody perceives what their underlying significance is.

There is, before the Australian Parliament at the moment, a Bill for an Act entitled the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commissioner Bill, or ATSIC Bill for short. According to the Government this is a good thing because it represents the first major attempts in our history to provide a formal framework through which Aborigines and Torres Strait Islanders can influence government decisions which affect them and their interests. The Bill has for the time being been sidelined by the uproar about the Aboriginal Development Commissioner and the dismissal of Mr Charles Perkins.

If and when the Bill comes to life again, one thing above all should be squarely confronted. It is that the Bill aims to set up an organisation closely resembling a mini-parliament for the sole use and advantage of Aborigines and Torres Strait Islanders. What this will mean is that a section of the Australian population will have been singled out by reference to race for separate representation based on a separate voting roll. If anyone suggests that this resembles apartheid, the answer will no doubt be made that in the first place the Bill does not deprive Aborigines or Torres Strait Islanders of any rights they may already enjoy, but on the contrary adds to those rights, and that the Government is trying to help them, not repress them. The fact remains that they are being singled out, and the process enshrined in law, on undisguisedly racial grounds.

Some of these consequences may not be welcome. Among other things, a body will have been brought into existence with which the Federal Government can negotiate a treaty analogous to the Treaty of Waitangi reached between whites and Maoris in New Zealand a century-and-a-half ago. Although there are supporters in this country of the idea of a treaty, there are others who legitimately have misgivings about it. It can be said, for example, that land rights have caused enough trouble already, without giving one side of the argument the status of a quasi-national independent community. It can be said also that in the long-run it is folly to enact a racial law which manifestly divides Australians instead of uniting them. The New Zealand experience has not been an entirely happy one, to put it mildly.

It is a fundamental cause for unease that, contrary to our professional political ideology, the ATSIC Bill, if it becomes law, will have revealed us as being as racist as anyone else. We should not be in the business of deliberately creating a sub-nation with a sub-parliament with enormous powers to claim land and other property as its own. Whatever the motives, this is a recipe for racial disaster.

The issue to be pursued is whether any of these, as with the DAA positions, have been upgraded without appropriate adjustments in responsibilities and workloads in the areas concerned. This being followed up as part of the classification audit program regarding implementation of the integrated office structure.
Public Service Commission, Reports on allegations about Personnel Management in the Department of Aboriginal Affairs, March 1989.
The following recommendations were made:
(a) In the absence of specific evidence, further investigation of alleged malpractice in the personnel management of DAA should not be pursued.
(b) A senior-level Task Force, supported by the seconded, expert officers should be established to assist DAA to improve its administration.

(c) The Task Force should report quarterly to the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs; its efforts should be comprehensively reviewed in DAA's Annual Reports tabled in the Parliament; and it should complete a ``sunset'' review after two years operation.
(d) The first priority of the Task Force should be to finalise DAA's long-outstanding Equal Employment Opportunity Program.
(e) Responsibilities and intentions in the areas of ``Aboriginalisation'' and ``criteria weighting'' should be clarified.
(f) All approved Government staffing policies in relation to Aboriginals should be consolidated into one booklet drawing on material in this report.

(g) Staff training and career development programs in DAA should be reviewed including consideration of a suggested new Aboriginal Staff Advancement Program for recruitment and development of talented Aboriginals at all levels.

(h) Consideration should be given to inclusion in the Code of Conduct and other Appropriate publications of an alert concerning patronage, etc, and the avoidance of conflicts of interest in staffing and other administrative matters affecting relatives and friends.
(i) The Merit Protection and Review Agency should be asked to organise special seminars for DAA staff on selections procedures, grievance rights, etc.
(j) The unions should be encouraged to play their full part in improving personnel practices and performance.
The Auditor-General, Special Audit Report, The Aboriginal Development Commission and the Department of Aboriginal Affairs, March 1989.
Conclusions regarding enterprise projects
Audit has shown (with except of Imparja Television) there were serious defects in the enterprise projects queried by Senator Tambling and other members of the Senate Estimates Committee E.
The Defective projects are the outcome of defective approval procedures and management controls within ADC.

The Audit found that ADC, in its concern to assist Aboriginals, has provided some of the funds under the enterprise programs in ways not authorised by the ADC Act. The ADC has occasionally been treated as a welfare program rather than a development program.
Audit's finding drew a hostile response from the ADC but this understand given the nature of the findings and the prospect of having significant administrative deficiencies exposed to wider scrutiny.
ADC enterprise program, is difficult to have successful outcomes; namely Aboriginals enabled to engage successfully in self-sustaining enterprises.
Accountability
ADC should be accountable for the way the money has been spent. The ADC's annual reports contain descriptive material but little information about the problems in the enterprise program.
The ADC's annual reports provide some detail of some grants provided for housing purposes but little information about people and organisations that have received enterprise grants or loans.

ADC's view overlooks the fact that its enterprise grants are in no sense commercial, that its enterprise loans are granted on concessionary terms and that both grants and loans are provided from public funds.

Disclosure of enterprise clients would avoid the speculation about the way in which funds are applied. Government bodies are likely to feel their responsibilities more keenly when their decisions are public.

ADC should also give more attention to the outcomes that the Parliament intended in the Act. It should identify the Aboriginals who have been able to engage in self-sustaining business enterprises, and the cost of ADC of achieving those successes. ADC should also be more forthcoming in its reports about the difficulties in achieving success and the reasons for failure. This information is necessary for the Minister and Parliament to make informed decisions about the program.
Audit recommends that the ADC should:

(a) disclose the names of people and organisations who receive enterprise loans and grants, together with details of the amount and purpose, and details of any significant increase or other change subsequently made, and
(b) disclose performance indicators of the success of the enterprise program in enabling Aboriginals to engage in self sustaining enterprises.
ABORIGINAL AND TORRES STRAIT ISLANDER COMMISSION WORKING PARTY ON CENTRAL OFFICE STRUCTURE
INTERIM REPORT - MAY 1989
1.3 SUMMARY OF MAIN FINDINGS AND RECOMMENDATIONS
(1) ATSIC will need to be properly resourced if it is to succeed as a vehicle for self-management as intended by the Government. ATSIC cannot be set up to fail.

(2) The staff savings envisaged by Dr McIver are not obtainable. The Bill itself and subsequent Government commitments have meant a degree of accountability for ATSIC of which Dr McIver could have had no knowledge.

(3) It will be possible, however, to limit the proportion of ATSIC staff employed in Central Office, as a proportion of the total resources, to a similar level to that envisaged by Dr McIver (30%). Our figure (34%) is not excessive as Central Office does not just consist of policy officers and their support staff. Some key client services are centralised (amongst others the incorporation of Councils and Associations, and aspects of CDEP/AEDP) and personnel and recruitment functions are centralised.

(4) The Working Party was unable to identify any function in DAA and the ADC that would not carry over under ATSIC. It was possible, however, to identify a reduction in positions, due to the amalgamation of functions performed in both existing organisations and to general increase in efficiency. The number of permanent positions required in ATSIC is even below the depleted numbers currently employed in DAA and the ADC leading to some staff savings initially, and the possibility of further reductions after 12 months.

(5) The Working Party noted that ATSIC Central Office would involve a number of additional functions (e.g. the Housing Fund and Land Fund to be administered as separate funds, the greater emphasis on training as a consequence of the Prime Minister's 11 April 1989 statement, and the consequences of the reduced role of State Offices). It has been possible to accommodate the additional functional responsibilities, whilst recommending an overall staff reduction.

(6) A structure of 312 positions has been recommended to provide the absolute minimum effective workforce to ensure the successful establishment of ATSIC. This structure is detailed in charts accompanying this Report. A further 15 temporary positions will be required during the establishment period.

(7) The workload on ATSIC will be highest for ATSIC staff in the first years of its operation. Some temporary positions have been included in the structure but the establishment should be reviewed after the first year of the Commission's operation to identify further staff savings.

(8) The staffing figures recommended by the Working Party however, are believed to be the absolute minimum for ATSIC's initial operation. If staffing is to be reduced further to a pre-determined maximum number of positions for reasons not associated with the administration of Aboriginal Affairs, then functions must be shed.

(9) Although the Working Party based its proposed organisation on a top structure agreed by Finance, there are obvious disparities between Division and Branch responsibilities. In particular, the Policy Development Division is overloaded.
(10) The Working Party puts forward for consideration two alternative models using three Divisions and the same number of SES officers, which better balance the Divisions.
(11) There is justification for a four Divisional structure, and the Working Party puts this model forward as the preferred option.
(12) The recent announcements about the Office of Evaluation and Audit have not been comprehensively addressed in this Report, and will need to be the subject of further work.
INQUIRY BY MR A. C. MENZIES INTO ALLEGATIONS AS TO THE ADMINISTRATION OF ABORIGINAL AFFAIRS
Final Report
June 1989
Recommendations
(1) The procedures of the D.A.A. should be examined to ensure that:

(a) not only when a formal decision is made by the Secretary or his delegate as to grant of funds for drug abuse programs but also when a substantive decision is made to recommend to the Minister the making of such a grant, all relevant matters are noted and taken into account;
(b) while the Secretary may deal directly with a junior officer in a particular matter, more senior officers have a clear understanding as to their roles in regard to any matters to dealt with; and
(c) incoming communications are promptly placed on relevant files;
(2) Mr Woods should be counselled as to his failure to alert Mr Perkins on 11 March 1988 as to a report by the State Office being outstanding in respect of the Downs' application; and

(3) Disciplinary action as provided under section 57 of the Public Service Act in respect of Secretaries of Departments and certain unattached officers is not called for in the case of Mr Perkins, but the contents of this Chapter should be drawn to his attention.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like the Senate to take time to review that list of recommendations and compare them with the comments that Senator McKiernan made here earlier today. He glossed over them as if they had no content and there were no important issues to be addressed. Those recommendations, as honourable senators will see when they peruse Hansard, require a lot of attention and a great deal of interest. Let me refer to the Menzies report, which was tabled in the Parliament several days ago by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke). The Prime Minister himself conceded that Mr Menzies found `cases of questionable practice'. The Prime Minister went on to say that the final report `brings out some further shortcomings in administration in the area of Aboriginal affairs-in some cases shortcomings for which Mr Perkins, as the departmental Secretary over much of the period, has to bear the ultimate responsibility'. However, the Prime Minister also acknowledged that `there were deficiencies in systems and procedures going well beyond the realm of Mr Perkins' personal responsibility'. If that is not an attack by the Prime Minister on the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Mr Hand) I would like to know what is. Let me repeat his remark:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . there were deficiencies in systems and procedures going well beyond the realm of Mr Perkins' personal responsibility.

Beyond Mr Perkins's responsibility? It is on the desk of the Minister. That is who the Prime Minister was questioning at that time. Included in the recommendations that I have incorporated in Hansard today were the recommendations of an interim report of a working party on central office structure with regard to ATSIC. This report was commissioned by the Minister as part of the ATSIC task force. The document that I have is the interim report dated May 1989 entitled Working Party on Central Office Structure. I seek leave to table that report.
Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —This report is signed by five employees of either the Department of Aboriginal Affairs or the Aboriginal Development Commission: R. J. Beadman, S. Dalton, E. van Oosten, N. Baxendell and P. Golack. I believe that S. Dalton and N. Baxendell are union officials who were invited to participate in the preparation of the report. The report is most interesting. It was released in May 1989-only five months, I remind the Senate, before the date that we are told ATSIC is to be up and running. It was an interim report on ATSIC's central office structure.

SPEECH.PARA: The report makes interesting, even striking, reading. We see experienced officials struggling with the realities of public administration and the Minister's airy-fairy theories of self-determination. In a masterpiece of understated but scornful despair these officers, including the union officials, point out a number of home truths. For example, they say that the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission Bill `reveals the complexity of the ongoing central office rule'. Secondly, the report says:
The McIver philosophy of a greatly reduced central office has not been reflected in the Bill, which creates additional work.
Thirdly, it says:
We are not aware of any particular attention being given to remote area allowances packages so as to increase the attractiveness of such posts.
This was five months before the whole shambles is due to get started. Fourthly, the report says there is:
. . . a potential conflict between the broader objectives of ATSIC and the cost savings objectives under the machinery of Government changes of 1987.
Faced then with the administrative and organisational mess that will be ATSIC, the report speculates that the Minister and his advisers who dreamt up the scheme might hold the view that:
. . . a deliberative and decisive reduction in both staff numbers will in itself lead to a devolution of power to the grass roots.
That is, only by weakening the effectiveness of the central administration can decisions be taken in communities.

We see here clearly the absurd bottom-up theory of management by self-determination. One might have hoped that by now the Minister would have learned something about the political rorts of management weakness in Aboriginal affairs. Not a bit of it! As the report points out, this Bill `does not provide for the total devolution of all power to communities'. The reason is clear, says the report, which states:
Decisions will be made underlined by the Minister in a manner not dissimilar to many decisions now made by him.
All that will change. The officials disparagingly conclude that things will get harder, more complex and more political. Here is the final masterpiece of understatement:
ATSIC is of itself unlikely to lead to a reduction in parliamentary interest in Aboriginal affairs.

The structures and processes in this Bill, the naive and simplistic reliance on white men's European dreams of what Aboriginal people are really like, the anarchic faith in grass-roots democracy, are no more than the plainest signs of a new paternalism. The Minister and his coterie of theorists know best what Aborigines should be like: forget about good management and accountability to the Parliament or to the Aboriginal community; forget about the machinery of government reforms so beloved by the Prime Minister; just in case something goes wrong, put in provisions to give the Minister control over everything and everybody; then make the chief executive officer, the Minister's pimp, tell on the very people he is supposed to work for.

The report that I have just tabled shows everyone just how muddled and confused the ATSIC concept is. As Charles Perkins said just this week, it is flawed fatally and fundamentally. Small wonder those who wrote the report warn:
ATSIC cannot be set up to fail.

Just as Charles Perkins is now free to speak his mind-and he has done so in the last few days-the officers who have signed the report would, I am sure, have expressed themselves much more frankly if they had not been bound by the Minister's demand for total obedience to his will, the style that I believe has been so indicative of the way in which Minister Hand has conducted his portfolio.

Let me draw to a conclusion the issues that I see becoming a problem. ATSIC will fail to meet its objectives because of a failure to achieve a consensus amongst the very people the proposal is designed to assist, Aboriginal Australians. Let us all ask the question: What will life be like under ATSIC? The administrative problems seen in the past will only get worse and Aborigines will cop the blame. Racism will be entrenched institutionally-by, if one can believe it, a Labor Government. The interests of traditional Aboriginal people will be subsumed. There will be a lack of accountability that will be totally confusing if these proposals are adopted.

The real needs for disadvantaged people in the community-health, education, welfare-will get bogged down in a shockingly socialist nightmare. Really that is what Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission (ATSIC) is all about.

The shadow Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, Warwick Smith, the Federal member for Bass, released a press statement the other day in which he examined very carefully the issues that had to be addressed with regard to ATSIC. Mr Smith came to the conclusion that the coalition must continue to oppose this Bill. The press release states:
. . . Mr Smith said ATSIC:
would establish an untried, experimental and radical structure that ignored existing local and State organisations,
would restrict the influence of local aboriginal communities, and
would give untried regional groups responsibility for the massive allocation of monies to fund a confusing mishmash of welfare and commercial objectives.

ATSIC does not address the principles and the proposals that I am sure are entrenched in the Labor Party's platform. ATSIC is a factional win for the socialist left. It is pushing a particular type of administration that is totally against the wishes of Aboriginal people and does not recognise their cultural needs and special structures. As I have moved around my electorate in the Northern Territory I have continually struck questioning and bewilderment about the proposal. This is despite the early exhaustive consultative program that the Minister and many of the staff of the Department attempted to engage in.

The problems of Aboriginal communities throughout Australia are complex. They cannot be tied up in simple little bundles and put into simple systems like this. The degree of sophistication of urban Aboriginal people is changing dramatically. The degree of sophistication in the traditional communities is changing drastically. I believe the influence of television on many of those communities in recent years, as they have been able to receive satellite television communication, has changed their awareness. The Aboriginal communities, whilst very complex and very disadvantaged, are also reaching a very sophisticated understanding of the politics of this particular issue.

During the recess I visited a number of communities in my electorate and I had representations from a number of Aboriginal organisations and groups, and individual Aboriginal leaders. None of those that I went to see, or that came to me, would support with enthusiasm 100 per cent or even 50 per cent of the proposals that are being pushed by Mr Hand. I say `pushed' because that is what is really happening. For some committed, radical reason the Minister, Mr Hand, is trying to create structures and advances that are principally not acceptable to the Aboriginal constituency that we seek to represent. As I said in the main part of my speech, I believe this will be a racially oriented structure that we will live to regret if established in the form proposed by Mr Hand.

Obviously the debate in the committee stage in the Senate over the next couple of weeks will be very complex. The fact that you, Mr Acting Deputy President, will be presenting about 158 amendments on behalf of the Opposition shows the seriousness of the issue to which we will have to address our attention. I know that you have paid particular attention to the way in which this can be facilitated for constructive debate by the Senate and that you have been able to package the amendments so that we will not speak on 158 individual amendments but, perhaps, on some 20 packages of amendments which we will be able to consider properly and efficiently. I challenge every honourable senator to consider most seriously every amendment that is put forward by the Australian Democrats and the Opposition. I believe that in the past two years the Australian Democrats and the Opposition senators who have taken a keen interest in this matter have spent their time fruitfully representing the Aboriginal constituency of Australia.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tonight we are discussing a further addition to the legislative packages which have come through this place over the years regarding the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people. I say at the outset that I think it is a pity, and probably symptomatic of what has happened in the past, that no Aboriginals are here in this chamber debating this Bill. When I first came into this chamber Senator Bonner, who was the only Aboriginal ever elected to this Federal Parliament, was here and I think his contributions were always listened to with great care and consideration because of his Aboriginality and also because of the fact that he had been able to reflect in depth upon his race and upbringing and was able to make very concrete and pertinent suggestions on where we might go in the future.

SPEECH.PARA: In an endeavour to overcome the lack of Aboriginal representation in Parliament there has been a very strong and, I believe, a very important press to have adequate consultation with Aboriginal people about each move that is made in this area. While it is easy to say we should have adequate consultation, it is a far more difficult thing to achieve. I represented this portfolio for my Party for six years and I found it an incredibly difficult task to come to grips with even the simple questions as to what precisely was the Aboriginal view. If one is seeking a single view one will never find it. There are many views among Aboriginal people. They differ from place to place, from group to group, and even within single communities. I was able to discover a vigorous and well articulated debate on what one would have thought might be a single approach which would have been easily discovered. In other words, the Aboriginal people, in terms of their political response, are as diverse as is the white community and as interested in pushing the views they have so that those views will be the final views.

That difficulty is precisely the reason why government after government has sought to establish some mechanism by which the Aboriginal peoples could come to a final compromise view which they might present, and that view might be able to be taken by this Parliament as the consensus, or majority, view of the people of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Island origin. The Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Bill is another attempt at that procedure. Whereas, when contemplating that, one might have thought that was a pretty easy thing to do, one only has to think about the history of the various groups that have been established, first by the Fraser Government and then by the Hawke Government, to see that that approach is not necessarily the simple way out either. Each of those groups had extraordinary difficulties. They often fell into disrepute amongst Aboriginal people-again, I think, often on the basis that they were not as responsive as they should have been. Often many Aboriginal people felt that they were not as representative as they should have been or that they did not represent in an Aboriginal way the views that should have been put.

If one believes that with the passage of this Bill a magic wand will be waved and the problems solved, one is naive in the extreme. This is a further attempt by white Australia to come to grips with its ancestry and what I prefer to call the white problem rather than the Aboriginal problem. An Aboriginal friend who tutored me in this said that Aboriginals do not have any difficulty being Aboriginals; it is the whites who have problems with Aboriginals being Aboriginals.

We in an all-white Parliament are trying to set down what is essentially again a white structure for Aboriginal people. I am unable to say whether this will have more or less success than previous attempts. I hope that it will be more successful. I fear that it might suffer the same fate as previous attempts. But I do not think that because of the possibilities of failure we can give up the attempt to seek a structure by which the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Island people are able to have a far larger, more effective and more influential say in the determination of their future than they have at present. We have to keep on with the attempts, inadequate though they may be.

I am quite sure that the establishment of this Commission, in the form in which this Bill is presented, will not see out twelve months, and certainly not 18 months. There will have to be immediate modifications. If there are not immediate modifications, one would realise that it had been a failure. We are attempting to let the Aboriginal people take control of their future. I am sure that the type of organisation they will eventually come up with will not look very much like the structure we are seeking to impose here. It will have to have some of the elements. Undoubtedly the element of accountability will be continuously maintained. I say by way of parenthesis that I feel very strongly that any approach we take on the funding of this should be based on the principle of compensation and not on the principle of hand-outs. I know that that is a minority view in this country, but unless it becomes the majority view I believe no progress will be made. True acceptance of the historical realities will be achieved only when there is acceptance that payments are by way of compensation.

I do not want to go into detail on a number of the contributions in the debate so far but I will pick up one point with regard to the view about where we are going and where our emphasis should be. Interwoven in a number of the speeches that have been made so far is the view that we ought really to be concentrating on the schools or the hospitals or some other particular item. I totally disagree with that view. Again, the fundamental flaw in that is that it is seeing the Aboriginal situation as though it were merely a variation of a white situation, and it is not. If one cares to sit down and listen long enough, one finds that the basic problem is with the historical land base. That is why I and my Party have never resiled from wholehearted support for Aboriginal land rights as being the central and fundamental issue that has to be faced. We can fudge our way around it and we can throw money at the problem. We can look at the Aboriginal infant mortality rate, appalling as it is, and say, `Now that's the problem we really ought to be concentrating on'. I am not suggesting we should leave it alone. We need to do work in all those areas, but if we ignore the fundamental underlying cause and that is the dispossession of the Aboriginal peoples of their land, then we will never come to grips with their history or with our history.

I suppose I have a pessimistic approach to the Commission. I see it as another step, hopefully forward. But one would have to be a super-optimist, looking at 200 years of black-white relations in this country, to think that this is the be-all and end-all. One hopes that it will be a step forward and that some of the matters outlined in the preamble, of which more will be said in the committee stage by my colleague Senator Coulter, might actually be taken on board; not simply another motion passed by this Senate. This has happened before. For example, the historic motion moved by former Senator Bonner, unanimously supported by this chamber, for the first time accepted the historic dispos- session. Let us hope that it is not just a matter of another motion being passed but rather that in voting for and accepting those types of propositions they are actually believed. If they are believed, we will have to go a long way further than this Bill goes. It merely scrapes the surface. In a sense, I would prefer it not to be passed and just simply add to the history of the relationships between our peoples in this country another broken promise, another lot of rhetoric, another lot of `Aren't these fine feelings on our behalf? That salves our conscience and now let's get on with doing what we have done up to date.' I hope they will be believed, or let us not do it at all.

The objectives on page 3 of the Bill, in recognition of the past dispossession of the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Island peoples and their present disadvantaged position in Australian society, are seeking to do four things. The first objective is to ensure maximum participation of Aboriginals and Torres Strait Islanders in the formulation and implementation of government policies that affect them. I have not heard any dissent from that in any of the speeches tonight by anyone in any political party. Let us hope that that at least is true. The second objective is to promote the development of self-management and self-sufficiency amongst Aboriginals and Torres Strait Islanders. Again, I have not heard any contribution to the debate on this Bill which dissents from that objective. The third objective is to further the economic, social and cultural developments of Aboriginal peoples and Torres Strait Islanders. Again, there has been no dissent from that objective by anybody in any party. The fourth is to ensure cooperation in the formulations and implementation of policies affecting the Aboriginal people and Torres Strait Islanders by Commonwealth, State, Territory and local governments without detracting from the responsibilities of State, Territory and local governments to provide services. Again, there has been no dissent from anybody in any party. In other words, the four objectives of the Bills are shared by all.

What the dispute is about, and what the dispute will be about in the committee stages, is the means by which those objectives are to be implemented. From my perspective, that is a step forward. It is nice to be able to say that we have gone past the disputes over those objectives in this place. However, I do not think that we should lull ourselves into a false sense of security. Each of those four objectives is still disputed in the community, while it is not disputed within this chamber. It is partly our responsibility and, hopefully, through this Commission of the Aboriginal people, to try to settle a larger majority on those objectives.

We have had some pretty heavy rhetoric and some sensible contributions so far on these disputes. Doubtless that will continue. I think that up to this point the progress of this legislation has been through a reason- able, sensible process, although it has not been without its traumas. I wish to thank all those senators who served on the Senate Select Committee on the Administration of Aboriginal Affairs for the work that they did. While I did not agree with everything-obviously, one cannot do so in terms of the various reports and dissenting reports-it was obvious that people had spent an enormous amount of time trying to come to grips with this difficult issue. Undoubtedly those people will be to the fore in the committee stages because of the quite extensive knowledge that they have developed over that time. Earlier this year we went through the same type of process in the debate on the corporations legislation. I hope that at the end of the day all the deliberations by this chamber will have contributed to a better Bill.

There are still a reasonably large number of matters in this Bill with which I am not happy. At the end of the exercise one will have to make a judgment as to whether the imperfect composition of the Commission is better than no commission at all. That is essentially the position that I am predicting, not knowing what amendments will be carried in the committee stages, will be the position in which I am likely to find myself. I do not think that the final outcome will be the best we could do, but presumably at the end of the day it might be the only thing that was able to be done at this stage. That is a pity. In politics one lives in hope that the improvements that have been missed this time round will be implemented the next time round.

In previous debates on this matter I have returned to what to me is always the linchpin of the exercise. It is pleasing to see that there is significant emphasis on the obligations of the Commission to deal with land. Without the return of the land where that is possible, without compensatory payments for that which is not possible to return, there will always be a continuing and probably growing dispute between our peoples. I think that at long last the community realises that the types of claims that the Aboriginal people are making are reasonable and genuine claims; that while they may be seen as threatening by some, they do not threaten one square metre of land owned by any white person in this country. But the progress under the legislation passed by the Fraser Government, which was first introduced by the Whitlam Government in the Northern Territory-unfortunately amended to write down some of the very strong positions Aborigines have, under the Hawke Government-should have formed the base from which we could go forward; but we did not. Progress has been so minuscule, so glacial and so slow that one realises the frustrations of the Aboriginal people.

The enactment of this Bill will not satisfy all Aboriginal people. Significant bodies are opposed to this legislation, for a variety of reasons. I think that it will be a significant and very difficult task for this Commission to get a wider consensus of view about where forward movement should be going. But I think that it will do so, given the goodwill of the white population and, hopefully, given a reasonable electoral base and a reasonable group of people in the initial Commission. I am talking not about those who have been appointed to get this rolling but about those who will be elected first up. At the end of the day, it will be on their shoulders whether this actually lives or dies.

We have to keep making these attempts. It is not an easy thing to do, but without making the attempt I do not think that we will ever be able to progress. Because of the disputes that have gone on to date amongst the people in this chamber, I hope that when the Commission is ultimately established everybody will wish it well. We hope that the objectives which everybody in this chamber has said should be supported will ultimately be achieved, because at long last in this country there is unanimity of views amongst all political parties that those are the types of goals that should be achieved in this area.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Violence-Logging: South-Eastern Forests, New South Wales-Myanmar-Child Migrant Scheme

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being 10.30 p.m., the debate is interrupted. Under sessional order I put the question:

INTERJECT.PARA: That the Senate do now adjourn.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Colston Sen M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: -It is with a degree of regret that I raise a particular matter in relation to violence. I mention my regret because violence in any form should be deplored by all Australians. Indeed, it is a tragedy that violence continues to be a major concern to the well-being of Australian society. The prevalence of violence in our society has been extensively analysed and documented. Many behavioural scientists are working towards identifying the causes and effects of all forms of violence. Their efforts and the efforts of others who work towards the elimination of violence should be commended. I also give credit to the media in supporting government initiatives designed to educate the public on the symptoms and causes of violence in the homes and in the streets of our community. In this, as with other matters of genuine public concern, the Australian media have, in general, been responsible and supportive. Nevertheless, any exception to this role of media responsibility in reporting and commenting upon such important issues as violence should, at least, be noted.

SPEECH.PARA: Newspaper readers often give a great deal of credibility to the authority of a newspaper editor or leader writer who seeks to offer opinions through editorial columns. When the editorial section of a newspaper addresses an important public issue such as violence there is an unspoken obligation to write fair, accurate and responsible commentary. Therefore, when editorial commentary is inflammatory and ill-conceived, that newspaper and its editorial staff deserve rebuke from its readers and the community in general. To illustrate this I refer to such an editorial recently published in a Queensland provincial city newspaper. The editorial refers to violence in the streets, concluding with this proposal:
A few more policemen on the beat with a few more well-chosen words and well-aimed cuffs behind the ear . . . that is the way to go.
In any other State of Australia, advice which sanctioned physical force by police and encouraged police brutality in any form would be sternly rebuked by readers.

In Queensland, where the community is still reeling from the scandals of the Fitzgerald Commission of Inquiry into Possible Illegal Activities and Associated Police Misconduct and resulting cynicism toward members of the police force, such an irresponsible editorial deserves the strongest condemnation. If one is to judge from the total lack of response to this editorial in the published letters to the editor in this particular newspaper, however, thousands of readers of this publication did not read the editorial or consent to the use of police violence, or have become complacent in relation to the use of physical abuse by a few bad apples in the Queensland Police Force.

Although readers of the newspaper to which I have referred may have remained silent, I must condemn an editorial which would promote further violence in the streets by encouraging police to take the law away from the judicial process and into their own hands. The action recommended by the editor, to allow police to give a few well-aimed cuffs behind the ear to the youth of the area, will invite confrontation and violence rather than deter it. It can only be hoped that the leadership of the Queensland police force chooses to solve the problem of violence on the streets without physical confrontation. They must, and I believe will, act in a manner which will rebuild trust and respect for police.

Newspaper editors carry a grave burden of responsibility in analysing and addressing issues of public importance for their readers. Any misuse of this responsibility, through frivolous or misleading commentary, serves to denigrate the respected role of journalism. By inciting police brutality against citizens, whether innocent or not, the editorial staff of the newspaper to which I have referred has abdicated its responsibility to the community. By publishing an editorial which encourages rather than condemns violence, the readers of this newspaper, the police and the youth of the area deserve an apology. So too do their more responsible colleagues in the media.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brownhill Sen D.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rarely use the opportunity to speak on the adjournment but tonight I felt compelled to highlight some absurd nonsense that some members of the Government in the other place are peddling. I refer particularly to the honourable member for Hotham (Mr Kent) who last night gave the most ridiculous account of logging in the south-east forests of New South Wales that I have heard for some time. His colourful little piece was so far removed from the reality that even the most dedicated greenie would have difficulty agreeing with him. Mr Kent is one of a number of blow-ins who, from time to time, give politicians a bad name. Obviously, he wanted to give his token environment speech for the session. He spoke last night of the moonscape nature of clear-felling in the south-east forests of New South Wales. He talked of the devastation. He said that it was an eerie experience and that the decimation was unnatural. He claims to have been there. I have taken his word for that, but his comments last night indicate to me either that he had his eyes closed at the time or that he was suffering from a loss of vision. He certainly has not seen the forests that I have seen. Admittedly, I have done more than just travel through the region, as the member for Hotham says he has done. I am fortunate that I have visited the area several times. I have toured the area with both the Regional Forester and the Secretary of the South East Alliance Conservation Group at separate times. I have taken numerous people to the region to let them judge for themselves what is happening.

SPEECH.PARA: What is happening down there is dynamic. Rejuvenated forests cover the landscape, not moonscapes. For a start, clear-felling is not used at Eden as the member for Hotham claims. There is an alternate coupe system. Under this system an area is logged-not clear-felled-leaving seed trees and other trees. The area is not logged again for 40 or 50 years. If Mr Kent had been there he would have known that.

He forgot to mention, or did not bother to find out, that nearly 50 per cent of the area will never be logged because it comprises a national park, nature reserve, or other designated area. He did not mention the wildlife corridors left between every coupe; the areas of known wildlife habitat that are left; the filter strips beside gullies and streams; and the use of cross banks to control erosion. Mr Kent has fallen for the old trick-a little knowledge is a dangerous thing. He knows all the right words; he cited Tantawangalo catchment, Egan peaks, and Coolangubra. They are all the current `in' words for the region. If he wanted to sound like an expert he should have mentioned the long-footed potoroo and the powerful owl. But I digress cynically.

The issue is important. I am pleased that not all members of the Labor Party are Luddites on the issue. The Minister for Resources, Senator Cook, has played a most proper role. He has worked on the basis of managed resources. That is what the Forestry Commission of New South Wales is all about-managing a resource for the maximum benefit of all, for the industry, for the environment. In an ideal world we may well be able to afford the luxury of a locked away resource as important as timber. Unfortunately, until we reach that place, we have to use what materials we can in the best way we can. That is just what is happening in the south-east forests.

I most certainly support the concept of plantations, as do Jim Collins and others. There is just one problem with that: there is not sufficient land available in the Eden area. The best land has been taken for farming, for grape growing, for dairies. If farmers living in that area are opposed to the logging of forests, let them offer their land for sale for plantations. I also happen to know that approaches have been made to these farmers to sell their land and they are not prepared to do so. So in the meantime, the Forestry Commission in New South Wales operates and manages with what resource it can. The Commission would be the first to admit that not everything in the past was done properly. It also would acknowledge that many of the reforms made to logging practice have been brought about by the pressure of the conservation movement and for that we should all be grateful.

We all do things better as we develop and get more experienced, and the New South Wales Forestry Department is no different. But I suggest that it is now the most efficient, most conservation minded of any forestry management in Australia. The management of the south-east forest is an example for the rest of Australia to follow. The two opposing groups each have the best interests of the forest at heart. Many of those involved in the conservation group-and I have met many-have excellent ideas and are not as rabid as the media portrays them. I am confident that it will not be too long before the more rational in both camps get together to resolve their differences. Meantime the ravings of the ill-informed people such as the honourable member for Hotham are doing no good at all. I am pleased that at least one of his colleagues the honourable member for Kalgoorlie, Mr Graeme Campbell, thought little of the arguments given by the member for Hotham and corrected him on numerous issues. Perhaps there is some hope for people taking part in the debate after his contribution.

The south-east forests are an important resource. The forestry industry in Australia employs some 13,000 people directly and another 90,000 indirectly. Our imports of timber currently stand at over $1.3 billion. With a current account deficit running at $18 billion, we need every resource possible to reduce our dependence on imports and expand our exports. The timber industry is one such industry. Forests are a renewable resource and, with the proper management that they are currently receiving from the New South Wales Forestry Commission, they will be with us for hundreds of years. In case there is a misconception, our current account deficit of $18 billion is the correct figure; $1.3 billion is the deficit on our timber imports every year.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cooney Sen B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —At the Australian Legal Convention Mr Mark Weinberg said some things that I want to remark on now and I hope to be able to remark on them in more depth at a later date. Mr Mark Weinberg, a very prominent member of the Victorian Bar, was previously the Dean of the Law School at Melbourne University. He is a silk in Melbourne and is presently the Commonwealth Director of Public Prosecutions. I obtained what he said from the wire service that is available to us here in Parliament House. I do not have his full speech available to me and I hope to get that before I speak upon this matter again. He told the twenty-sixth Australian Legal Convention that there had been an explosion of quasi-judicial bodies, including the Independent Commission Against Corruption (ICAC), the National Crime Authority and the National Companies and Securities Commission. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: We need fewer investigative agencies.
He also said:
We must avoid randomly handing out coercive quasi-judicial powers to those agencies that are established unless there is a clear overwhelming case for them.

He went on to make the point that the ICAC's powers vastly exceed those of the police or even quasi-judicial bodies such as royal commissions and boards of inquiry. I think it is time that we, as a nation and as a Parliament, began to think seriously of the sorts of powers we give bodies to investigate corruption. Nobody wants corruption or crime in our society. I consider the statement made by Vice-Chancellor Sir J. C. Knight Bruce a great statement. Last century, in the case of Pearse v. Pearse, he said:
Truth, like all other good things, may be loved unwisely- may be pursued too keenly, may cost too much.

I give as an example what is happening with the operations of the Independent Commission against Corruption in New South Wales. To illustrate what I mean, in referring to that body, I will look at some of the headlines that have appeared in the Sydney newspapers. One such headline states, `Wal: I want to clear my name'. The article states:
Wal Murray came out fighting yesterday after evidence given to the Independent Commission against Corruption on Tuesday linking him with a bag man from the North Coast developers.
Why should the New South Wales Deputy Premier have to say that?

TALK.START.PARA: —Wait until they start on Neville Wran.

—That is exactly what I am getting at. Although I have great respect for Senator McGauran, I do not like that sort of statement being made. I am using Mr Wal Murray to illustrate how the ICAC can slander people. If Senator McGauran thinks it is proper for Mr Murray to be slandered in that way he ought to think again. It is outrageous that a politician--
—I know your tactics, Cooney. You have had a go. You are dragging--

—I think Senator McGauran misunderstood what I said. I hope that I am misunderstanding what he is saying. This is exactly what I am getting at. With bodies such as the ICAC, people are slandered without their being given an opportunity to clear their names. Mr Murray is saying, `I want to clear my name'. He should never have been put in a position where he had to say, `I want to clear my name'. Senator McGauran might think that is all right, but it is wrong for people to be put in a position where they have to defend their names without any real evidence against them. An allegation was made against Mr Murray. His name was slandered and he had no opportunity to properly defend it. Senator McGauran comes into this chamber and says that that system is all right. He should not say that, no matter what he thinks.
—I did not say that. I know what you are up to, Cooney.
—Order! The honourable member will use the honourable senator's proper title.

—To be fair to Senator McGauran, I think he has misunderstood what I have said; so I will leave him be. But if he has not misunderstood what I said, I am afraid that that illustrates exactly what I have been saying here tonight.

SPEECH.PARA: As I have said, it is desirable and it is in the public interest that corruption and crime be eliminated. But when people's names are put in newspaper headlines from which allegations can be made it is difficult to rebut those allegations in everybody's eyes. When mud is thrown it sticks and it is outrageous that that should happen. I think it is time that we, as a Parliament, took the same strong stand that Mr Mark Weinberg has taken. Mr Mark Weinberg has pulled us up as we should be pulled up. He has asked us to look at what we are doing in giving powers to these bodies and giving them the opportunity to run amuck; I do not say that they have. Looking at the headlines about politicians in the New South Wales newspapers over the last few weeks-it does not matter what party these politicians are from; in this case it was the National Party of Australia-that should never have happened.

I met Mr Wal Murray on one occasion, together with Senator Brownhill. From my meeting with him I can only say that he was a man of the utmost integrity and, as I understand it, he still is. The sorts of things that are run out by bodies such as the ICAC bring him, if not into disrepute, into a shadow from which he has to clear himself. It is therefore disappointing that the Independent Commission Against Corruption Act has been amended by inserting section 17k after section 17j. There is a defence of absolute privilege for the publication of anything that comes out of the Independent Commission Against Corruption. That means that whatever is said before this body and whatever is published is absolutely privileged. So anything can be said-just as anything can be said in this Senate-and run out against people. In my view it is outrageous that powers that have been given to the police and that have been established as a balance over the years should now be usurped and given to bodies that can force people to give evidence under oath against themselves, issue warrants and follow all sorts of extraordinary procedures which are not even available to royal commissions and jeopardise people's careers. Even if they do not ruin these people, in my view it is enough that they have jeopardised their careers.

I have taken this occasion-as I said earlier I hope to develop this further-to praise, with great respect, what Mr Mark Weinberg has said. I urge all parliamentarians to take careful note of what he has said and I hope to return to this subject at a later date when I have more time to develop the theme.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Schacht Sen C.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tonight I wish to make some remarks about the situation that exists in Myanmar which was formerly Burma. In February this year I went privately to Myanmar on a week's visit organised by the Australian Embassy and, in particular, our ambassador, Chris Lamb. I understand that I was the first politician from any Western democracy to visit Burma since the coup took place in September last year that put the army in control and formed the Government of Burma called the State Law and Order Restoration Council (SLORC). The visit to Myanmar was certainly a major experience for me. It gave me an insight into how lucky we are in Australia to have democracy as we know it and how we take things for granted compared with what the ordinary people of Myanmar have now.

SPEECH.PARA: Since I returned I have kept a close interest in the events of that country. I have spoken to members of the local Burmese community, as they are still called here, and at a number of public meetings in Sydney, Melbourne and Perth as well as a public rally recently outside the Myanmar Embassy. The members of the local community here, which I understand is made up of nearly 30,000 people who either were born in that country or are first born in this country but still consider themselves as having very close connections with Myanmar, are very concerned about events that are occurring in their homeland, although they get very little information in Australia as a result of the lack of press freedom in Myanmar.

When I was there I was very impressed by the itinerary that the Australian Embassy arranged for me. I met all the major leaders of the SLORC and all the major leaders of the various opposition forces. I also met a whole range of students and ordinary citizens who had been involved in the various demonstrations that took place last year when the people demonstrated in favour of democracy. I also had the opportunity to travel from Rangoon-I think it is now called Yangon-to Mandalay. I travelled the romantic road to Mandalay and along the way was able to stop at many towns and speak to ordinary citizens. I would like to place on record my appreciation of the Australian Ambassador Chris Lamb. He is without doubt the best ambassador operating in Myanmar today. He has the widest range of contacts. It is certainly known in Bangkok amongst the foreign press correspondents that if one wants to find out anything that is going on in Myanmar the best person to contact is Chris Lamb. He has contacts with both the government and the major opposition figures. He also has a good understanding of the culture, history and politics of the country and has put that to good use. I do not think there has been any diplomat in Burma over the last two or three years who has done more to encourage the restoration of democracy and the holding of free and fair elections than Chris Lamb. He has put the Australian Government's case consistently to the Burmese authorities and, particularly in recent times, to the SLORC.

A book has recently been published which gives details of what happened at the major demonstrations in Burma last year. It was written by a correspondent in Bangkok, Bertil Lintner. The book is called Outrage-Burma's Struggle for Democracy. Bertil Lintner has followed events in Burma over many years and has been a critic of the present government in that country. The eyewitness accounts of the demonstrations last year in that country contained in his book are quite moving. We were all greatly moved in this country when we saw almost live on our television sets the demonstrations in China and the terrible massacre that took place in Tiananmen Square and elsewhere in early June of this year. Many people from Myanmar point out that even more terrible events took place in their country during several months of last year. The estimates of the people killed in demonstrations by the army, by the former regime, now run at between 4,000 and 5,000. The accounts that Bertil Lintner gives of the courage of unarmed citizens facing up to the army and in many cases sacrificing their lives are quite moving. I quote from a couple of those accounts from Bertil Lintner's book to put them on the record. The main demonstration last year was on 8 August. They have just had the first anniversary of that big demonstration. It is estimated that several million people went on general strike or went into the streets to demonstrate for democracy. I quote from the book:

A festive mood prevailed all day-and the army remained in the background at the intersections, protected by rings of students. Spontaneously, some demonstrators struck up the national anthem, the army song and shouted: `The Pyithu tatmadaw (people's army) is our army!' The soldiers were addressed as akogyi, or elder brother; there was a widespread belief that the soldiers would join the uprising and help overthrow the government. To show the soldiers that they would have to kill their own people if they didn't, some young demonstrators even walked up to the lines of troops, which were positioned here and there, unbuttoned their shirts and shouted: Shoot me if you dare!
The demonstration went on for much of the day all over Myanmar. I again quote from Bertil Lintner's book:

At 11.00 pm there were still thousands of people outside the Sule Pagoda. At 11.30, trucks loaded with troops roared out from behind the City Hall. These were followed by more trucks as well as Bren-carriers, their machine-guns pointed in front of them. Spontaneously, the demonstrators began singing the national anthem. Two pistol shots rang out-and then the sound of machine-gunfire reverberated in the dark between the buildings surrounding Bandoola Square. People fell in droves as they were hit. The streets turned red with blood as people `scattered screaming into alleys and doorways, stumbling over open gutters, crouching by walls and then, in a new wave of panic, running again,' . . .

That is an eyewitness account. That went on until three or four o'clock in the morning. Throughout this book are many accounts of similar indiscriminate shootings by the army, not only in Rangoon but elsewhere in Burma, during July, August and September, when it is estimated, as I say, that at least 4,000 people died.

I had the opportunity to meet many people who participated in those demonstrations. I was particularly impressed when meeting young students as young as 14 or 15 years of age from high school and university who had participated in these demonstrations.
